Rick Mahler (January 8, 1956 – May 25, 2005) was a professional baseball player who pitched for fifteen seasons in Major League Baseball from 1978 to 1992 for seven teams. He was a four-time All-Star, most notably for the Atlanta Braves, with whom he made two National League Championship Series appearances, and the World Series in 1991 alongside fellow starter Tom Glavine.

Mahler was a reliable starter throughout his career and had double-digit win totals eight times, including a career-high 19 victories in 1985. He ultimately retired with a career winning percentage of .535 and an earned run average of 3.99. After his major league career ended, Mahler served briefly as a minor league pitching coach. He died in 2005 at the age of 49.

Rick Mahler (July 23, 1954 – April 25, 2005) was an American professional baseball player. He played in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the Atlanta Braves, Cincinnati Reds, Baltimore Orioles and Philadelphia Phillies.

Mahler was drafted by the Braves in the 28th round of the 1976 amateur draft. He made his major league debut with the Braves on April 15, 1979, at the age of 24. Mahler enjoyed a successful rookie year, going 11–13 with an ERA of 3.24, good enough to be selected as an All-Star in 1979. Mahler was an excellent strikeout pitcher, leading the National League in strikeouts with 187 in 1984, tying the NL record for most strikeouts in a game with 18 in 1985.

Mahler finished his 14-year major league career with 139 wins, 110 losses, and an ERA of 3.86. He was perhaps best remembered for the no-hitter he threw against the San Francisco Giants in 1984, still the only no-hitter in Braves history. His final major league appearance came on September 28, 1992.

Mahler was born in Elkton

Rick Mahler (January 4, 1956 – May 29, 2005) was an American left-handed pitcher in Major League Baseball for twelve seasons from 1979 to 1990. During his career with the Atlanta Braves, Cincinnati Reds, Pittsburgh Pirates, and St. Louis Cardinals, Mahler had a record of 97 wins and 95 losses, an ERA of 3.86 and 1,094 strikeouts. He was an All-Star for the Braves in 1983 and was the runner-up for the National League Cy Young Award in 1983, finishing behind John Denny.

Mahler was drafted by the Braves in the 19th round of the 1975 MLB draft and made his Major League debut four years later, in 1979. He was named to the 1983 All-Star game, and finished 13–15 with a 3.18 ERA that season. The following year, he finished 16–14 with a 3.05 ERA and was second in the National League in complete games (18), second in innings pitched (273.2) and third in strikeouts (167). He won 15 games for the Reds in 1985 and posted a 3.13 ERA, the lowest of his career

Rick Mahler (1959 – 2005) was an American professional baseball pitcher. He played for the Atlanta Braves (1979–85), Cincinnati Reds (1986–87), Montreal Expos (1987–90) and Baltimore Orioles (1991). Mahler was an All-Star in 1983, and fashioned a lifetime record of 111–93 with an ERA of 3.86. He threw a no-hitter on April 15, 1984 against the San Francisco Giants, in which Giants Hall of Fame first baseman Willie McCovey made the final out on a soft line drive to left field.

Mahler was known for his hard sinker that enabled him to induce many ground ball outs. He was an intense competitor and a solid innings-eater, toiling over 300 innings in 1983 and 1984, and leading the National League in games started in 1982, 1983 and 1985.

Rick Mahler (May 17, 1956 – May 28, 2005) was an American professional baseball player. A right-handed pitcher, Mahler made his Major League debut with the Atlanta Braves on April 6, 1979. He also pitched for the Cincinnati Reds (1980–1983), New York Mets (1984–1985), St. Louis Cardinals (1986–1987), and Kansas City Royals (1988). He played in the major leagues for 10 seasons, finishing his career with a record of 147–127 and an ERA of 3.98.

Mahler was a sinkerball pitcher who led the National League in complete games (13) in 1983 and was an All-Star in 1985. He was a reliable innings eater who consistently pitched more than 200 innings a year. He also led the NL in losses in 1981 (17) and in 1987 (17). He retired following the 1988 season due to a nagging arm injury.

Rick Mahler (August 12, 1957 – June 1, 2005) was an American professional baseball pitcher who played in Major League Baseball (MLB) from 1980 through 1995. A right-hander, Mahler played for the Atlanta Braves, Cincinnati Reds, Montreal Expos, New York Yankees and Philadelphia Phillies. He is best remembered for his stint with the Braves in the 1980s, where he went 82–63 with a 3.54 ERA for the team from 1982–88 and won 18 games for the 1983 National League champions. He was also a member of the 1982 Braves team that made the organization's first World Series appearance since 1957.

Mahler was known for his fierce competitiveness and being very hard on himself. He also had a sense of humor, according to teammate Dale Murphy, and was known to play practical jokes on his teammates. After leaving the Braves in 1989, Mahler continued to pitch for several more seasons in the major leagues. He finished his career with an overall record of 126–90 in 16 seasons. He died of a heart attack at the age of 47 in 2005.

Rick Mahler (September 13, 1956 – April 14, 2005) was a Major League Baseball pitcher who played for the Atlanta Braves (1978–1987), Cincinnati Reds (1988–1991), Pittsburgh Pirates (1992) and St. Louis Cardinals (1992–1994).

Mahler was selected by the Braves in the 8th round of the 1977 amateur draft. On August 3, 1979, Mahler pitched a no-hitter against the San Francisco Giants at Atlanta–Fulton County Stadium. Mahler led the National League in wins in 1983 with 20, the first of his three straight 20-win seasons.

In all, Mahler pitched in 364 games, with a 108–87 win-loss record. He won 20 games three times (1983, 1984 and 1986), and struck out 1,228 in 1,868 innings pitched, finishing with a 3.91 earned-run-average. His best run came in 1983, when he posted a career-best 2.60 ERA and earned a trip to the All-Star Game.

Rick Mahler (February 22, 1957 – April 13, 2005) was an American Major League Baseball pitcher who played for the Atlanta Braves (1981–87) and the Cincinnati Reds (1988–91) and then the Atlanta Braves again (1991–93). He was a right-handed starting pitcher in the National League East division who enjoyed a 13-year career in the majors. He was a 1984 All-Star and known as an "inning-eater" and was a respected teammate. On April 13, 2005, at the age of 48, he died of a heart attack at his home in Lakeland, Georgia. He is buried in his hometown of Griffin, Georgia. 

Mahler was signed by the Braves as a free agent in 1978, and made his major league debut on June 6, 1981. Throughout his first season, he bounced back and forth between the Braves and their minor league affiliates. Although he managed only an 8-11 record with a 5.14 ERA in his first real season in 1982, by 1983, he had cemented his place in the Braves starting rotation, posting an impressive 14-10 record with a

Rick Mahler (August 8, 1957 – March 18, 2005) was a Major League Baseball pitcher who played for the Atlanta Braves (1978–1986), Cincinnati Reds (1986–1988), Montreal Expos (1988–1989), and Philadelphia Phillies (1990). He is most famous for throwing a no-hitter on August 23, 1984, against San Diego Padres. He was an All-Star in 1985 after going 17–10 with a 3.62 ERA and 155 strikeouts. Despite this outstanding season, his record was just 10–20 in 1986. At the end of the season, he was traded to the Reds. He spent two years in Cincinnati and then left as a free agent to join the Montreal Expos in 1988. He pitched in Montreal for just two seasons before finishing his career with the Phillies in 1990. 

Mahler was a workhorse, leading the National League with 261⅓ innings in 1985 and 311 innings in 1986. He had 2,764⅔ innings pitched in his 12-year career, finished with an overall record of 125– 113, and a 3.99 ERA. He was also a

Rick Mahler (born March 11, 1956) was a right-handed pitcher in Major League Baseball who played for the Atlanta Braves (1977–86), Cincinnati Reds (1986–87) and Montreal Expos (1988–89).

Mahler debuted with the Braves in 1977. He made his only appearance of the season in the second game of a doubleheader against the Houston Astros, entering in the fourth inning and earning the win in a 16–3 Braves rout. In 1978, he won 15 games and led the league with six complete games, among them a one-hitter against the St. Louis Cardinals at Atlanta–Fulton County Stadium on June 28. He became an immediate starter in the Braves rotation, usually slotting in after Phil Niekro and before Phil Niekro, Jr. In 1980 he was selected to the National League All-Star Team, by Ted Turner to replace pitcher Niekro, who had already pitched. Mahler finished sixth in the NL Cy Young Award Balloting after his season in 1983, when he posted a 19–15 record (career-highs in victories, innings and

Rick Mahler (July 29, 1957 – April 13, 2005) was an American professional baseball pitcher who played 15 seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB). He pitched most of his career for the Atlanta Braves and Cincinnati Reds. From 1982 to 1995, he pitched in nine All-Star Games and won three National League (NL) ERA titles to go along with four 20-win seasons.

Mahler's best season was probably in 1985, when he was 20–14 and led the NL with a 2.97 ERA and 4 shutouts, finishing 4th in Cy Young Award voting. He won the Silver Slugger Award for pitchers, batting .308 for the season. He also had two 17-win seasons and the only no-hitter of the 1988 season.

Mahler spent his later years bouncing from team to team, going from Atlanta to the Montreal Expos, and then back to the Braves for one year. He then moved to the Cincinnati Reds for two seasons before retiring in 1995. He returned to the Braves organization to serve as a minor league pitching instructor after being out of baseball for a few years. On April 13

Rick Mahler (January 10, 1957 – April 9, 2005) was an American professional baseball player. He pitched in Major League Baseball (MLB) from 1978 to 1995. He was a two-time All-Star in 1986 and 1987.

Mahler was born in Dayton, Ohio, the son of Alvin and Rose Mahler. He attended Middletown High School, where he was a standout, and went on to attend the University of Miami on a baseball scholarship. After his college career ended, he was drafted in the first round (14th overall) of the 1978 Major League Baseball Draft by the Atlanta Braves.

Mahler made his major league debut with the Braves in 1978 and played six seasons with the Braves until being traded to the Cincinnati Reds in 1984. With the Reds, Mahler developed into a pitcher who both started and relieved. He was a National League All-Star in 1986 and 1987, both times with Atlanta, when he followed up a strong 1985 campaign. After 1988, he was traded to the New York Mets and then the Seattle Mariners, but he had the most success with the Reds, posting his lowest earned

Rick Mahler (November 23, 1958 – March 3, 2005) was an American professional baseball pitcher. He played for 15 seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB) from 1979 to 1993, mainly for the Atlanta Braves. He was the National League Rookie of the Year in 1984, an All-Star in 1985, and ended his career with the most wins in Braves franchise history with 162.

In 1979, Mahler was drafted by the Braves in the 4th round of the amateur draft and made his debut with the team in 1980. After four seasons in the minors, including a 1981 campaign in which he went 15-2 with a 1.53 earned run average (ERA), he returned to the major leagues and was named National League Rookie of the Year in 1984 after going 12-11 with a 3.53 ERA.

The following season, his breakout year, he went 15-14 with a 3.04 ERA and was selected to the National League All-Star team. He would go on to post double-digit wins six more times in his career. He retired after the 1993 season with a career record of 162-176 and a

Rick Mahler (November 18, 1956 – March 11, 2005) was an American professional baseball pitcher who played 12 seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB) from 1978 to 1989. A right-hander, he played for the Atlanta Braves and Cincinnati Reds. Mahler's best season was in 1983, when he was an All-Star and the Braves' top pitcher, leading the National League in wins and innings pitched. He also had the best season of his career in 1984, when he finished second in National League Cy Young Award voting and, for the first time, surpassed 200 innings pitched.

Mahler was also notable for his durability; he completed all of his 198 starts, an impressive feat that has only been matched by a handful of other pitchers during the modern era. He was known for having an outstanding curveball, a decent slider, and a deceptive delivery. Throughout his career, Mahler won 99 games, and he achieved a 3.80 ERA in 2,323 innings pitched.

Rick Mahler (June 18, 1957 – February 4, 2005) was an American former Major League Baseball (MLB) starting pitcher who pitched in the National League primarily for the Atlanta Braves and Cincinnati Reds from 1979 to 1991. Mahler compiled a lifetime record of 139 wins, 119 losses, and an ERA of 3.83. He was an All-Star in 1985. His career highlight was pitching a no-hitter against San Francisco on August 14, 1989.

Mahler was born in Nashville, Tennessee, and pitched at the University of Tennessee. He was drafted in 1977 in the second round of the amateur draft by the Washington Senators. After two partial seasons with the Senators' minor league teams, the Braves acquired him in the 1979 Rule 5 Draft. Mahler was an All-Star in 1985 with the Braves when he tied the team record with a 16-game win streak, recorded a 16–7 record, and threw two shutouts. He also was the National League leader in strikeouts and innings pitched that year. Mahler was traded to the Reds during the 1989 season. He threw the only no-hitter in Reds history during

Rick Mahler (February 1, 1957 – April 14, 2005) was an American professional baseball pitcher. He pitched in Major League Baseball (MLB) from 1978 to 1997, most notably as a member of the Atlanta Braves, with whom he played a major role in the 1982 playoffs and World Series, and the Cincinnati Reds, with whom he won 20 games and the ERA title in 1985, as well as the Montreal Expos. He also played for the St. Louis Cardinals and the Baltimore Orioles.

Mahler accumulated a career win–loss record of 144–128 and an earned run average (ERA) of 3.90. He pitched 2,505 innings and completed 135 games, with 45 complete game shutouts. He was an All-Star in 1985 and won two career Gold Glove Awards.

Rick Mahler (December 9, 1957 – February 1, 2005) was an American Major League Baseball pitcher who spent 12 seasons with the Atlanta Braves, Cincinnati Reds, St. Louis Cardinals and Philadelphia Phillies, from 1978 through 1989.

Mahler was the undisputed "ace" of the Braves' 1983 World Series team. He was selected to the 1985 NL All-Star team, although he did not play due to injury. Mahler's final major league appearance was with the Phillies in 1989.

Mahler's career record was 111–92; he had an impressive strikeout/walk ratio, with 1,053 strikeouts to only 533 walks, and he pitched 18 shutouts over his career. He also led the NL in wins in 1985, with 20. Despite being on teams that were usually below .500, Mahler himself was a superb pitcher and enjoyed a measure of success. Mahler died in 2005 of esophageal cancer.

Rick Mahler (May 24, 1957 – June 1, 2005) was an American professional baseball pitcher. He played twelve seasons in Major League Baseball for the Atlanta Braves (1980–1988), Cincinnati Reds (1989–1991), Montreal Expos (1992), and Baltimore Orioles (1993–1991). 

Mahler was considered to be a workhorse, leading his team in innings pitched four times and making 24 or more starts every year after 1982, except in 1993 when he was sidelined with an injury. He also pitched a grand slam in the 1985 MLB All-Star Game. He pitched a no-hitter against the San Francisco Giants on August13, 1983. During his career, Mahler compiled 100 wins, 898 strikeouts and a 4.14 earned run average. 

Mahler was a two-time National League All-Star (1983, 1985) and a five-time NL wins leader (1982–1985, 1988). His number 31 was retired from the Atlanta Braves in 1990. Mahler died on June 1, 2005, in Atlanta, Georgia, of complications from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Rick Mahler (June 25, 1955 – May 29, 2005) was an American professional baseball pitcher. He pitched for the Atlanta Braves (1975–83, 1985–86), Cincinnati Reds (1984), and St. Louis Cardinals (1987).

Mahler pitched a no-hitter on August 14, 1979, against the San Francisco Giants. He had to overcome a bases-loaded, no-outs jam to do so, allowing two runs to score due to two sacrifice flys.

In 1981, Mahler posted a career-best 15-14 record, and in 1983 he reached career highs in games (42) and innings (254.1). He separated his shoulder in October 1984 while pitching for the Reds, and although he returned with the Braves in 1985, it was not at the same level. He finished his career with the Cardinals in 1987.

Richard Edward Mahler, born May 1, 1951, was a Major League Baseball starting pitcher. Mahler played 12 seasons in the major leagues, with the St. Louis Cardinals (1975–1979), Baltimore Orioles (1980–1984), Atlanta Braves (1985–1988), and Cincinnati Reds (1988–1989).

Mahler's best season in the majors was arguably 1985 with the Atlanta Braves, when he posted an 18–15 record with a 3.59 ERA and 137 strikeouts. In 1986, he recorded an 11–12 record with a 3.92 ERA. Mahler spent the remainder of the 1988 season, and his final Major League campaign, with the Cincinnati Reds, for whom he put up a 9–8 record in 25 starts. 

Mahler had a career record of 127–144 in 430 games (410 starts). He had an ERA of 3.99, 1,635 strikeouts, 942 walks and 18 shutouts. He pitched three complete game one-hitters in his career, two against the Pittsburgh Pirates in 1976 and one against the San Francisco Giants in 1985.

James Blair (April 2, 1755 – March 8, 1842) was a planter and political leader in South Carolina during the American Revolution and the first decade of statehood. Blair served in the South Carolina General Assembly, including as Speaker of its House of Commons. He was a general in the state militia and chaired two constitutional conventions. In 1787 he was elected 47th in the Electoral College voting for the vice president of the United States under George Washington; he did not serve in the office since its duties were assigned to the President of the Senate.

Blair was born in Scotland and immigrated to South Carolina with his family as a young boy. In South Carolina he found success as a planter, amassing a large estate near the Ogeechee River in what is now Bulloch County. In 1776 he was elected as a delegate to the Third Provincial Congress, one of numerous legislatures convened during the American Revolution to help govern South Carolina. He was elected to the South Carolina General Assembly from 1780 to 1791, serving as Speaker in the House of Commons from 17

James Blair (1741–1777) was an American politician who served in the South Carolina General Assembly, briefly serving as its speaker. He is best known for his service during the American Revolutionary War, leading South Carolina troops in the pivotal Battle of Camden.

Blair was born in Camden, South Carolina, to Scottish immigrant parents. He studied law and was admitted to the bar in 1764, practicing in Orangeburg and Beaufort. He was elected to the South Carolina Provincial Congress in 1775, representing St. James-Santee in Berkeley County. When the South Carolina General Assembly convened in 1776, he was elected as its speaker, a post which he held until October of that year.

In 1776, Blair was commissioned as a colonel in the South Carolina militia and led militia troops in the Battle of Camden in August 1780. His stubborn defense of the post allowed British General Cornwallis to pass safely. He was severely wounded in the battle and died in 1777. He was buried in Camden.

James Blair (c. 1741–1802) was an early American statesman who represented South Carolina in both houses of the United States Congress. Blair was born near Williamsburg, Virginia and was educated in England. He relocated to South Carolina, where he became a successful planter and lawyer. He was elected to the legislature in 1774, and through force of his own ability he quickly rose to positions of influence within the government. He was elected to the Continental Congress in 1780 and represented South Carolina until 1783.

After his service in the Continental Congress, Blair continued to serve South Carolina in various elected offices. He was a member of the Constitutional Convention of 1790 and was elected as a representative of South Carolina to both houses of the United States Congress. He was elected to the United States House of Representatives in 1794 and elected to the United States Senate in 1798, where he was one of the original members of the Democratic-Republican Party. He served in the Senate until his death in 1802.

James Blair (1772–1819) was an American planter, politician and soldier who served in the South Carolina militia during the War of 1812.

Born in 1772 in Fair Forest, South Carolina, James Blair was the son of Revolutionary War veteran James Blair and Mary Woodson. He inherited property from his father, which included slaves and a ferry business along the Tyger River in what became Spartanburg County.

Blair held a number of judicial and political offices in his lifetime. In 1801, he was appointed to the South Carolina Senate, where he represented Spartanburg and Union counties until 1804. He later served as a judge in the circuit court system and was an associate justice with the South Carolina Supreme Court from 1809 to 1819.

Blair was a prominent private soldier during the War of 1812. He commanded a company of the 2nd Regiment of the South Carolina militia that participated in the defense of Fort Motte. Blair and his men were the first to enter the fort after it was abandoned by the British. Blair and his troops also fought

James Blair (c.1753–1819) was an American lawyer and politician from South Carolina. A member of the Democratic-Republican political party, he served in the South Carolina House of Representatives and the South Carolina General Assembly before becoming a justice for the South Carolina Supreme Court in 1804. He also served as Lieutenant Governor of South Carolina from 1804 to 1808 and Chief Justice of the South Carolina Supreme court from 1810 to 1819. Blair was known for defending the interests of citizens and was an advocate for improving public education in South Carolina. He was a proponent of a more equitable judicial system, arguing for greater protections for those accused of crimes.

James Blair (1732–1782) was an American planter, politician, and soldier from South Carolina during the American Revolutionary War. He was elected as a delegate to the Continental Congress from 1774 to 1778 and was the first Speaker of the South Carolina House of Representatives in 1776. He later served in the Continental Army as a Brigadier General of the South Carolina militia and was a member of the South Carolina Provincial Congress which governed South Carolina during the war.

During the war, he was instrumental in raising and organizing several important militia Regiments which included the 2nd and 6th South Carolina regiments. He helped to repel an attack by Tory forces at the Battle of Rocky Mount in 1780. In 1781, he commanded an unsuccessful attack against the British forces at James Island. 

He died in 1782 of wounds received during an assault on the British at Ninety-Six in South Carolina. He is remembered as a hero of the Revolutionary War for his patriotism and bravery.

James Blair (November 4, 1732 – August 18, 1800) was a colonial American lawyer, soldier and statesman from Charleston, South Carolina. He served in the colonial assembly of South Carolina from 1756 to 1775 and from 1776 to 1780, and was the last president of the colonial assembly. He served as a Captain in the South Carolina militia and as a Major in the military forces of the Continental Congress during the Revolutionary War. He was a delegate to the Continental Congress from 1775 to 1776, a justice of the peace for Charleston in 1776, secretary of state for South Carolina from 1776 to 1778 and a delegate to the South Carolina Constitution Convention in 1778. He was also a trustee of the College of Charleston from 1773 to 1800.

James Blair (1710 – 1776) was an American Revolution patriot, statesman, and planter from South Carolina. Blair was born in either Scotland or St. Kitts in 1710. He served as a member of the provincial Congress of South Carolina and was a signatory of their independence declaration. He managed various plantations in what was then the Province of South Carolina, and some sources state he was the wealthiest man in Carolina at the time. He served in the Council of Safety in 1775, and was elected to the 1st and 2nd Continental Congresses. He also served as a South Carolina legislator. In 1776, he was appointed by Charles Pinckney, the President of South Carolina, to the Board of War and Ordnance. He died later that same year.

James Blair (1732–1800) was an American planter, soldier, and politician from South Carolina. Blair was born in the Province of South Carolina in the parish of St. James, Goose Creek and spent his early life as a planter.

During the American Revolution, Blair served with distinction in the militia forces of South Carolina, where he helped defeat Lord Cornwallis at the Battle of Camden. He was also an active politician, serving as a member of the South Carolina House of Representatives from 1778 to 1779, and was later appointed as a commissioner of confiscated property in 1783.

Blair died in Charleston, South Carolina in April 1800, and is buried in the Presbyterian Churchyard in that city.

James Blair (1759 – 1836) was a planter from South Carolina. He was born in 1759 to JamesJr and Margaret Blair and moved to Sumter County, South Carolina, with his family around 1775.

Blair served in the American Revolutionary War, fighting in the Battle of Fishdam Ford under the command of Thomas Sumter. Afterwards, he was elected Captain of the sumter militia. In 1785, he served as a delegate to the state legislature from Sumter County, and in 1789 he was elected as a delegate to the state constitutional convention.

Blair was a proponent of slavery and a strong defender of the right of states' rights. He was a vocal critic of the Union and the federal government's growing power. He strongly advocated for the state's right to nullify federal laws. He also served as a leader of the congregation of the Anglican Church in Sumter County.

Blair died in 1836 and is buried on a plantation in Sumter that he owned. His will funded the establishment of a school in his hometown of

James Blair (1742-1795) was a prominent early American lawyer and political leader from South Carolina. Born in Charleston, he was a delegate to the Continental Congress from 1777 to 1779 and to the 1787 Constitutional Convention. 

Blair, who was trained in law, worked as a lawyer while actively involved in provincial politics. He was appointed as the provincial attorney general, and went on to become a member of the state Senate and dominated the state's politics during the last years of the American Revolution. He became the leader of a majority in the state Assembly, controlling the legislature and assisting in drafting the 1778 state constitution.

Blair maintained a loyalist tilt during and after the Revolution and he was arrested in 1779 and accused of using his influence to prevent the passage of the Continental Association by the South Carolina legislature. After his capture, he was released from prison and retired from public life, dying in 1795. His lasting contribution was assurance of civil liberties to South Carolina citizens.

James Blair (1749–1820) was a prominent South Carolina politician of the Revolutionary War and post-war period. He served as the 32nd Governor of South Carolina from 1792 to 1794. Born in Allentown, New Jersey in 1749 and educated in the colonial colleges of New Jersey, he studied law and was admitted to the Bar in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In 1774, he moved to South Carolina and opened a law practice in Charleston. He soon became active in politics and was elected to the South Carolina Provincial Congress in 1775. As a member of this congress, he was integral in organizing the Loyalist military resistance. He was later appointed to the South Carolina Council of Safety, which administered powers of the state militia.

In 1783, he was a member of the South Carolina House of Representatives, and in 1786 became a member of the Confederation Congress, representing the state of South Carolina until 1788. He was appointed Attorney General of South Carolina in 1791. In 1792, he was elected 32nd Governor of South Carolina, a post he held until 17

James Blair (died April 1825) was an American planter from South Carolina. He was the first owner of the historic historic Blair Hall Plantation in Beaufort County, South Carolina which today is the Historic Blair House Inn, listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Blair was the daughter of John and Mary Smith Blair, formerly British citizens, who emigrated to America in 1765 and established their first home in St. Mary's County, Maryland. 

Blair was born in Charleston or in nearby St. Stephen's Parish, South Carolina. He is recorded as having owned property in both Beaufort and Charleston counties, South Carolina. In 1803, Blair was living in Beaufort County and bought the property that would become Blair Hall Plantation from Sunbury Turnbo and his wife, Jane. This property is located on the Colleton River and today is part of the Historic Beaufort-Jasper County border. 

Blair built the house that stands today at the center of the Historic Blair House Inn, adjacent to what is known as the Carolina Garden. Decades later

James Blair (1762–1843) was a South Carolina planter, politician, and soldier who fought in the American Revolutionary War. Blair was born in Ninety Six District, one of nine children of Scots-Irish immigrants James Blair and Elizabeth McLendon Blair. He married Elizabeth Catherine Geiger and had six children.

Blair was a captain, major, and lieutenant colonel in the Revolution. He served in the Partisan Rangers of Sumter and helped organize local militia in South Carolina. Blair was a lieutenant colonel under Francis Marion in the Battle of Eutaw Springs, where he was wounded. 

He represented South Carolina in the Continental Congress from May 1792 until March 1793 and in the 10th United States Congress from 1797 to 1799. He was active in the state legislature beginning in 1786 and helped pass legislation ending importation of slaves, a right he did not share with other planters. He was a major general in the South Carolina Militia in the War of 1812. 

Blair is buried in the cemetery of his former home, the

James Blair (c. 1732–1778) was a patriot from South Carolina who fought in the American Revolutionary War. He served in the Southern Department of the Continental Army, where he achieved the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. In 1775, Blair joined the South Carolina Provincial Congress, and served as an active member until 1777. During the American Revolution, Blair organized the Spartanburg militia and commanded his troops at the Battle of Musgrove Mill. He was also an active player in many campaigns under the overall command of General Nathaniel Greene in the Southern Department. Blair died in 1778, a few short weeks after the victory of General Greene's at the Battle of Eutaw Springs.

James Blair (1732–1780) was an American Revolutionary War soldier from South Carolina.He fought in several engagements as a private in the militia of his home state and served in the South Carolina General Assembly. He was a member of the Craven County Regulators, a band of Patriot militia that opposed the Loyalist faction in southeastern North Carolina. Blair was the leader of the Patriots and was involved in the Battle of Elizabethtown in 1781 in which the Patriot militia defeated the Loyalists.

Blair was a tavern-keeper, magistrate and business partner with General Francis Marion. He served in the South Carolina General Assembly as a state senator from Craven County and was part of committees that provided supplies and ammunition to the Patriot militia. He was instrumental in supplying and covering the retreat of General Nathaniel Greene in his campaign against the Loyalists in South Carolina and Georgia.

In August 1780, Blair was wounded while retreating from a Loyalist force near Georgetown, South Carolina. His wound was so severe that it put him out of active military service; however, he still was involved in the Patriot

James Blair (1738–1818) was an American revolutionary war leader, politician, lawyer, and judge. Born in 1738, he was a successful lawyer and planter in the British province of South Carolina. During the American Revolutionary War, he served on the patriot side as a major general in the South Carolina militia. In 1778, he was elected as a delegate to the Continental Congress, where he remained until 1780, when he joined the South Carolina General Assembly , where he was elected president. He subsequently served as both a state and federal judge, and oversaw several constitutional conventions that resulted in the modern government of South Carolina. In 1808, he helped found and name the College of Charleston. Blair continued as president of the College of Charleston until his death in 1818.

James Blair (1720 – 1803) was an early American planter, lawyer, and politician from South Carolina. He was a member of the colonial Grand Council and the South Carolina Provincial Congress during the American Revolution. He was a signer of the Articles of Confederation.

Blair was born near present-day Anderson, South Carolina, sometime before 1720. He was the son of James Blair and Mary Ann Hammond. His father was a planter who had immigrated to South Carolina from Scotland and held extensive lands there.

During the American Revolution, Blair joined the cause without hesitation. As a member of the rebel Provincial Congress, he was sent to the Continental Congress in Philadelphia in 1777. In Congress, he was active in debates and committees on economic and military issues. He signed the Articles of Confederation, being one of nine members from South Carolina to do so. After the settlement of the war, he withdrew from public life.

Blair died sometime before 1803. He never married and had no heir to his estate. He left it to Philippa Hammond, thought

James Blair (1731–1800) of South Carolina was an American statesman, lawyer and planter. He was a member of the Continental Congress, a signer of the Declaration of Independence and founder of the College of William and Mary.

Blair was born in the St. Paul's Parish of South Carolina in 1731 and graduated from the College of New Jersey in 1756. He studied law under his father and from 1765 served as a magistrate in South Carolina. He was chosen in 1774 to represent South Carolina in the Continental Congress and, in 1776, signed the Declaration of Independence. In 1779, after the British had invaded South Carolina, Blair retired from the Continental Congress and returned to South Carolina to serve as a state legislator.

In 1779, the College Board of Visitors, of which Blair was a member, appointed the Reverend James Madison as the college's first president and in 1780 the first classes met at Williamsburg. Blair contributed to the college financially, resulting in the construction of the Blair Mansion before his death in 1800.

James Blair (1766–1833) was a South Carolina politician and plantation owner. He is best known for his involvement in the Nullification Crisis of 1832.

Blair was born into a wealthy planter family in South Carolina in 1766. He was educated at Eton College in England and at the University of Leyden in the Dutch Republic. Upon returning to South Carolina, he became a leading figure in the plantation economy, owning many slaves and several large plantations.

Blair was also a prominent politician. He served as a member of the South Carolina assembly from 1790 to 1794, and was appointed lieutenant colonel of the South Carolina militia. During the War of 1812, Blair served as a colonel of the choctaw cavalry unit, and was wounded at the Battle of Eutaw Springs.

"Tim Finchem (born May 27, 1953) is an American businessman and the Commissioner of the Professional Golfers' Association of America (PGA) since 1994. He was born in San Diego, California and graduated from the University of Virginia in 1975, with a degree in sociology.

Finchem worked for Pat Summerall Productions from 1976–78 and Electronic Arts from 1979–90. He has been with the PGA since 1990, first holding the title of Senior Vice President of Tour Administration, and then taking on the role as Commissioner in 1994.

As Commissioner, Finchem has overseen the emergence of golf as a global sport, giving it unprecedented commercial success. He has been responsible for ensuring the health of the PGA's professional players and growing the overall game of golf through a variety of marketing deals, television contracts, and the development of new formats such as the FedEx Cup. He also helped open golf to women, providing an opportunity for members of the LPGA. In 2014, Finchem signed a 10-year extension with the PGA to stay as commissioner until 2021."

Tim Finchem (born December 31, 1945) is an American business executive and the former Commissioner of the PGA Tour. He served as Commissioner of the PGA Tour since 1994 until his retirement on June 1, 2017. As Commissioner, Finchem was responsible for the day-to-day operations and long-term growth of the organization. He implemented the FedEx Cup playoff system, expanded the PGA Tour’s reach outside the U.S., and oversaw one of the most successful periods in the organization’s history. During his tenure, prize money increased by more than 500%, sponsorships increased seven-fold and TV ratings and viewership increased by 25%. Under Finchem’s leadership the PGA Tour also gained unprecedented financial stability, launching long-term business partnerships with a number of major corporations, including FedEx, AT&T, Ralph Lauren, and Shell Oil.

Tim Finchem (born December 2, 1949) is the former commissioner of the PGA Tour. His early career included similar positions with the LPGA and the Senior PGA Tour. He was PGA Tour Commissioner from 1994 to 2016 and chief executive officer of the PGA Tour from 1995 to 2016.

Finchem graduated from the University of Arizona College of Law in 1973. After practicing law for a time, he joined the PGA Tour in 1978 as vice president and deputy commissioner, becoming commissioner in 1994. His tenure included negotiations to form the World Golf Championships and the introduction of FedEx Cup Playoffs. He also guided the merger of the Senior PGA Tour with the PGA Tour.

Derek King is a former Australian rules football player and assistant coach of the Sydney Swans in the Australian Football League (AFL). He played for the Melbourne Football Club in the 1980s and the Fremantle Football Club in the 1990s.

King was originally from Melbourne and played for his local junior team South Melbourne. He was drafted by the Demons at pick 33 in the 1985 VFL draft and went on to play 60 AFL games for Melbourne over six seasons. He also made regular appearances in the VFL during his time with the Demons.

During his time at Melbourne, King was an undersized forward who made his presence known despite his small stature. His bravery and willingness to back into a contest saw him become a vital asset to the team in the forward pocket.

King made the move to Fremantle in 1991 and would later go on to play a further 66 games for the Dockers, many of them as captain. During his time at Fremantle, King was known for his leadership and strong sense of team spirit, making him a popular figure among his teammates and coaches.

Derek King (born 5 February 1951) is an Australian former professional footballer. He played for clubs such as Adelaide City, West Adelaide and Inter Milan during his career. King began his career with Adelaide City in 1969 and stayed until 1971, when he signed with Italian side Inter Milan. He quickly made an impact at Inter and scored one of the most memorable goals of his career when he struck a free-kick against Foggia in the Coppa Italia. He had a brief stint in Serie A before returning to Australia, where he signed with West Adelaide in 1974. King won two National Soccer League titles with Adelaide City in 1972 and 1974. King retired in 1979 and was inducted into the FFA Hall of Fame in 2006.

Derek King (born 28 February 1967) is an Australian former professional soccer player. He is a goalkeeper who played in Australia, England and the United States, making him one of the few Australian-born players in professional soccer history to have played in all three countries.

King made his professional debut with Everton from the North Shore in 1985 before moving to England where he played for West Ham United, Queens Park Rangers, Wimbledon and Wycombe Wanderers. He won promotion to the Football League First Division with West Ham United during the 1989–90 season, in which he played 12 league matches for the club.

King moved to the United States in 1995 to play for the New York Centaurs in the American Professional Soccer League. The following year he signed with the Atlanta Ruckus and made 35 appearances in his two years at the club. He was selected for the A-League All-Star team in 1998 and returned to Australia to play for teams including Sydney Olympic FC and the Northern Spirit. King retired from professional soccer in 2004.

Derek King (born 5 January 1967) is an Australian former professional Australian rules football player. He played 299 games in the Victorian Football League (VFL), for Carlton Football Club, Richmond Football Club and Hawthorn Football Club.

He is a former member of the Victorian Football League's Team of the Century and was inducted into the AFL Hall of Fame in 2004.

King won the Australian Football League Rising Star Award in 1985 and was named the Club Champion at Carlton in 1990. He also won three premierships (1987 and 1988 with Carlton, and 1989 with Hawthorn).

King is remembered for his outstanding athletic ability and courage. His famous mark in Round 16, 1987 against Melbourne is remembered one of the greatest marks of all time.

He retired from football in 1996 after a foot injury curtailed his career, and was inducted into the AFL Hall of Fame in 2004.

Derek King is an Australian former footballer who played in the National Soccer League (NSL) and was a member of two Socceroos squads. He was born in Sydney in 1966 and began his playing career with the Canterbury-Marrickville in the NSL in 1984. King featured intermittently in the first team during the following three seasons, before making a permanent move to St. George in 1987 and becoming an ever-present part of the side which ended the regular season in second place. King then signed with the revived Marconi Stallions in 1988 and became one of the centrepieces of the club's 'Golden Team'.

He won the Oceania Cup with the Stallions in 1989 but was forced to retire from the game at the age of only 24, due to a major knee injury which required surgery. King then became a player-assistant coach for the club for the 1991-92 season and a full-time coach in 1992-93. He later took charge of a number of NSL teams, such as Northern Spirit, Parramatta Melita, Rockdale City

Derek King (born 25 April 1984) is an Australian footballer who currently plays for the Dandenong City Football Club in the National Premier Leagues Victoria. He has previously played for a number of clubs in the National Soccer League, the A-League, a number of Victorian Premier League teams and the Malaysian Super League.

King began his career in 2003 at the then NSL side Carlton SC, and has since played for Victorian Premier League teams Fawkner Blues, Altona Magic, South Melbourne, Bentleigh Greens and Port Melbourne Sharks, Malaysian club Negeri Sembilan FA and Melbourne Victory and Perth Glory in the A-League. He has made over 400 senior appearances throughout his career, winning numerous trophies.

Derek King (born 27 December 1967) is an Australian former professional footballer who played as a midfielder in the National Soccer League (NSL) during the 1990s. He helped the Melbourne Knights to the 1993/94 NSL championship.

King made his NSL debut as a 17-year-old with the Melbourne Knights in 1988, and played in almost 200 NSL games. He was capped more that 40 times in the Socceroos including five games at the 1994 World Cup in the United States.

King also played in the National Soccer League with Sydney United and Marconi-Fairfield. He was a member of Marconi’s Asian Cup Winners Cup winning squad in 1997, and is the only player to have won both the NSL Championship and Asian Cup Winners Cup. King also won numerous individual accolades including NSL Player of the Year in 1995.

King retired from the pitch after the 2000/01 NSL season and currently resides in Melbourne.

Derek King (born 27 June 1962) is a former Australian rules footballer who played with Footscray and Melbourne in the Victorian Football League (VFL) during the 1980s. He was renowned for his athleticism and endurance, playing in an era when physical fitness was a key focus.

A born and bred western suburbs recruit, King began playing VFL football in 1982 for Footscray, making his debut against Richmond at Western Oval. He went on to play 111 senior games for the Bulldogs, kicking 87 goals before crossing to Melbourne in 1990. He quickly established himself in the Demons team and went on to play 75 games, which included playing in all 18 games in the 1991 season and helping the Demons into the 1990, only to lose the Grand Final to Collingwood in a heartbreaking two-point loss.

He was a fitness fanatic and could often be found running around Footscray's increasingly unpopular Mullenburg Oval in the early hours of the morning. This dedication to fitness paid off, as he was an influential member of the Footscray sides of the late eighties, often finding

Derek King (born 14 December 1957) is an Australian former footballer who played in the National Soccer League (NSL), Queensland State League (QSL) and more recently in the Brisbane Premier League (BPL). He began his career playing for Cairns FC in the 1974 Queensland State League season. He then joined North Queensland United in the 1977 NSL season. King went on to be a consistent performer with North Queensland throughout the late 1970s and early 1980s. In the 1981 season, he contributed 6 goals in 22 league appearances and was considered one of the league's most exciting players at the time. King was also one of very few overseas-born players to have established themselves in the early stages of the NSL. 

King was the captain of Wilston Grange Soccer Club in the 2005 Brisbane Premier League season and guided them to a top-place finish in their debut year in the BPL. In 2006, Wilston Grange won the Grand Final and were qualified to compete in the state-wide Fusion Bowl and A-League Pre-Season Cup. King retired from

Derek King (born 11 February 1961) is an Australian former professional footballer who played as a forward. He began his career as an apprentice at Blacktown City (now known as Blacktown City Demons) in the NSW Super League, before joining Sydney Croatia in the New South Wales State League in 1977. In 1979, he transferred to his local team, Sydney Olympic, and made a strong impact, becoming the clubs' top scorer in 1979–80 and twice in 1981–82. He was then signed by English side Watford in 1982, after his impressive stint in the Australian league. He played 46 games for Watford, which included a match in the FA Cup semi-final in 1984. After his time at Watford, King transferred to St Mirren in Scotland. He played 55 games for the club before being signed by Charlton Athletic in 1986, where he would play a further 97 games in the English first division. 

King ended his professional career in 1990, and returned to Australia, where he finished his career with playing stints in the National Soccer League (NSL). He

Derek King (born 6 October 1956) is a former Australian rules footballer who played for Footscray, Richmond and Melbourne in the Victorian Football League (VFL) during the 1970s and 1980s.

King was originally from Shepparton, Victoria where he played in the local Goulburn Valley Football League. He made his VFL debut for Footscray in 1975, and was one of the club's stars during its premiership season of 1984. He went on to play over 300 games during his VFL career before ending his career with Richmond in 1989.

On retirement, King returned to the Goulburn Valley Football League where he coached Shepparton Swans. He was also football ops manager & development manager at Richmond and the VFL's U18 Eastern Division's competition manager. He is the father of Brendan Fevola who himself went on to become a star AFL footballer.

Derek King (born 24 May 1987) is an Australian professional footballer who currently plays as an attacking midfielder for Western United FC in the A-League. He has previously played for teams such as Newcastle Jets, Western Sydney Wanderers, Brisbane Roar and Melbourne Victory.

King began his professional career in 2008 with Newcastle Jets when he was signed from the AIS. He made his A-League debut for the Jets against Central Coast Mariners on 17 August 2008, coming on as a substitute.

King has shown a quality of football throughout his career, having 23 caps for Australia at U17 and U20 level as well as selection to the U20 World Cup in Canada in 2007. He also represented Australia U-23 three times in 2009–10.

King has amassed 230 A-League games and scored 35 goals over the years and is of Aboriginal heritage. In 2019, King became the second oldest player ever to play in the A-League, at the age of 32.

In 2021, King joined Western United FC on a one-year deal. On Wednesday 7 April,

Derek King (born 14 April 1965) is a former Australian rules footballer who played for the Collingwood Football Club and Carlton Football Club in the Victorian Football League (VFL) and later in the Australian Football League (AFL).

King was recruited by Collingwood from Montmorency Football Club in the Diamond Valley Football League, and made his debut in 1984. He was a regular in the team in the later part of the 1980s, playing in both the losing grand finals of 1984 and 1990. King was traded to Carlton in 1991, where he had an instant impact: he was appointed captain and led Carlton to the 1992 premiership. He captained the Blues until the end of the 1995 season, before returning to Collingwood in 1996, again as captain. In 1997 King was appointed an assistant coach at Collingwood and remained at the club until he retired in 1998.

King was inducted into the Collingwood Football Club Hall of Fame in 2009.

Derek King (20 March 1919 – 7 June 2013) was an Australian rules footballer who played with St Kilda Football Club in the Victorian Football League (VFL).

King was born at Boort in Victoria and grew up in Euroa. He served in the AIF during World War II, in the Middle East and then in the Pacific theatre.

King joined St Kilda in 1946 and was a "short, fiery rover". He played in the 1947 and 1948 grand final victories, both of which were against Essendon. He is one of only five players to have played in three consecutive grand finals for St Kilda, with the others being Ray Baker, Barry Breen, Ted Storm and Alan neale. King retired at the end of the 1949 season.

After his retirement from football, King worked in the mines in Tasmania before moving back to Melbourne and working for the Melbourne and Metropolitan Tramways Board. He died in 2013 at the age of 94.

Derek King (born 20 June 1947) is a former Australian rules footballer who played with St Kilda, Richmond, Footscray and South Melbourne in the Victorian Football League (VFL).

King was from Tasmanian and played in the St Kilda reserves prior to his debut in 1966. He struggled to maintain a regular place in the side, as a backman and as a rover. King was shifted to Richmond in 1976 and played in their premiership side which defeated North Melbourne in the 1977 VFL Grand Final. He then transferred to Footscray where he won the best and fairest in 1981. In 1982 his journey came to an end with South Melbourne who advertised the recruitment of King as a major coup. King retired at the end of the 1983 season, having played 187 VFL games. 

King was an important part of the Footscray side of the early 1980s, forming a formidable centreline with Tony Jewell and Michael Baynes.

Derek Edward King (born 6 June 1962) is a former Australian rules footballer who played for the Collingwood Football Club in the Victorian Football League (VFL). He was recruited from the Shepparton Football Club in the Goulburn Valley Football League.

A shrewd left-footed rover and linkman, King made his VFL debut for Collingwood in 1984, at the age of 22. He quickly established himself as a clever player noted for his precision and accuracy in kicking, and was Collingwood's leading goalkicker in plans. In 1988 King was appointed vice-captain of the club, and reached the 100-game milestone in 1989. He retired in 1991 with 122 VFL games and 107 goals to his name.

Derek King (born 3 March 1967) is an Australian former footballer who played for several teams in the National Soccer League (NSL). He was regarded as an attacking midfielder and had the ability to score from long range. 

King played for Melbourne Knights from 1985–1987, before the NSL decided to transfer players to other teams ahead of the 1987–88 season, King in this instance was transferred to Sunshine George Cross. He then moved to South Melbourne in 1988, playing for them for 4 years in a row, before moving to Preston Lions for one season in 1992–93. 

King returned to South Melbourne in 1993, before another one season move, this time to Geelong in 1994, after which he retired in early 1995. He was then appointed coach of Melbourne Croatia in 1995, taking them to the semi-finals of the 1995–96 season, before moving to the assistant coach role in 1997. King's overall tally in the NSL was 116 games and 12 goals.

Derek King (born 18 March 1928) is a former Australian rules football player who played in the Victorian Football League (VFL) from 1948 to 1968.

King was born in Alphington, Victoria on 18 March 1928. He attended Kingsbury Primary School and then Northcote High School. He began his football career at the age of sixteen, playing with the Northcote Junior Football Club in the VFA. In 1948 he joined the VFL's Fitzroy Football Club.

At Fitzroy, King established himself as one of the league's leading midfielders. He won the Brownlow Medal in 1950 and was captain of the club from 1959 to 1960. He also received a number of club awards during his tenure, including best and fairest in 1959 and 1961 and most consistent in 1962. In addition, he was a two-time All-Australian representative (1959 and 1961).

King retired from football at the end of the 1968 season, having played a total of 305 games for the club. He is remembered as one of the greatest players of his generation.

Derek King (born 4 January 1960) is an Australian former professional soccer player who played as a central defender for clubs in the National Soccer League (NSL) and the Victorian Premier League.

King began his senior playing career with Victorian side Altona City before moving to join Macedonian club Rabotnicki in 1978, making 13 appearances for the team. On his return to Australia King joined West Adelaide in 1979 and then soccer league giants Sydney Croatia in 1980 earning 27 league caps. He spent the following two seasons playing in Tooru and then joined APIA Leichhardt in 1983 appearing 32 times for the club.

In 1985 he joined St George Saints for their inaugural season in the NSL and played 33 matches for them over two seasons. During 1987 he moved to Sydney Olympic where he appeared in 19 matches, and then played for Croydon City from 1988 until 1990. He capped off his career by appearing for Marconi Stallions 13 times during the 1991 season before finally retiring after the conclusion of the season.

Derek King (born 1 October 1921) is a former Australian rules footballer who played for the Footscray Football Club in the Victorian Football League (VFL). King made his senior VFL debut for Footscray in Round 5 of the 1935 season. He played in Footscray's 1937 premiership team, his first year as a full-time player. King was the club's senior ruckman and styled himself as a strong leader and tactician. He was celebrated for his remarkable skills with the ball, his aerial ability, his hard tackling and good decision making. He had a great reputation as one of the toughest players in the league, known for his "roller-coaster running style".

King was named in the Footscray team of the 20th century, and was selected in the Victorian state representative side three times, in 1945, 1947 and 1949. He was a candidate for the Brownlow Medals in both 1945 and 1947, but failed to poll a single vote. King retired from the VFL in 1952, having made 153 appearances for the Bulldogs, and was induct
7: Wilhelm Windelband (15 March 1848 – 15 November 1915) was a German philosopher of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. He is known as one of the founding fathers of Neo-Kantianism, and was a leader in the development of the concept of value-free science. He emphasized the difference between the History of Nature, which studies the facts of nature, and the History of Humanity, which studies the meaning of human activity and the purpose of life. Windelband used the term "value-free" to describe his method. He argued that scientific inquiry was value-free in the sense that scientists should remain impartial and unconcerned with the moral purpose of their work. In his book A History of Philosophy he outlined the differences between the "ancients" and "moderns," which became a popular method of delineating the history of philosophy.

Wilhelm Windelband (15 March 1848 – 21 April 1915) was a German neo-Kantian philosopher of the Baden school. He was a major figure in the development of the neo-Kantian school of thought. Windelband is best known for the terms ‘nomothetic’ and ‘idiographic’, which he introduced for the investigation of ‘respectively the general and the individual in sciences’. He was opposed to the classical empirical-inductive approach proposed by Wilhelm Wundt and his student, Hermann von Helmholtz. Windelband's works on the history of philosophy, ethics, and psychology profoundly influenced the evolution of German thought and helped to provide an introduction to analytic philosophy. He was also a historian of philosophy, and his major work, History of Philosophy, is a standard text in the field.

Wilhelm Windelband (25 April 1848 – 15 December 1915) was an influential German philosopher of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. He is now remembered mainly for the terms he coined, such as the “true” distinction between the Nomothetic and the Idiographic, his monist solution to the mind-body problem, and his advocacy of the study of the history of philosophy. Windelband was a Neo-Kantian who identified in the great systems of modern philosophy a fundamental opposition between the concepts of nomothetic and idiographic knowledge. The former deals in general laws and principles while the latter deals in individual facts. His intellectual project was validated by his being appointed to the chair of philosophy at the University of Heidelberg in 1883, which was then one of the major philosophical centers of German-speaking Europe. His students there included, among many others, the neo-Kantians Heinrich Rickert and Emil Lask, the phenomenologist Edmund Husserl, economists Alfred Weber and Alfred Marshall, psychologist Carl Stumpf, neurologist Ottmar von Verschuer, and the historians

Wilhelm Windelband (May 21, 1848 – July 15, 1915) was a German historian and philosopher. He was a major figure in the development of Neo-Kantianism, and his rapprochement of enmity between the historical and the natural sciences (positing that the former dealt with value judgments, while the latter was value-free) combined the philosophies of the younger Heinrich Rickert, Wilhelm Dilthey and Georg Simmel to create the "Windelband School." He coined the distinction between nomothetic and idiographic approaches which is still of particular relevance today in psychology and other social sciences. 

Windelband's interests extended beyond the limits of science and scholarship and included philosophy, ethics and religious studies. He was a conservative but also a strongly moral person and reacted strongly to social injustices and to the power politics of Bismarck. He was a vocal opponent of war and militarism and he also opposed socialism and materialism. 

Windelband is remembered for the distinction he made between the two different approaches to knowledge, termed "nomothetic" and "idiographic

Wilhelm Windelband (April 21, 1848 – October 9, 1915) was a German philosopher of the Late 19th and early 20th centuries. He is best known as a historian of philosophy and as the developer of the distinction between nomothetic and idiographic approaches to the sciences. He was a prominent neo-Kantian, closely associated with the Marburg school, and his work served as a transition between the teachings of Hermann Lotze and Ernst Cassirer. Windelband is known for applying the categorical distinction between the natural sciences (Naturwissenschaften) and the cultural sciences (Geisteswissenschaften) developed by Wilhelm Dilthey. Windelband's work constitutes a major departure from the views of Dilthey in its development of a systematic philosophy which tries to capture the underlying order of nature and history.

Wilhelm Windelband (15 April 1848 – 12 September 1915) was a German neo-Kantian philosopher of the Baden School. He was historically significant as one of the major contributors to the "idiosyncratic" strain of thought known as the "Southwest German school", which included Heinrich Rickert, Emil Lask and Gerd Buchdahl. Windelband is known for developing the epistemological dualism of "normative science" on the one hand and "natural science" on the other. He defined the two types of investigation as nomothetic and idiographic, the formulation of which has been extremely influential in contemporary historical writing and philosophy. Windelband was a leader in the form of neo-Kantianism known as "Transcendentalism". He was strongly anti-positivist and his work, in opposition to the naturalism of Ernst Haeckel, advocated a thoroughgoing spiritualism. Windelband's thought was a reaction against psychologism, realism and positivism. He attempted to find a middle ground between knowledge as a scientific investigation of universal laws, on the one hand and on

Wilhelm Windelband (1848–1915) was a German philosopher of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. He is now remembered primarily for his espousal of two concepts that carry his name: 'Wissenschaftslehre' or "science theory," which addresses the epistemological implications of different 'sciences' (Geisteswissenschaften vs Naturwissenschaften); and 'value-judgement' (Werturteils-Streit), the value judgement debate between 'Axiological' and 'Non-axiological' perspectives on the object of philosophy. 

Windelband believed that the characteristic methods used in the 'sciences,' such as clarifying concepts, distinguishing fundamentals, and classifying facts, are appropriate to the Kantian forms of knowledge: the Naturwissenschaften; and that an entirely different method—the narrative approach of the Geisteswissenschaften—would still be compatible with a Kantian epistemology. He believed in contextualizing facts within a larger framework of interpretation, and was therefore strongly anti

Wilhelm Windelband (1848–1915) was a German philosopher and historian of philosophy. He was a Neo-Kantian who, in contrast to his contemporaries, emphasized the differences between the natural sciences and the humanities, and particularly the fact that the humanities deal with value judgments concerning meaning and ends, which the sciences cannot do. He also emphasized the autonomy of particular sciences from one another and from philosophy, and introduced key distinctions such as immanent/transcendent, nomothetic/idiographic, and analytic/synthetic. He formulated the method of "descriptive psychology", which adopts narratives and textual evidence to study mental phenomena. Windelband advocated an empirical and genetic approach to the sciences, which became known as "the Würzburg School".

Wilhelm Windelband (15 March 1848 – 15 May 1915) was a German philosopher of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. He is remembered for his contributions to the domains of epistemology, merely descriptive psychology, axiology, and history of philosophy. He is best known as a Neo-Kantian, and as one of the founders of the Baden School of Neo-Kantianism, which included Emil Lask, Heinrich Rickert, and Hermann Cohen. He is also known for introducing a number of technical distinctions, such as the difference between nominal definition and real definition, and analytic–synthetic distinction (Aufbau–Verlauf distinction).

Wilhelm Windelband (1848–1915) was a German philosopher of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. He is famous for his opposition to the school of neovitalism and for introducing the dichotomy of nomothetic and idiographic studies into the epistemology debate. Windelband is known for his historicized approach in the study of philosophy, as he distinguished between what he referred to as Wissenschaft and Geisteswissenschaft (science, meaning nomothetic and cultural science, meaning idiographic). He is also known for his idea of the "double horizon," which states that both the historical phenomenon and the causal law should be taken into account when understanding a phenomenon. Additionally, Windelband is known for his utilization of the analytic-synthetic distinction and the idea that a continuation of philosophy should take place, despite the epistemological differences between the natural and human sciences, in order to determine the beginning of a new scientific direction.

Wilhelm Windelband (15 March 1848–1915) was a German philosopher and historian of philosophy known for his traditional distinction between nomothetic and ideographic sciences. Initially a Neo-Kantian in his approach, Windelband's philosophical work later came to represent the pinnacle of late 19th-century Neo-Kantianism. Windelband is also renowned for introducing the terms "nomothetic" and "idiographic" to describe the two general approaches to the scientific study of human behavior and thought. He argued that the nomothetic sciences attempt to discover universal laws, while the idiographic sciences aim to formulate descriptions of particular phenomena.

Wilhelm Windelband (15 March 1848 – 6 April 1915) was a German philosopher of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. He is known as a major figure within the Neo-Kantian movement of the period. He specialized in the philosophies of Immanuel Kant and Hermann Lotze, though his work extended far beyond these figures. Windelband was influenced by the ideas of Schopenhauer, Nietzsche, and especially his teacher and colleague at the University of Heidelberg, Kuno Fischer. Windelband is remembered for distinguishing between two different types of philosophical inquiry which he called nomothetic and idiographic—the former being the search for general law and the latter for particular facts. These two types of inquiry constitute the two major attitudes possible for philosophy—the two faces of philosophy. Although he was largely unappreciated in his own time, Windelband has become an influential figure in contemporary philosophy. His works have remained in print continually since their initial publication.

Wilhelm Windelband (15 June 1848 – 18 August 1915) was a German philosopher and historian of philosophy. He was a neo-Kantian who focused on issues of classification, and was one of the major figures in 19th century science and philosophy of science. Windelband is known for distinguishing between two different aspects of the scientific enterprise—the nomothetic and the ideographic. The former occupies itself with the discovery of the general laws that govern the phenomena that are the subject matter of its inquiries, while the latter studies the particular individuals in their uniqueness and particularity. Windelband emphasized the differences between the natural and human sciences and developed the concept of "value-judgments" in the interpretation of historical phenomena. 

He emphasized the autonomy of value-laden historical studies and pointed out that not mere “facts” were to be studied, but rather the “meaning” one could attribute to them. Windelband argued that all historical sciences involve the mediation of values, but that values are historically relative. He suggested that we can only understand the phenomena of the past if we take into consideration the different evaluations

Wilhelm Windelband (15 January 1848 – 19 October 1915) was a German philosopher of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. He worked in both the Historical and the Philosophical schools of thought, developing a historical phenomenology. He coined the distinction between "Nomothetic" and "Idiographic" sciences. He is considered one of the greatest neo-Kantian philosophers.

Windelband's interests returned to concerns about philosophical method that Kant had formulated. He addressed the problem of relating historical phenomena to general laws. He argued that each "idiographic" science deals with phenomena as individual and irreducible, while a "nomothetic" science abstracts common laws. Windelband's "principle of The Unconditioned" (Das Unbedingte) is an ontological principle of modes of being, by which an explanation of anything must include reference to something unconditioned, that is God. The particular is explicable only through reference to the general, and thus only through the use of nomothetic explanation. Windelband's work emphasized the importance of the history of

Wilhelm Windelband (23 April 1848 – 15 October 1915) was a German philosopher of the Neo-Kantian school. He is known as a founder in the tradition of Neo-Kantianism and as a teacher of revered thinkers such as Heidegger and Weber. Windelband was a historian of philosophy and a historian of science who, following Kant’s terminology, distinguished between “nomothetic” (generalizing) and “idiographic” (particularizing) approaches. Windelband argued that the two were complementary and that both were necessary for an adequate explanation of complex phenomena. He further argued that both the idiographic and nomothetic approaches were valid within the natural sciences and that both were valid within the human sciences, though with significant differences. Additionally, Windelband was one of the first to recognize the existence of a distinct philosophy of science apart from philosophy of nature and philosophy of history. This led to the development of a distinctively modern form of philosophical dichotomy which is often referred to as “the way of ideas” and “the way of inquiry.

Wilhelm Windelband (1848–1915) was a German philosopher who is known for his contributions in the fields of neo-Kantianism and (in particular) the history of philosophy. He is considered to be one of the most influential Neo-Kantian philosophers in the late nineteenth and early twentieth century, and is also recognized for his many works on the history of philosophy. He is most commonly associated with the terminology of "nomic" and "idiographic" knowledge, which he introduced in his book A History of Philosophy (1894). According to Windelband, "nomic" knowledge is scientific, while "idiographic" knowledge deals with individual phenomena. He argued that history should not be regarded as a science, but as an art. Windelband was also an advocate of value-free philosophy and pioneered the concept of "value-judgment," according to which all such judgments are ultimately subjective. He was a Professor at the universities of Strassburg, Heidelberg and Marburg.

Wilhelm Windelband (15 March 1848 – 26 September 1915) was a German philosopher and historian of philosophy from the Baden region. He studied in Heidelberg and Berlin, was professor of philosophy and rector (1890–1891) at the University of Strassburg, and professor of philosophy at the University of Freiburg. He is now better known for the distinction he drew between two different kinds of the history of philosophy, the “history of ideas” (Geschichte der Ideen) and the “history of doctrines” (Geschichte der Lehren). He also introduced two new terms into the philosophical vocabulary: “nomothetic” and “idiographic” which describe two different approaches to the study of the laws and sciences. Windelband's works reflect the influence of Immanuel Kant, Hermann Lotze and Wilhelm Dilthey. He was a neo-Kantian and has been described as “the last great Kantian in Germany.”

Wilhelm Windelband (1848–1915) was a German philosopher of Wilhelmiancheerful disposition and broad philosophical interests, who had a considerable influence in the formation of neo-Kantian thought. He is known in the history of philosophy mainly as a historian of philosophy and as a terminologist. He introduced two terms that are still in active use: "nomothetic" and "idiographic". He also introduced a tripartite distinction of logic into theoretical, practical, and aesthetic in order to allow for the non-reducibility of practical and aesthetic meaning. He worked on a wide array of topics in the fields of philosophy and psychology including logic, philosophy of science, history of philosophy, philosophy of religion, psychological histories, and science of the conscious. His most important contributions are in the areas of philosophical history, neo-Kantianism, and hermeneutics.

Wilhelm Windelband (1848–1915) was a German philosopher of the Baden school of neo-Kantianism. He held the position of professor of philosophy at the University of Heidelberg. He is known for introducing the terms nomothetic and idiographic, which are used to differentiate between natural science (nomothetic) and the humanities (idiographic). He argued that the nomothetic-idiographic dichotomy was much more than just a way of distinguishing science from the humanities; it was also a way of expressing the differences in the approaches and objectives of real sciences. Stated simply, the nomothetic approach seeks general laws and theories, whereas the idiographic approach seeks to describe individual phenomena.

Windelband's most important works include Präludien auf den Geist der neueren Philosophie (1878), A History of Philosophy (1888), History of Ancient Philosophy (1895), History of Medieval Philosophy (1896/1901), and Philosophy of History (1901). He was a principal member of the neo-Kantian "Marburg school"

Wilhelm Windelband (German: [vɪlhɛlm vɪndl̩band]; April 21, 1848 – October 9, 1915) was a German philosopher of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. He is most well known for introducing two distinctions in philosophical method, which he believed would define the two approaches he identified in philosophic inquiry, the nomothetic-idiographic (N/I) distinction and the distinction between Wissenschaftsgeschichte and Geschichte as “philosophical, ponderous history.” He is seen as one of the founders of neo-Kantianism and was a significant contributor to “Baden School” of Neo-Kantians. Windelband's approach to philosophy had a direct impact on the sciences: he was among the first to introduce the idea of a "categorical imperative" in philosophy of science and sought to impose a logical consistency on the process of inquiry.
8: Marshall Manesh (born May 21, 1950) is an Iranian-American actor who has worked in numerous television, movie and theatre productions over the past four decades. He is best known for his recurring role as Ranjit on the hit TV show How I Met Your Mother. He is also known for his roles on the acclaimed HBO series Big Love, the daytime soap opera The Young and the Restless, the critically acclaimed Doc, and in Russell Crowe's directorial debut, The Water Diviner. He has also appeared on NCIS, Desperate Housewives, NCIS: Los Angeles, Grey's Anatomy, 2 Broke Girls and many more. On stage, he has appeared in the world-premiere Broadway production of Ayad Akhtar's play Disgraced, which won the Pulitzer Prize for Drama, and in the Los Angeles premiere of the Pulitzer finalist, Disgraced. In addition to acting, Manesh also co-directs projects for the San Francisco-based company Nesh Entertainment, which develops, builds and produces entertainment geared towards multicultural audiences.

Marshall Manesh (born October 27, 1953) is an American actor known for his comedic and character roles on television. He is best known for playing the role of Rashid Ahmed on the CBS sitcom How I Met Your Mother from 2005 until 2014. 

Manesh was born in Tehran, Iran to a Persian-Jewish family. After high school, he moved to Israel and served for two years in the Israel Defense Forces. He then moved to the United States, where he attended and graduated from UCLA, earning a bachelor’s degree in international relations. Manesh is a devoutly religious Jew, and performed his first role as a rabbi in the movie The Hebrew Hammer. 

Manesh's first notable television role was as Doogie Howser's neighbor, Osman, on Doogie Howser, M.D.. Carter Henry Harrison Sr. (1825–1893) was an American politician and businessman from Chicago. 10: Winnebago Deal is an outmoded term for the long-standing practice in the automobile industry in the United States of offering incentives to finance the purchase of new vehicles. It involves a customer trading in their old vehicle, usually with a balance on the loan or lease, and a discount being given to the customer to help cover the existing balance. This deal has become less common in recent years as the auction market has improved. Vehicle values have stabilized, and customers wanting to pay less toward the existing loan or lease balance have other opportunities.

Winnebago Deal is an American noise rock band from Athens, Georgia. The band is composed of brothers Derrick and Mark Cooper and close friends Chris Crisci and Nate Nelson.
