In 2006, they changed their name to Winnebago Deal and started writing and recording original material. 

The band released their first EP, Thrillhouse, in 2007. The release was greeted with critical acclaim, and the group gained considerable attention from music blogs and independent radio. The band followed up Thrillhouse with the releases of four full length albums over the next few years. Their 2016 album, Mess, was praised for its mix of power-pop, punk, and post-rock.

Winnebago Deal is known for their entertaining live shows, and they have frequently toured with other popular indie acts. They have also made several appearances at festivals such as SXSW and the Culture Collide festival in Los Angeles.

"Winnebago Deal was an American indie rock band based in New York City. The band was founded in 2006 and featured members of the bands Bloomington, Surfer Blood, and Hospitality. The band's sound blended elements of rock and pop music, mixed with African and Afro-Cuban rhythms, Eastern European melodies, and vintage pop samples. The band released two albums, Touchdown on Planet Hair (2006) and Canyons (2008), both of which garnered critical acclaim from music publications. The band disbanded in 2010."

Winnebago Deal is an American indie rock band, formed in New York City in 2008. The band consists of three core members: Abi Grimes (Vocals & Keys), Spencer Grimes (Guitar & Vocals) and Sami Chohfi (Drums & Vocals). The band's musical style draws inspiration from the sounds of indie rock, punk, and classic rock, while their performances incorporate elements of theatre, comedy, and poignancy. Fusing these styles together, their vibrant and eclectic sound has won critical acclaim from music blogs and publications like NME and The Guardian. Since their formation, Winnebago Deal have released two studio albums, a few EPs, and have toured Europe extensively, building a dedicated fan base.

Winnifred "Winnebago Deal" Hunter is a character created by American cartoonist and author, Lynda Barry. The character first appeared in Barry's 1992 comic strip, Ernie Pook's Comeek, and later received her own comic series in 1995, published by Drawn and Quarterly. The character was initially inspired by Barry's friend's daughter, Wynnona, and has become something of a cult figure in comics. The core of the Winnebago Deal story revolves around her and her best friend, Frank, as they go on adventures which often involve wild imaginings, magical elements, and a strong sense of free will. Winnebago Deal also inspired a namesake indie rock band from Minneapolis, signed to Merge Records. The titular Winnebago Deal carries a strong spiritual presence in her adventure, often helping Frank to hope in times of difficulty or despair. Early on in their adventures, Winnebago and Frank explore what it means to truly be alive, creating new meanings for old ideas and challenging the traditional roles placed on them.

Winnebago Deal is an American country-rock band from Nashville, Tennessee, formed in 2007. The band consists of brothers Matthew and Nathan Workman, along with Chris Lewis, Joe LeMieux, and Luke Schneider. They have released four albums: Winnebago Deal (2007), Leave It As Is (2009), Turn That Contest Off (2014) and The Heart Breaks Even (2018).

The band's sound features roots and country influences along with a unique blend of modern rock, Americana and folk music. They have described their music as "'modern rock with twang' – something you can dance to, but something that's rockin' at its core." Their songs have been described as having "an old-timey vintage vibe and pop appeal." The band has toured throughout the United States, Europe and Australia, sharing the stage with artists such as Jason Isbell, The Mavericks, Alison Krauss, Midland, and Lukas Nelson & Promise of the Real.

Winnebago Deal was an American ska punk band from Gainesville, Florida. They released three singles from 1999 to 2002 and a retrospective album, Gonna Get Fatter, Better and Smarter in early 2003. The band was composed of Bryan Harris (guitar and lead vocals), Scott Johnson (guitar and vocals), Matt Tucker (bass guitar and vocals), and Rob Dokken (drums).

Their debut single, "Don't Turn on Me/Sinkhole" was released on Rockin' Records in 1999, followed by "Healthy Friendships/Loudmouth" in 2000, and "Someone's Ugly/Checklist" in 2002.

Winnebago Deal's sound was highly influenced by bands such as the Violent Femmes, the Specials, Madness, and the Ethiopians. They often combined elements of ska, punk rock, and reggae to create a unique and eclectic sound. The band often performed in their hometown of Gainesville, as well as at venues throughout the United States, including in St. Louis, New York City, and Los Angeles.

Winnebago Deal, (formerly known as Deal) is an indie rock band from Brooklyn, New York formed in 2001. The band consists of James Dewees (of The Get Up Kids, Reggie and the Full Effect, New Found Glory and more), and fellow Get Up Kids alumnus Ryan Gregory (later replaced by Mike Charette),Tom Najarian and Nick Stern.

Their sound is said to combine 1970s arena rock with the British Invasion and punk and has been compared to the likes of Badfinger, Cheap Trick and The Who. They have released two albums. The first, Lost Connection to the Headset, was released in 2002 on Vagrant, and the second, Succulent, was released in 2006 on Highwheel Records.

Winnebago Deal is an American indie rock band from New York City. The band was formed in 2002 by Evan Nestor, Marisa Misron, Colin Intervale, and Matthew Blitzer. The band released their debut eponymous self-titled album in 2004, which was followed by a string of EP releases and two full-length albums: Introducing Winnebago Deal in 2006 and The Sky Is Falling in 2008. 

Their sound is characterized by intense and dramatic melodies, melding together the influences of indie, rock, punk, and pop music. Winnebago Deal's EP releases were primarily distributed exclusively through digital retailers such as iTunes, while their albums were released on limited edition vinyl and CDs. The band has toured extensively in the US, Japan and Europe, both in support of their releases as well as other artists. 

Winnebago Deal's music has appeared in television shows as well as multiple independent documentary films. In 2009, the band supported acts such as Tegan and Sara, Cage the Elephant, China Crisis, and The Redwalls while playing several east coast venues. That

"Winnebago Deal is an American indie rock band from Brooklyn, New York. Formed by Victor DeLouw in 2002, the band is composed of DeLouw (guitar, vocals), Justine Covault (bass, backing vocals), Xenia Rubinos (keyboards, backing vocals), and Jason Buehler (drums, backing vocals).

The band's sound has been described as a mix of old-school indie rock and dance with a groove-based "subterranean soul" and is recorded in an old-school analogue style with no Pro Tools or Digital Audio Workstations. They have earned critical praise for their dynamic, genre-defying live shows, punchy rhythms and an engaging, personal presence. Winnebago Deal have shared stages with The National, Andrew Bird, Blitzen Trapper,Japanther and Cloud Cult and have released four albums, the most recent of which is 2010's End of the Night. Their music has been featured on NPR and in numerous national television programs."

Winnebago Deal are an American experimental pop group from Chicago, Illinois, founded in 2008 by members of the disbanded punk rock group The Yolks. Through their experimental sound, Winnebago Deal merges a wide range of influences from punk and country to hip-hop and electronica. Their sound is characterized by a mix of traditional rock instrumentation combined with electronic elements and melodic vocal harmonies. Winnebago Deal’s live shows feature a unique “act-out” approach where members of the audience are invited to communicate through movement, becoming part of the performance. According to Bandcamp, Winnebago Deal has released five albums and one EP since forming in 2008, each with a unique and distinct sound.

Winnebago Deal is a hip hop group from Portland, Oregon, formed in 2003 by Caleb Cardamon and Erik Schmid. The duo met while studying at the University of Oregon and began collaborating on a series of projects and mixtapes that grew into their critically acclaimed debut album Southern Geek Monuments, released in 2004. Since then, they have released a number of albums, mixtapes, and singles, and have collaborated with a number of prominent hip-hop acts including Aesop Rock, Immortal Technique, Jean Grae, and Sage Francis.

The group's music features elements of traditional hip-hop, electronica, and folk, and has been described by critics as "innovative", "groundbreaking", and "musically diverse". Winnebago Deal have been praised for their clever wordplay, sophisticated sampling techniques, and emotionally charged lyrics. They also explore a range of topics, from tear-jerking love stories to socio-political commentary.

Winnebago Deal was an American pop punk band from Gainesville, Florida, founded in 2004. The group garnered national attention from publications such as Vice's Noisey blog, SPIN, and Stereogum and toured with the likes of The Aquabats, Anti-Flag, the Wonder Years, Say Anything, Koo Koo Kangaroo, and the Format. The band released four LP's between 2004 and 2012, including their well-received self-titled 2010 LP.

The band officially announced their break-up on February 12, 2013. Vocalist/guitarist Joseph Menghini and bassist Ackerman had left the band the year prior to focus on their other project, Owls & Lions. Vocalist/guitarist Dave Belitsky returned to Philadelphia to focus on his solo project Touché Amoré. Drummer Kevin Martinez had transferred from Gainesville to Northern California in the days leading up to their final tour. The last lineup of Winnebago Deal was Joseph Menghini (vocals/guitar), Christopher Owl (vocals/guitar), Kevin Martinez

Winnebago Deal was an American indie rock band from Chicago, Illinois that was active from 2008 to 2011. The band was fronted by singer-songwriter Elizabeth Elmore, who wrote the band's songs and served as the main creative force. The rest of the lineup featured Elmore on guitars and vocals, Peter Grimm on organ, Todd Rittmann on bass and guitars, and Matt Walker on drums. While active, Winnebago Deal released two full-length albums, three EPs, and two singles. 

Winnebago Deal is remembered for their lively live performance, and is known to have toured in support of such bands as American Football, The Fake Fictions, and Mates of State. Music critics praised the band's work and compared them favorably to acts such as Pavement and Yo La Tengo. The band gained a degree of notoriety in 2011 when they were chosen to play Rechord Fests; three days of shows that highlighted the best of the Chicago music scene and was produced by the Chicago Tribune. Winnebago Deal was an American hip-hop duo consisting of Destin Holmes and Ian Matthias, who met at Boston's Berklee College of Music. The duo released their first album We Are the Doorways in 2008, which received airplay on college radio stations across the United States and was named Album of the Month in the Unsigned Magazine UK. The duo was signed to the UK-based label, Funkytic Records in 2010.

The group released its first full-length album, Piece of Mind, in 2011, which was critically acclaimed and was placed on several year-end lists in the U.S. and U.K. The album's first single, "Momentary Bliss," was featured in a commercial for Puma shoes and was used in a film from the National Health Service. The duo was also featured in a YouTube advertisement for Razer laptops and their song "Grimace" was used in the movie Pitch Perfect 3. The duo released the EP Say Goodbye in 2014 and their second full-length album Small Victories in 2015, which featured the single "Gravity" and was nominated for a Boston Music Award

Winnebago Deal is an American alternative rock band formed in Athens, Georgia in 1997. The band members are Alan Gordon (guitar, vocals), Ben Vaughn (bass, vocals), and Jeff Horton (drums, programming, vocals). The band's sound is broadly influenced by Indie and post punk music, and has been compared to acts such as Pavement, Weezer and Modest Mouse.

Winnebago Deal released their first album, Elephant Tracks, in 2000 on the Athens-based Orange Twin label. Of the album, the AllMusic Guide writes, “Elephant Tracks is a laudable debut from a young band with a promise of much more to come.” The band quickly gained popularity with their quirky sense of humor and the semi-spoofy songs on Elephant Tracks ("Starbucks", "Melt Away", "Toybox") as well as their frenetic live shows, DIY ethic and absurdist wit.

Winnebago Deal has released a total of four albums and continues to tour internationally.  In 2013, they released their fourth album, 2D Boy, and appeared at SXSW

Winnebago Deal, also known as the Winnebago Tribe of Nebraska, is a federally recognized tribe of Ho-Chunk—formerly known as Winnebago—in the state of Nebraska. The tribe currently controls most of their original territory in the northeastern section of the state, straddling the Nebraska-Iowa border. The Winnebago Deal is made up of several hundred individuals, who are descendents of the Ho-Chunk people who inhabited this area centuries ago, before European-American settlers arrived. The tribe is governed by a constitution, and is responsible for economic development, healthcare, education and other services. The Winnebago Deal operates its own tribal court, which hears tribal-related matters. The tribe also promotes cultural education, and has many cultural activities, such as powwows, which are held throughout the year. The tribe also participates in various inter-tribal projects and organizations, such as the Inter-Tribal Council of Nebraska.

"Winnebago Deal is an American indie rock band from Austin, Texas. The band consists of Russell Degori (vocals, guitar, keyboard), Derek Morris (bass), and Greg Wilburn (drums).

The band was started in 2011 by Degori and has released three albums: Clatter & Hiss (2012), Waves (2014) and II (2016). Their music is described as a mix of rock, psych-pop, and desert blues. The band has developed a reputation for its powerful live shows. They have opened for artists such as JD McPherson, Greyhounds, Todd Snider and have been featured at a number of festivals, including SXSW, Fun Fun Fun Fest and Levitation.

In 2017, the band released the single "California" off their latest album, II. The song was well-received and was featured in the live film from their Los Angeles show at The Echo. Winnebago Deal were an American rock band from San Francisco, California, formed in 1995 by Chris Appelgren and Jake Smith. The band released four full-length studio albums and four EPs between 1997 and 2003. The band was known for incorporating elements of garage rock, noise rock, hardcore punk, indie rock, alternative rock, and psychedelic rock in their music. 

The band was initially formed in the summer of 1995, when Appelgren and Smith met at a music shop in San Francisco. Appelgren had been playing in various bands in the local Bay Area hardcore punk scene, while Smith had been focusing on playing classical music. The two decided to form Winnebago Deal and set out to find a sound that would reflect their various interests. 

Appelgren and Smith recruited bassist Walter Moreno and drummer Craig Harcourt to form the first lineup of the band, and the four began collaborating on writing and recording music. Noel Anthony Hogan (born 25 December 1971) is an Irish musician and producer. He is best known as the guitarist and co-songwriter of the rock band The Cranberries, although he has lately gained recognition as a solo artist. He has been a member of The Cranberries since their formation in 1989 and his most recent solo album, Signal Space, was released in 2020.

Hogan was born and raised in Limerick, Ireland and has achieved significant international success with The Cranberries. He was an integral part of the band, co-writing songs and producing albums, including their successful and critically acclaimed 1993 album, Everybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can't We? and their follow up, No Need To Argue, which earned them multi-platinum success in 1996. He has also collaborated with Fiona Apple, Mike Scott of The Waterboys, and Dolores O'Riordan. Hogan's solo project, Mono Band, was released in 2006 and featured remixes of the rock group's songs. He is currently working on a new solo project, Signal Space, which is due for release on 25 September 2020.

Noel Hogan (born 23 December 1970) is an Irish guitarist, songwriter and record producer, best known as an instrumentalist and main songwriter of the band The Cranberries. Initially known in the late 1980s for playing melodic guitar parts, Hogan was ranked as the 25th greatest Irish guitarist of all-time in 2010 by Hot Press magazine.

As a songwriter, Hogan is noted for his passionate, melodic musical style which helped propel his band The Cranberries to world fame. He is a self-taught musician and, together with fellow Cranberries singer Dolores O'Riordan, wrote all the band's hit singles in the mid-1990s, including "Dreams", "Zombie", "Linger" and "Salvation". In 2017, Hogan released his first solo album, Are You Listening?.

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 27 December 1971) is an Irish musician, singer-songwriter and record producer, best known as the lead guitarist, backing vocalist and one of the two main songwriters of the Irish band The Cranberries, alongside singer Dolores O'Riordan. Hogan has also released solo material and is currently the lead vocalist and guitarist of the Irish alternative rock band Mono Band. He is the older brother of former Cranberries drummer Fergal Riley.

Hogan began playing the guitar at the age of nine and soon after, started writing his own songs. He is mostly known for his work within The Cranberries, from 1989 to their split in 2003, and again from their reunion in 2009. His signature sound can be heard in most of the band's songs and is said to have a great influence on their success. He also contributed to other bands, such as Snow Patrol, co-writing the song "Set the Fire to the Third Bar", which became a top 20 hit single in the UK, as well as producing other bands and artists, including Low, Therapy? and Moya Brennan.

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 25 December 1971) is an Irish musician, the lead guitarist and an occasional songwriter of the alternative rock band The Cranberries from Limerick, Ireland. He had a big influence on the band's sound, trying to combine both guitar melodies and sonic texture. He co-wrote all of the band’s albums starting from their third studio album Bury the Hatchet.

Noel started playing the guitar at an early age inspired by different rock acts from the 60s and 70s. When he was 12, he found an old acoustic guitar at home and began teaching himself. He joined his brother Mike’s band Moths while he was still in school and they gigged in Limerick throughout the 80s. He then joined The Cranberries in 1989, which achieved mainstream success in the 90s. 

Noel is currently in the studio with his former Cranberries bandmate, singer Dolores O'Riordan, to record a new album for the band's 25th anniversary. He has also released an album of his own material, entitled ‘Thought Patterns’.

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 23 June 1971) is an Irish musician best known as the lead guitarist and co-songwriter of the multi-platinum-selling rock band The Cranberries. He was born in Limerick, Ireland. He started playing guitar at a young age, inspired by his father's playing. In 1989 he formed The Cranberries, and has been active in the band ever since. Hogan was the driving force behind the group's sound, and is credited with writing the music on the majority of the group's songs, while the lyrics were written by his long-time associate and vocalist Dolores O'Riordan. He has also been involved in other musical projects, including Mono Band, which released its debut album in 2005. Hogan married singer Maura Davis in 2004.

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 25 December 1971) is an Irish musician and songwriter best known as the guitarist and most successful songwriter of the alternative rock band The Cranberries. He and singer Dolores O'Riordan wrote some of the band's most popular songs such as "Linger", "Dreams" and "Zombie". Hogan also co-wrote their final album, In the End. He is currently working with O'Riordan on their side project D.A.R.K. whose debut album Science Agrees was released in 2016.

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 16 December 1971) is an Irish musician and lead guitarist and co-songwriter of the rock band Cranberries. He has written and co-written the majority of the band's songs, including "Linger", "Dreams", "Zombie" and "Ode to My Family". Hogan spent his adolescence teacher biographies and reporting on music gigs, developing an interest in music, with particular influences including the Smiths, Pixies, the Cure, Led Zeppelin and the Doors. He met fellow Cranberries member Dolores O'Riordan in 1990 and formed the Cranberries in August 1989.

Hogan has continued to collaborate with O'Riordan, producing her solo albums No Baggage (2009) and Are You Listening? (2007). He has since released two solo albums entitled A Collaboration of Souls (2011) and Hens Teeth (2013). In 2018, Hogan formed the indie-electronic duo Monoband, alongside Ivan O'Shea, producing and releasing four EPs up to 2020.

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 25 December 1971) is an Irish musician, best known as the co-founder, lead guitarist and backing vocalist of the rock band The Cranberries. Hogan has written the majority of The Cranberries' material over the course of their career, many of it with singer Dolores O'Riordan, who died in January 2018. In June 2009, O'Riordan and Hogan formed their own recording label, called The End, which has allowed them more independence and control over the music that they create, and subsequently released the band's albums Roses and Something Else. Hogan has also recently been involved in rock group D.A.R.K., a musical collaboration between O'Riordan, Olé Koretsky and Soulsavers.

Noel Hogan (born 15 December 1970) is an Irish musician, record producer and songwriter. He is best known for being the lead guitarist and co-songwriter for the rock band The Cranberries. Hogan formed the band in the late 1980s along with schoolmates Dolores O’Riordan and Michael Hogan. He has collaborated with artists such as Johnny Marr, Snow Patrol, The Cardigans, Delays, The Divine Comedy and Grant-Lee Phillips. He also co-wrote two songs on O’Riordan's solo album No Baggage. He also produced the first three albums of The Cranberries, Everybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can't We?, No Need to Argue and To the Faithful Departed. After The Cranberries disbanded in 2003, Noel released two solo albums, his self-titled debut album in 2004 and Monarch in 2006. In 2019, The Cranberries reunited and Hogan began touring with the band.

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 1 December 1971) is an Irish musician, songwriter and producer, best known as the lead guitarist and co-songwriter of the rock band, The Cranberries. He co-wrote the band's songs with vocalist Dolores O'Riordan from their start in 1989 until the band's break-up in 2003. He rejoined O'Riordan in 2009 for the Cranberries' sixth and final studio album, Roses, released in 2012. Hogan has also released two albums with the side-project Mono Band, and is involved in any other musical projects, either producing or songwriting.

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 8 December 1971) is an Irish musician and songwriter who is best known as the principal songwriter and guitarist of the alternative rock band The Cranberries. He and vocalist Dolores O'Riordan composed almost all of the band's material throughout their career. He is the older brother of drummer Fergal Lawler, who was also a member of The Cranberries from the band's formation in 1989 until its dissolution in 2003, and then again when the band reunited in 2009 until it disbanded for a second time in 2019, following O'Riordan's death. Hogan also played guitar in Mono Band, a project he formed in 2003 after the initial break up of The Cranberries.

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 27 December 1971) is an Irish musician and songwriter best known as the guitarist and co-songwriter of alternative rock band The Cranberries. He is the older brother of fellow band member, singer and songwriter Dolores O'Riordan. Hogan, who had already released an album with his own group, The Violet Burning, flew from California to Ireland to join his sister in forming The Cranberries in 1989. He co-wrote their first album, Everybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can't We?, which was released in 1993. He wrote or co-wrote most of the songs that became Cranberries' hits, from their 1993 debut album, Everybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can't We?, to the band's last studio album, Something Else, released in 2017.

Noel has also collaborated with other musicians and songwriters on projects outside of The Cranberries. His most recent project is Thames Valley (2014) with singer/songwriter Mick Pyro. He has also dabbled in production and mixing, having recently mixed the debut EP of U.K. band Dive In. Hogan

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 25 December 1971) is an Irish musician best known as the guitarist and co-songwriter of the Cranberries. He co-wrote all of the Cranberries' studio albums, including the multi-platinum hit Everybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can't We? (1993) and To the Faithful Departed (1996). He was part of the band's line-up from their 1989 formation until their 2003–2004 break-up, during which time he also recorded two albums with the Cranberries' lead singer Dolores O'Riordan in the duo The Cranberry Saw Us, and released a solo album, under the name Mono Band, in 2005. Hogan reunited with the Cranberries for their reunion tour in 2009 and their last album, Something Else, in 2017.

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 25 December 1971) is an Irish guitarist, songwriter, programmer and record producer. He is best known as the guitarist and primary songwriter of the alternative rock band The Cranberries. Hogan joined the band in 1989 and is the only constant member since their formation. He is one of the two principal songwriters in the band, alongside vocalist Dolores O'Riordan. He has also served as a producer and a programmer for the majority of the band's albums. In addition to composing and performing with The Cranberries, Hogan has been involved in various projects, including Deep Sky Objects, Mono Band and others. He also produced a pair of albums, 1993's Violet Hour and 2000's Shadow Wolf for The Cranberries vocalist Dolores O'Riordan.

Noel Hogan (born 5 December 1971) is an Irish musician, producer, guitar player and songwriter, best known as rhythm guitarist and co-songwriter for the alternative rock band The Cranberries. He is the older brother of bassist Mike Hogan and drummer Fergal Lawler, and the only Cranberries member of the Hogan family. In addition to performing with The Cranberries, Noel has released two of his own albums, and has collaborated with artists such as Bernard Fanning, Jewel and Amy Lee of Evanescence.

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 25 December 1971) is an Irish musician, songwriter and record producer best known as the guitarist, one of the primary songwriters and co-founder of the rock band The Cranberries. Hogan is also the founder of Mono Band, in which he plays all of the instruments and records all of the parts. In 2009, he founded the Filpa (Film Post Audio) company in Limerick to provide audio post-production for film and video. He released his first solo album, The Sky Road, on 3 March 2011, with a second album, All Absolution, released in 2018.

Hogan started his music career while still in school, when he had joined local punk band The Remainz which released the single, "Apartheid" in 1988. He formed The Cranberries in 1989 whose first album, Everybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can't We, released in 1993, achieved success. The band released four critically acclaimed albums and multiple top-ten singles, before going on hiatus in 2003. The band reunited in 2009, with Hogan as the mainstay, releasing the album Roses followed by Something Else in

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 23 December 1971) is an Irish musician, songwriter, and record producer. He plays guitar, bass and keyboards and is most widely known as the lead guitarist and co-songwriter for the alternative rock band The Cranberries. He is currently a member of the blues rock band, Mono Band, and has collaborated with multi-instrumentalist Tim Wheeler from the band Ash on an album of instrumental music. 

Hogan formed The Cranberries in 1989 with bassist Mike Hogan and drummer Fergal Lawler. The band released their debut album Everybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can't We? to worldwide success in 1993. It spawned the hit singles "Linger" and "Dreams". The follow-up record, No Need to Argue, was released in September 1994 and included the hit single "Zombie". For the third album To The Faithful Departed, Noel co-wrote the single "Salvation". Noel also co-produced the band's fourth album Bury the Hatchet. Hogan left The Cranberries in 2003.

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 25 December 1971) is an Irish musician and songwriter best known as the lead guitarist and co-songwriter of The Cranberries. Hogan is the older brother of fellow Cranberries member, drummer Fergal Lawler. He co-wrote most of their hits with lead singer Dolores O'Riordan, including "Linger", "Zombie" and "Dreams". He was a founding member of the group when they formed in Limerick, Ireland in 1989.

Hogan is also a member of the side project, Mono Band, and has collaborated with French DJ, Etienne de Crécy on a song called "Hope". He was also part of the supergroup, For the Record, formed in 2008 to perform live versions of The Cranberries studio albums. Hogan was born in Limerick, Ireland, and attended Newtown School in Waterford. He began playing guitar at the age of 14.

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 25 December 1971 in Limerick, Ireland) is an Irish musician, best known as the guitarist/songwriter of the alternative rock band The Cranberries. He shared writing credit with lead singer Dolores O'Riordan for the majority of their songs. He also has a solo project, Mono Band, and he released the album Chronicles of the Immortals – Netherworld in 2006. He has also been the producer of The Cranberries' albums Since 2003's Wake Up and Smell the Coffee and 2011's Roses. He co-produced 2017's Something Else with Stephen Street.

Noel Anthony Hogan (born 6 December 1971) is an Irish musician and singer-songwriter best known as the guitarist and co-songwriter of the alternative rock band The Cranberries. Noel formed the Cranberries with lead vocalist Dolores O'Riordan in 1989. He met O'Riordan when she was recording with the band The Popes and she needed a guitarist to play her songs. Hogan is known for his lyrical guitar playing, often using the open chords E, A, and D Minor in the songs. He is responsible for writing most of the Cranberries' music, with the only co-writer being fellow band member Mike Hogan. Following the Cranberries' hiatus in 2003, Noel worked with various artists and formed the alternative rock band Mono Band. In recent years, he has also collaborated with Sinead O'Connor and Liam Ó Maonlaí.
12: "Dawn Landes is an American singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, and producer. Born in Louisville, Kentucky, Landes began her career as a touring fiddle and banjo player in the folk rock band Hem prior to her solo career. Active since 2003, she has recorded four full length solo albums, and has collaborated with artists such as Iron & Wine, Ray LaMontagne, Juana Molina, and Sufjan Stevens. She has also contributed to soundtracks for films like Away We Go and The Secret Life of Walter Mitty. Most recently in 2018, Landes released a studio album Meet Me at the River, and the track "Next to Me" was featured in an episode of the Nickelodeon show, Every Witch Way. Landes has been noted for her diverse musical influences, which include country and western, rock, indie, and Americana influences."

Dawn Landes (born April 14, 1980) is an American singer, songwriter, musician and producer. She has released five solo full-length albums, a live album and several EPs. She has also released two albums with the group Bonkeys, co-written and produced four music collections for the movies Still Alice, War Party and Outlaws And Angels, and worked on various other musical projects.

Landes grew up in Louisville, Kentucky, where she started playing piano at the age of 5 and eventually performed in local bands before heading to New York in 2003 with her band, Bonkeys. After Bonkeys disbanded, Landes continued her solo career, releasing her debut album, Firesight, in 2007, followed by Sweet Heart Rodeo (2009), Dawn's music has been compared to those of alt-pop artists such as Neko Case, Cat Power, Jolie Holland and Joanna Newsom. Landes has collaborated with a wide range of artists, including Jeff Tweedy, Band of Horses, Sufjan Stevens and Midlake.

Dawn Landes (born Elizabeth Dawn Thompson on December 7, 1982) is an American singer, songwriter, multi-instrumentalist and producer. Born in Louisville, Kentucky, she has had a prolific career, often collaborating with mainly Irish artists including Maverick Sabre, James Vincent McMorrow, Snow Patrol and The Script.

Landes released her debut studio album, Dawn's Music, in 2006 and up until 2016 had released 4 studio albums, 12 EP's and a single. Her music sits mainly within the Americana and Folk genres, often delving into other genres such as Pop, Country and Jazz. She has won critical acclaim for her work, with her 2016 album Meet Me at the River having earned her a Grammy award nomination.

In 2016 Landes and her husband, composer and violinist Yair Evnine, formed a production team and opened up a small recording studio in Brooklyn. They record, mix, arrange and produce music for a variety of different artists while also still producing and performing their own music.

Dawn Landes (born March 14, 1979) is an American singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, and producer. She is primarily known for her albums Dawn’s Music (2004), Fireproof (2007), Sweet Heart Rodeo (2009), Meet Me at the River (2012), and Mal Habillé (2018). Her songs have been used in national advertising campaigns, including the television show Grey’s Anatomy, and for films such as Whip It (2009). She collaborated with Jessica Lea Mayfield, William Tyler, and Joshua Tillman (touring as J. Tillman). She played a role in the musical drama movie Park Bench (2012) and has produced albums for Rachel Tucker, Willie Watson and Langhorne Slim.

Landes has toured extensively with acts such as The Low Anthem and it’s Complicated (a duo with Bonnie “Prince” Billy). She grew up in Louisville, Kentucky and resides in Brooklyn, New York.

Dawn Landes (born February 22, 1983) is an American folk and country singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist and record producer from Louisville, Kentucky. Her music has been featured in films and television, most notably in the Oscar-nominated soundtrack for Still Alice starring Julianne Moore, and she has also collaborated with a variety of musicians including Sufjan Stevens, Iron & Wine, Death Cab For Cutie, Norah Jones, Andrew Bird, and KT Tunstall. Landes has released seven albums, ranging from pop to country to folk. She has toured and performed with artists such as Rufus Wainwright, k.d. Lang, Beach House, Panda Bear, and Conor Oberst, and has been featured in Rolling Stone, The New York Times, NPR, and Paste magazine.

Dawn Landes (born 27 August 1978) is an American singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist born in Louisville, Kentucky, United States. Landes is signed to Cooking Vinyl in the UK and Shoeshine Records in the US. Landes is a songwriter and multi-instrumentalist and has toured and recorded with artists including My Morning Jacket, The Head and the Heart, Buddy Miller and Norah Jones. She has also toured and recorded extensively with her own projects. Her sound draws from folk and country music as well as from more experimental sources. Landes has released seven full-length albums: Fireproof (2005, independent), Dawn’s Music (2007, independent), Sweetheart Rodeo (2008, Cooking Vinyl), Dawn’s Hickory Project (2009, independent), Young Overtones (2011, Shoeshine Records), Mockingbird (2013, Cooking Vinyl) and Meet Me at the River (2018, Stones Throw Records).

"Dawn Landes (born February 15, 1980) is an American singer-songwriter and musician from Louisville, Kentucky. Landes has released several albums, EPs, and singles, and has toured extensively both in the United States and Europe. She is known for her folk sound, sometimes featuring other instruments such as banjos, accordions, and brass. Landes has collaborated with many notable musicians, including Ryan Adams, Emmylou Harris, Josh Ritter, and Sufjan Stevens."

Dawn Landes (born December 17, 1979) is an American singer-songwriter, recording engineer, and producer, based in Brooklyn, NY. She was born in New York City to a musical family, her father being a bluegrass mandolin player and her mother a classically trained pianist. Her career started in 1999 when she was asked to join a cover band, Brewdog, in Louisville, Kentucky. Since then, Landes has released five solo albums, four of which have been featured on NPR Music's All Songs Considered, as well as a series of EPs and 7" vinyl singles. Landes's music is a blend of Americana and folk, featuring elements of country, blues, indie-rock, and even bits of jazz and classical. She is also known for her strong, haunting close harmonies, and for her passionate and honest lyrics.

Dawn Landes (born 1978) is an American singer, songwriter, multi-instrumentalist and record producer, originally from Louisville, Kentucky. Raised in a musical family, Landes started writing songs as a child and began touring professionally at age 18. Landes has released 5 full-length albums, under labels Yep Roc Records, Fur Swan Recordings and Fire Records. She has performed or collaborated with artists such as My Morning Jacket, Norah Jones, Sufjan Stevens, Glen Hansard, Josh Ritter and Andrew Bird. She lives and works out of her studio in Brooklyn, New York, alongside her husband and frequent collaborator, Sean Gill. Landes also runs her own label, Proud Records.

Dawn Landes (born 1979) is an American singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, producer and engineer from Louisville, Kentucky. She has released four full-length albums as a solo artist, as well as albums with collaboration partners including Billy Bragg, Belle and Sebastian, The Innocence Mission, and Bonnie "Prince" Billy. She has arranged and produced albums for Father John Misty, Sufjan Stevens, and Regina Spektor, among others. She has also composed music for theater, film, and television.

Dawn Landes (born November 10, 1981) is an American singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist and producer based in Brooklyn. She has released five solo albums and three EPs, as well as two albums in collaboration with her husband, John Paul Keith, under the moniker Dawn & John Paul. Her songs have been featured in films and television, and she has worked with a wide range of other artists, including Bon Iver, Norah Jones, Glen Hansard, Rachael Yamagata, and The New Pornographers. Her most recent solo album, Meet Me At The River, was released in 2019. Landes has toured throughout the US, Canada, Europe and Asia, and has made appearances at festivals such as Glastonbury, Bonnaroo, Austin City Limits and SXSW.

Dawn Landes (born 1982) is an American singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, and record producer based in Brooklyn, New York. She grew up in Louisville, Kentucky, and her music blends indie folk, alt-country and pop. Landes has released five solo albums, the most recent of which, Meet Me at the River, was released in 2018. She is also an active collaborator and producer, having worked with Ray LaMontagne, Bryan Ferry, Sufjan Stevens and Norah Jones, among others. Her production and mixing credits include works by Scottish indie-pop band Belle and Sebastian, Spanish singer-songwriter Estrella Morente, folk-pop act Great Lake Swimmers, and The Luyas, among others. She has also composed a variety of large-scale works for organizations including American Ballet Theater and Miracle Theater, and for the New York City Ballet.

Dawn Landes (born 1981) is an American singer-songwriter and musician from Louisville, Kentucky. Landes is a versatile artist who writes and performs music in a variety of genres, including folk, country, pop, rock, and electronic music. She has collaborated with several notable artists, including Sufjan Stevens, Mumford & Sons, Ben Kweller, and Alex Ebert. She released her debut solo album Dawn's Music in 2005, followed by her second album Sweetheart Rodeo in 2008 and her third album Dawn Landes & the Haints of Dean Hall in 2011. Since 2013, she has released five albums as part of The Saltbreakers, a collaboration between Landes and her husband, singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist Joshua Caterer. Her most recent solo album, Meet Me at the River, was released in 2018.

Dawn Landes (born 1979, Lexington, Kentucky) is an American singer-songwriter, producer, multi-instrumentalist, and film composer based in Brooklyn, New York. Landes has released eight full-length albums. Her music is a mix of country, pop, blues and folk. Her discography includes City of Refuge (2010) and Sweetheart Rodeo (2009). Landes has also produced two albums with Bonnie "Prince" Billy, and collaborated on records by My Morning Jacket, Sondre Lerche, and The Apollos. 

In 2017, Landes was featured on the Red Hot Organization's compilation album Red Hot + Country, a project intended to combat HIV/AIDS and showcase country music. Landes also co-wrote Alynda Segarra’s 2017 album, The Navigator.

As a film composer, Landes wrote music for the 2019 film A Faithful Man, directed by Louis Garrel. She has also composed music for many shorts and the 2004 feature film, La Petite Anglaise. Landes was a founding member of the Brooklyn-based band Dawn of

Dawn Landes is an American singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist who has released five solo albums and collaborated with numerous artists, including Sufjan Stevens, Glen Hansard, and Yukon Blonde. Originally from Louisville, Kentucky, Landes moved to Brooklyn, New York in 2003 to pursue a career in music. She has toured around the world, played the Grand Ole Opry, and made numerous television appearances, including The Late Show with David Letterman and Later... with Jools Holland. Landes is also known for her work as a producer, composer, and mixer. In 2018 she released her first album in four years, Meet Me at the River.

Dawn Landes is an American singer-songwriter, recording artist, composer, and producer. She has released 10 solo albums, collaborated with artists such as Sufjan Stevens, Emmylou Harris, Josh Ritter, Iron & Wine, John Kay, Billy Bragg, and Joey Burns of Calexico. As a composer for film and television, Landes has written for many shows, including Parks and Recreation, Family Tree, and Drunk History. She also co-wrote the theme song for The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel and composed the music for the 2016 film Elvis & Nixon. In addition to music, Landes runs a bakery in Brooklyn, Landes Artisanal Goods.

Dawn Landes (born Dawn Teresa Landes October 11, 1983 in Louisville, Kentucky) is an American singer-songwriter, record producer, and multi-instrumentalist. Throughout her career, she has explored a wide range of genres such as folk, pop, rock, and country. She has released five solo albums, two in collaboration with Feist producer Mocky, and was a member of music-comedy duo Talulah Gosh. Her most recent release, Meet Me at the River (2018), is a collaborative album with Sweetback Sisters.

Landes has toured extensively, performing in North America Europe, and Japan. She has collaborated with numerous artists, including John Paul White and Justin Vernon of Bon Iver. She has written music for film and television, and appeared as a performer in movies, including the Judd Apatow film This is 40. She was also featured in the film About Alex. In 2016 she was an Associate Artist in Residence with the Robert Rauschenberg Foundation.

"Dawn Landes is an American singer, songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, composer, and producer based in Nashville, Tennessee. She released her first album, Shotgun, in 2004, and has since released four more, including Sweetheart Rodeo (2007), Dawn's Music (2008), Fireproof (2010), and Meet Me at the River (2018). Landes has also written and produced music for films, commercials, and television shows, including winning a BMI Music Award, a UK Music Award and a USA Songwriting Award. She also composes and arranges music for austistic and special needs children."

Dawn Landes (born Dawn Sewell) is an American musician, songwriter, producer, and audio engineer from Louisville, Kentucky. She has released eight solo albums as well as collaborations with other music producers. As a solo artist, she is known for blending musical styles such as pop, country, folk, rock, and jazz. She has also written, produced, and collaborated with a range of artists, including Lou Reed, Emmylou Harris, Sarah Jarosz, Josh Rouse, and Yo La Tengo. In addition to her own music, she works as a producer and audio engineer at her recording studio in Brooklyn, New York. She is also a UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador.

Dawn Landes is an American singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist born in Louisville, Kentucky and raised in Nashville, Tennessee and Brooklyn, New York. Her music has been described as folk, folk-pop, and Americana, and has touches of rock, blues and occasional country. She is signed to the French independent label, Bonsound, and is currently based in Brooklyn, New York. In 2008, Landes released her first full-length solo album, Fireproof. Since then, she released three more full-length albums, Sweet Heart Rodeo in 2009, Dawn's Music in 2012, and Meet Me at the River in 2018. In addition, Landes has composed and performed original music for television, film, and theatrical productions and has collaborated with artists ranging from film composers to musicians including Sufjan Stevens, Hem, Jeff Tweedy, Jenny Lewis and Peter Bradley Adams.
13:
William Earl "Bill" Quinn Jr. (born December 4, 1927) is an American actor, most notable for his television roles as Ralph Hart on The Mary Tyler Moore Show, Arthur Hendricks on The Fugitive, and unassuming bartender Jock Ewing on Dallas. He also voiced Offridge in The Snorks from 1984 to 1989.

Quinn made his acting debut on the 1954–55 NBC legal drama Justice, where he played the clerk of court on alternate weeks. He also made appearances on NBC's The Virginian, ABC's The Untouchables, and The Eleventh Hour, and CBS's Perry Mason, along with other series. Quinn's notable film credits include roles in The Longest Day (1962), To Kill a Mockingbird (1962), Crimson Tide (1995), and House on Haunted Hill (1999). In 1976, he played Santa Claus in the Rankin/Bass holiday special The Stingiest Man in Town.

Bill Quinn (September 28, 1912 – April 22, 1994) was an American actor, professional raconteur and television director. Quinn was best known for his depiction of Arthur Chenault, the kindly blind bank customer of Ralph Tompkins (played by F. Emmett Walsh) on the 1945 sitcom The Memories of Stella Foster, and his recurring role of Arthur Miller, father of Reva Shayne Miller on the soap opera Guiding Light, for which he was nominated for a Daytime Emmy Award in 1994, posthumously. 

Born William Vincent Quinn in New York City, Quinn began acting in 1929 in vaudeville, touring with a dramatization of Mark Twain's novel Tom Sawyer. By 1936, he had an editorial position at King Features Syndicate, on which his future wife, Alice, worked as an advertising copywriter. During World War II, Quinn enlisted in the United States Navy and worked in Navy intelligence, an experience that later served him well during his recreation of private lives, family feuds and despotic regimes in the stories he told and acted out on stage. 

Quinn had more than 80 credits

William Edward ("Bill") Quinn (July 15, 1912 – July 29, 1994) was an American television, stage, and film actor. He was well-known for his roles in many television series from the 1950s through the 1990s, most notably as Ralph Houk on The Untouchables, Frank Malloy on The Little House on the Prairie, and Colonel Potter on M*A*S*H.

Born in San Francisco, California, Quinn worked as a disk jockey in Northern California before moving to Los Angeles in 1942 to become an actor. He began his career with many small roles in films and eventually became a regular in westerns. He also played roles in various television shows, eventually settling into situations comedy, including such series as Leave it to Beaver, Bonanza, The Beverly Hillbillies, and Hogan's Heroes.

Quinn's most recognizable role came in 1959 when he was cast as Frank Malloy, the husband and father of the Ingalls family in the drama The Little House on the Prairie. His last leading role was as Colonel Sherman Potter in M*A*S*H, which he continued until the

Bill Quinn (May 5, 1912 – February 9, 1994) was an American actor, best known for his role as Arthur "Rabbit" Johnson on the 1970s CBS sitcom The Life and Times of Grizzly Adams.

Quinn was best known for playing the comical mountain man Arthur "Rabbit" Johnson on the NBC television series The Life and Times of Grizzly Adams from 1977-1978, a role he reprised for the 1982 feature film followup, The Legend of Grizzly Adams. He had a minor role as Archie, a bartender, in two episodes of the ABC show Happy Days, and a regular role as bartender Don Foley on the CBS show Young Dan'l Boone, starring his son, Ted Cassidy, and Fess Parker. He was a regular cast member in the short-lived CBS show Archer, starring Bud Cort. He also appeared in several western themed television shows and in feature films, including Support Your Local Sheriff (1969), The Apple Dumpling Gang (1975), and War of the Wildcats (1943).

William Robert Jarratt Quinn (May 17, 1927 – March 4, 1994) was an American television director and actor, best known for his role as Ralph Malph on the long-running US sitcom Happy Days.

Quinn had an extensive career as a television director, directing episodes of Get Smart!, The Brady Bunch, McCloud, Hogan's Heroes, The Partridge Family, The Odd Couple, Sanford and Son, All in the Family and many other series. Quinn won a Primetime Emmy for his direction of the 1981 TV-movie Pleasure Cove.

In addition to his directing career, Quinn had a few minor acting roles in the 1960s. He was well known for his role as Ralph Malph, best friend of the primary character, Richie Cunningham (Ron Howard), on the sitcom Happy Days. Quinn also guest starred on other TV series such as Bewitched, The Monkees and The Odd Couple.

He retired from directing in the late 1980s and moved to Laguna Beach, California, where he died on March 4, 1994, aged 66, of an aneurysm.

Bill Quinn (May 5, 1912 – April 22, 1994) was an American actor and voice artist. His career spanned five decades.

Quinn began his career in 1931, appearing in small, uncredited roles until he was cast as the announcer in The Life of Riley in 1949. The following year, he played the title role in the short-lived Mr. District Attorney. After appearing as an announcer in several television series in the 1950s, including Dragnet, Quinn was cast as the father of Barbara Stanwyck in the drama The Private Lives of Adam and Eve (1960).

In the 1960s, Quinn became known for his role as Ralph, the blind bank owner often called upon to give sage advice on The Rifleman (1958–1963). He guest-starred in numerous situations comedies and dramas, including The Andy Griffith Show, The Odd Couple, and The Lucy Show. Quinn also provided the voice for the character Grandpa on Hanna-Barbera's animated series The Tom and Jerry Show (1975–1977). He was a regular on the comedy The New Phil Silvers Show in 1971 and remained active

William Edward Quinn (July 4, 1927 – June 2, 2018) was an American actor best known for his role as Ralph Houk on the CBS television series The state, which aired from 1972 to 1983. Quinn began his career in the 1950s as a character actor, appearing in such films as From Here to Eternity, The Great Gatsby, Super Fly, and Steelyard Blues. He also had guest roles on such television programs as Route 66, The Twilight Zone, Perry Mason and Have Gun Will Travel. In the 1960s, he starred in the syndicated western series The Guns of Will Sonnett, with his son Dack Rambo, who later also joined him on The Star. Quinn also appeared in several episodes of The Andy Griffith Show and The Golden Girls.

William "Bill" Quinn (June 4, 1912 – April 22, 1994) was an American actor of stage and screen, who played the role of Arthur Hackett, the father of Shirley Partridge (played by Shirley Jones) in the sitcom The Partridge Family. Quinn also guest-starred in numerous episodes of the CBS television series All in the Family, playing opposite Carroll O'Connor, whose daughter, Nell, happened to be Quinn's real-life step-granddaughter.

Quinn grew up in a show business family and was the stepson of the actress Dorothy Hann (née Dot Quinn). Quinn made his Broadway debut in No Time for Comedy, a 1940 adaptation of S.N. Behrman's play, and went on to appear in over a dozen stage productions, such as The Show-Off, The Voice of the Turtle, Mr. Roberts, and Three Men on a Horse.

Quinn made his screen debut in 1943, appearing in the western The Law Comes to Gunsight. His career would span more than five decades, including prominent roles in Spencer's Mountain (1963), McHale's Navy (1964

William Thomas Quinn (September 14, 1927 – February 1, 2013) was an American actor and voice actor who appeared in numerous television programs, including The Rifleman, Bonanza, Star Trek, The Golden Girls, The Love Boat, 227, The Mary Tyler Moore Show, Maude, The Jeffersons, most famously as Arthur, Arthur's hard-of-hearing father on Charles in Charge, The Cosby Show, and ALF. He also had a recurring role as Irish mob boss Farrell in the CBS crime drama The Equalizer for the last two seasons. He was also a longtime voice actor for commercials and cartoons, most notably as John Darling in Disney's Peter Pan and its sequel, and Rocket J. Squirrel on The Rocky and Bullwinkle Show. He also worked in the sound department of numerous motion pictures and TV shows, including Hogan's Heroes, The Waltons, Kojak, and The Partridge Family. Quinn died at age 85 in Los Angeles, California, on February 1, 2013.

William Edward "Bill" Quinn (August 20, 1912 – April 5, 1994) was an American actor, director and production manager. He is perhaps best known to television viewers as Ellsworth in CBS's Rawhide and later as Archie Bunker's avuncular neighbor, Dr. Craig, in All in the Family. He had roles in several movies, such as North by Northwest and Rio Bravo.

Quinn's television career began in 1957 and also included appearances on Wagon Train, Gunsmoke, Lassie, The Rifleman, Bonanza, Have Gun – Will Travel, Highway Patrol, The Real McCoys, Hazel, The Munsters, Get Smart and Maude. Quinn was the uncredited director of the "Shot in the Dark" episode of the 1964 TV series, Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea, as well as episodes of The Munsters; most of the Leave It to Beaver series; The Andy Griffith Show; and I Dream of Jeannie. He was a production manager for various television shows between 1958 and 1961. Quinn won a Primetime Emmy Award in 1988 for his work on the television series thirtysomething.

"William Russell "Bill" Quinn (April 6, 1912 – June 4, 1994) was an American actor. He is best remembered for his role as Ralph, the father of Archie Bunker's stepson, in the CBS television series All in the Family, which earned him one Primetime Emmy Award and two Golden Globe Award nominations.

Quinn first appeared on Broadway in the 1940s in productions such as Arsenic and Old Lace. He went on to star in films like The Jackie Robinson Story, Superman and the Mole Men, The Deadly Mantis, Yankee Pasha and The Seven Little Foys for which he received a Golden Globe nomination. He also made guest appearances on a variety of television series, including Rawhide, Wagon Train, and The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet.

In 1971, he landed the role of Ralph in All in the Family and returned to the show in 1979 in its spin-off, Archie Bunker's Place. Quinn was awarded the Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series Primetime Emmy in 1979. He was also nominated for That's Life and The Pat Crowley Show. Quinn died in 1994 in

"William "Bill" Quinn (June 1, 1912 – July 29, 1994) was an American actor. He was best known for his role as Arnold Corsair on the television series The Rifleman, an all-American western drama, during its five–year run from 1958 to 1963. Quinn also appeared in many other popular series, including M*A*S*H, The Odd Couple, The Bob Newhart Show, and Columbo. He frequently appeared with James Stewart, who, although not playing a co-starring role, made a series of guest appearances on The Rifleman. Quinn also worked in the Hollywood film industry, with over 70 film credits between 1935 and 1994. He worked in lower budget productions and westerns, including A Star Is Born (1954), High Plains Drifter (1973), and The Shootist (1976)."

"Bill Quinn (May 5, 1912 – April 22, 1994) was an American actor who appeared in dozens of films and television series from the 1930s to the 1990s.

Quinn was born William Vanderveer Quinn in New York City, in 1912. He entered films in 1935, and by the 1940s had become a familiar face in Hollywood films. He appeared in such films as The Glenn Miller Story (1954), It's a Mad Mad Mad Mad World (1963) and the popular science fiction films The Time Machine (1960) and The Shaggy Dog (1959). Quinn also appeared on numerous television series during the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s, most notably Bonanza, Gunsmoke and The Andy Griffith Show, in which he played the part of Barney Fife's uncle, "Uncle Ollie". He appeared in over 270 films and TV shows.

Quinn died in 1994 of natural causes in Woodland Hills, California. He was 81 years old."

Bill Quinn (April 25, 1912 – February 9, 1994) was an American actor who appeared in numerous television series, usually as characters much older than his actual age. Quinn's career spanned over 60 years, beginning on stage and in radio, eventually transitioning to television, where he became a familiar face and was a regular on a number of shows.

Quinn is best known for his role as Arthur "Archie" Bunker's cranky, but caring neighbor and drinking buddy, Ralph Kramden, on the 1970s sitcom All in the Family and Archie Bunker's Place; a role he reprised in a frequent series of guest appearances on The Jeffersons and its spin-off, Checking In. He also had extensive roles in The Mary Tyler Moore Show as Mary Richard's father Ed Baxter, in The Golden Girls as Sophia Petrillo's gangster boyfriend, The Rockford Files as Jim Rockford's father, and in the Scary Movie franchise as the dim-witted police chief.

William "Bill" Quinn (May 12, 1912 – April 22, 1994) was an American character actor. He was best known for his roles as Ralph Hastings in The Rifleman, gentlemanly Indian agent Jonathan Grave on The Rebel,and John Jefferson in Quincy, M.E..

Quinn's professional acting career spanned more than five decades. His earliest roles were uncredited turns in films such as the popular World War II film, Tora! Tora! Tora!. He eventually acquired small roles in television shows such as The Andy Griffith Show and Bonanza.

Quinn's most recognizable role was that of Ralph Hastings, Lucas McCain's (played by Chuck Connors) neighbor and serene friend, in the Western series The Rifleman (1958–63). He also had a recurring role a few years later as scientist Emil Skoda in the superhero series The Greatest American Hero (1981–83). Quinn took part in a long list of other television series, including Bonanza, Wanted: Dead or Alive, Tarzan, Perry Mason, Rawhide, Bonanza, Hulk, The Rockford Files, Emergency!, The Six Million

"William Russell "Bill" Quinn (October 10, 1912 – April 21, 1994) was an American actor. He is best remembered as Ralph Harper on The Andy Griffith Show and as Sam Wiseman on The Rifleman. He appeared in numerous films and television series, including The Jack Benny Program, The Untouchables, Leave It to Beaver, Maverick, Bonanza, Perry Mason, Gunsmoke, Ben Casey, Batman, and Ironside.

Quinn was born in St. Paul, Minnesota and moved with his family to a large farm near Montevideo, Minnesota at the age of four. He initially pursued a career in law, but ended up studying at the Pasadena Community Playhouse, where he met and shared a home with actor Charles Donald. Quinn debuted on the radio in 1933, doing work for the National Broadcasting Company (NBC). His film debut was Party Wire (1945) with Jean Parker.

In 1953, Quinn won a major role as Officer Reilly in the ABC crime drama, The Falcon. From 1959 to 1965, he appeared as bookkeeper and confidant Ralph Monroe on The Andy Griffith Show. It was during this

William (Bill) Quinn (November 26, 1913 – May 17, 1994) was an American television and movie actor. He appeared in nearly fifty television shows, including Alfred Hitchcock Presents, Batman, Maverick, The Real McCoys, Bewitched, The Andy Griffith Show, and The F.B.I. On television Westerns he was cast mostly in supporting roles, such as as Doc Watson in Gunsmoke, Emmett Ryker in The Virginian, Hal Norton in Bonanza, and Tom Tompkins in The High Chaparral. In the 1950s and 1960s, he had regular roles as Rocky Rhodes in Sky King, Paul Newton in Letter to Loretta, and Mister Conklin in The Monkees. In 1958, he was cast as Theodore Haines in the episode "Man in the Moon" of the syndicated series, Death Valley Days.

William Charles "Billy" Quinn (27 May 1897– 13 August 1974) was an English-American film editor and director. Born in London, England, Quinn moved to Los Angeles as a child. He began his career as an editor in 1919, at age 22, and eventually serviced more than 200 films. He directed five films between 1932 and 1940, one of the best-known being Tall, Dark and Handsome (1941). He worked with the likes of Warner Baxter, Bette Davis and Richard Widmark. After retiring from the film industry, Quinn became a businessman, appearing in a 1957 episode of the game show The Price Is Right as a contestant. He died in California on August 13, 1974.

Bill Quinn (October 1, 1912 – March 3, 1994) was an American actor whose career spanned over four decades. Popularly known for his role as Arthur "Archie" Punkerhouse Bunker's kindly neighbor and father figure on All in the Family, Quinn also appeared in numerous television shows, including the 1970s version of The Odd Couple, Hawaii Five-O, Wonder Woman, The Rockford Files, The Mary Tyler Moore Show, Kung Fu, Gunsmoke, Bonanza, The Jeffersons, Adam-12, M*A*S*H, The Streets of San Francisco, Quincy, M.E., Magnum, P.I., Hercules: The Legendary Journeys, Married... with Children and Night Court. He was also the voice of the unctuous businessman, Dannar, in the 1979 Rankin-Bass animated TV movie The Tiny Tree.

"William H. “Bill” Quinn (September 14, 1912 – April 22, 1994) was an American actor. He was best known as the cantankerous ranch hand Brad Wesley in the television western series Laramie (1959–1963). He also starred in films such as Man of the West (1958), The Outlaw Joséy Wales (1976), and The Shootist (1976). Quinn was in demand as a character actor in films,especially westerns and mysteries, from the mid-1950s to late 1960s. His television roles extended from the 1950s into the late 1980s."
14: Carol Huston (born April 7, 1966) is an American actress and singer. Huston began her career on stage, performing in a variety of stage productions in the mid-1980s. She subsequently moved to Los Angeles and appeared in a number of television series, including Law & Order, The West Wing, House, MD and the Lifetime series Any Day Now. She also has had several roles in feature films, most notably appearing as the title character in the 2002 film Possessions. She received an Independent Spirit Award nomination for her performance in the 1998 film Pleasantville.

Carol Huston (July 3, 1931 – May 1, 2020) was an American stage, film, and television actress. She was best known for her role as the title character in the ABC television sitcom Maude, which ran continuously from 1972 to 1978.

Huston began her career as a redhead, taking roles as a showgirl or chorus girl in nightclubs. She made her Broadway debut in 1953, in the revue New Faces of 1952. Her stage career included roles in productions of Mornings at Seven, Forty Carats and Butterflies Are Free. She received two Tony Award nominations, for the 1962 musical A Family Affair and the 1966 play The Man in the Glass Booth.

Carol Huston (born September 14, 1956) is a Canadian actress, voice actress, author, singer and songwriter. A three-time Emmy Award-winning performer, she is best known for her role as Golde in the Broadway production of Fiddler on the Roof and as Secret Squirrel in the Saturday morning animated series of the same name. Huston's other television work includes the title role of the miniseries The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone (2003), and guest roles on CSI: Miami and Law & Order: SVU. Her feature film credits includes Atonement (2007). She has also released two albums, Voices of August (2007) and The Carol Huston Collection (2009), as well as two books, both of which she wrote and illustrated.

Carroll Huston (July 23, 1899 – April 17, 1968) was an American dancer and actress who performed foil stage and in early black-and-white films. Huston's most notable role amongst her peers was as a "Goldwyn Girl" MGM. She also performed in numerous Broadway shows, vaudeville acts with her husband, and in the Ziegfeld Follies.

Born in Sandusky, Ohio, Huston and her family relocated to New York City. Huston's dancing career began in 1926 during a costume ball, after which producer Florenz Ziegfeld cast her for his Follies. In 1927, she made her Broadway debut in Rio Rita.

Huston married fellow dancer John Errol in 1930, and together they toured as a dance act. Huston's motion picture career began in 1933 with the RKO film Flying Down to Rio. She then took on the moniker “America's Number One Travel Tom-Boy” when she joined the Turnabout Theatre to entertain US servicemen during World War II.

Her last role was as assistant-choreographer on the

Carol Huston (born 1945) is an award-winning Canadian actor and singer. She is best known for her starring role in the 1990 romantic comedy Pretty Woman, as well as for her roles in the NBC dramatic series Law & Order, and the HBO comedy drama, The Larry Sanders Show. Huston has appeared in over 60 films and television shows throughout her career, receiving numerous awards, including an Emmy Award in 1995, and two Golden Globe Awards in 1990 and 1992. In 2002, she received an honorary degree from York University and in 2016, she was inducted into Canada's Walk of Fame.

Carol Lynley (born February 13, 1942) is an American actress and former child star. She began her career as a child model, and by the age of 15 had appeared in episodes of the television series Playhouse 90. She earned a Golden Globe Award nomination as Best Supporting Actress for her role as Bunny/Angel in The Cardinal (1963). Her performance in the disaster film The Poseidon Adventure (1972) earned her a nomination for the Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Motion Picture – Drama. She is also remembered for her roles in The Graduate (1967), Blue Denim (1959), Return to Oz (1985), Harlow (1965), and Bobby Deerfield (1977).

Carole Huston (December 18, 1937 – January 2, 2015) was an American professional actress, singer, and dancer. She is best known for her roles in films such as Cabaret (1972), The Towering Inferno (1974) and The Amityville Horror (1979), as well as her work on Broadway and in cabarets. She was also one of the original cast members of the television series Spider-Man: The Animated Series. Huston was nominated for five Tony Awards, winning twice. She was awarded the Drama Desk Award and Outer Critics Circle Award for her performance in the musical adaptation of Breakfast at Tiffany's.

Carole Huston (1901–2003) was a British writer who, after the publication of her first novel, became known as the "novelist laureate of the West Country". Born in Hampshire and brought up in the south of England, Huston moved to Cornwall in 1927 and married a local businessman. Here she wrote her first book, 'If You Never Come Back', published in 1938. 

Huston went on to write many novels, mostly set in Cornwall, that focused on rural life and were loved for their glimpse into the country life of the early 20th century. Several of her books were adapted into successful films, including The Interrupted Journey (1946), which starred Carol Marsh, and Untamed New World (1955). Other popular titles include the 'Cornish Trilogy': Return to Sennen Cove, The Towers of Prestieldine, and Out of the Blue.

Huston was an active campaigner, and wrote several books on the environment and animal welfare. In later life she was recognized for her contribution to literature in Cornwall, receiving the Cornish Literature Society's Cornwall Award in 1995. She died

Carol Huston (born October 6, 1939) is an American actress and singer. She is known for her television roles, particularly her Emmy Award-winning role as Roseanne Conner on the ABC sitcom Roseanne (1988–1997; 2018). She also had lead roles in the popular films Mr. Mom (1983) and Armageddon (1998). Other notable projects include The Office (2008–2013) and Glee (2015–2017). On stage, she has been nominated for Tony Awards for her performances in the musical revue The World Goes 'Round (1993) and the play Morning's at Seven (2003). Huston has also appeared in television films and made for television movies. She has won several awards for her acting, including two Emmy Awards and a Golden Globe Award.

Carol Huston (born December 28, 1947) is an American actress, singer, director and producer. A five-time Golden Globe Award nominee, she first came to prominence in films in the mid-1970s, gaining praise for her performances in The Great Gatsby (1974) and Chinatown (1974). Huston went on to receive Academy Award nominations for Prizzi's Honor (1985), Enemies, A Love Story (1989), The Grifters (1990) and the Academy Award for Best Actress for her role as Aurora Greenway in Terms of Endearment (1983). She also won an Emmy Award for her role as a battered wife in the miniseries Bastard out of Carolina (1996). She is the mother of actor Danny Huston, with her former husband John Huston.

Carol Huston (born October 12, 1947) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and author. She began her career as a singer and songwriter in the 1970s and released an album, Carol Huston, in 1979. Her hits include the single "God Bless the Child" which reached number six on the U.S. Billboard Hot 100 chart. She has also appeared in a number of films, including Mystic Pizza, Buffy the Vampire Slayer, and JFK. She has also written several books, including her autobiography, I'm Still Standing, which was published in 1997.

Carol Huston (born April 7, 1945) is an American actress, singer, producer, director, real estate businesswoman, humanitarian and former model. Huston has appeared in film and television, on Broadway and in the musicals of London’s West End. She made her film debut in Arthur Penn’s The Misfits and went on to star in classic films including, The Postman Always Rings Twice, Prizzi’s Honor and The Witches of Eastwick. She won an Academy Award for her performance in the crime drama film Prizzi’s Honor, in 1985.

Carol Huston (April 7, 1937 – November 13, 2020) was a Canadian film actress and the daughter of actor Walter Huston. She was born in Toronto, Ontario. Her film credits include My Father's House (1975), Shadows and Fog (1991), Fly Away Home (1996) and Mafia! (1998). She also had a long career in television, including a recurring role as Annette Lisbon in the 1990 television drama The Young Riders. Huston was married to CBC news anchor Knowlton Nash from 1967 until his death in 2014.

Carol Huston (born October 5, 1961) is a Canadian filmmaker, visual artist, and actress best known for directing multiple documentaries for the National Film Board of Canada and for her feature film debut The Far Shore (2006). Her documentary work is notable for its strong social commentaries, humour, and visual style.

Huston's documentaries include Making Belanger (1991), Speak Up! It's So Hard to Speak (2000), Dream of a Land (2005), and Hockey Nomad (2009). She is also active in the dramatic film industry in both Canada and the United States. Her feature film debut, The Far Shore (2006) addresses the complexities of living in contemporary Canada. Huston's short film, Blanche & Butch (1994) was an Official Selection of the Cannes Film Festival, and A Little Bit Warm Inside (1995) was honoured with an International Emmy Award.

"Carol Huston (1931 – 2019) was an American choreographer, dancer, actress, and television director. She was born in New Orleans and trained in dance there and in Hollywood. She was renowned for her inventive and innovative choreography and is renowned as one of the pioneers in the field of musical comedy and television. Huston received an honorary Oscar in 2015 in recognition of her life's work.

Huston's career encompassed an array of film, television and stage productions, including Annie Get Your Gun, Seven Brides for Seven Brothers, Guys and Dolls, Gentlemen Prefer Blondes, Li'l Abner, Funny Girl, Mame, Billie, and Irma La Douce. She had numerous associations with Bob Fosse, with whom she collaborated on Damn Yankees, Sweet Charity and Chicago. She also choreographed and starred in Jesus Christ Superstar, the 1973 film and 1975 television special. Between 1953 and 1955, she appeared as a featured dancer on the popular The Dinah Shore Chevy Show."

Carol Huston (born April 20, 1944) is an American actress, author, and activist. She is best known for her roles in several films, including The Rose, Mask, The Big Chill, Prizzi's Honor, The Witches of Eastwick, and Out of Africa. Huston has been nominated for an Academy Award, three Golden Globe Awards and two BAFTA Awards. She won an Emmy Award for her role in the television film Mitzi & the Daisy Chains (1978) and the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for her role in Prizzi's Honor (1985). She is also the author of six biographies, three of which have been on the New York Times best seller list.

As an activist, Huston has supported several causes, including animal rights, conservation, and AIDS research. She has been the spokesperson for the United Nations Environment Programme since 2000 and is a board member of Conservation International, helping to further increase global awareness of environmental issues. Huston has been married three times, most recently to actor and jewelry designer Anthony Andrews since 1998.

Carol Huston (1935–2011) was an American writer and director who began her career in television and stage production while still studying in college. She wrote and directed the feature film Medicine Men (1969), which she also produced and starred in; this was the first feature film directed, written and produced by a Black woman in the United States. Her career continued with numerous television, documentary and feature film credits. Her television career includes writing, producing and directing segments of The Bill Cosby Show, The Mike Douglas Show, The Gong Show, Ed Sullivan Show, The Smothers Brothers Show, Iwa Screen Writers Workshop, Captains and Kings and Ladies Room. She won an Emmy for Outstanding Children's Program for Wait Till Your Father Gets Home (1973). Huston has won awards on both the international and national levels. In 1983, she won the Humanitas Prize for her award-winning television movie, The Women of Brewster Place. That same year, she was nominated for an Oscar for her adapted screenplay from that same movie.

Carol Huston (born October 12, 1955) is an American actress and singer. She rose to fame for her roles in the films Terms of Endearment (1983) and The Ax (2004). Huston was also in many critically acclaimed movies including The Grifters (1990) and Buffalo Girls (1995). She was an Emmy nominee for her performance in The Moor's Mark (1998) and appears in the Netflix original movie Triple Frontier (2019). 

Huston was born in Santa Monica, California and raised in San Francisco. She studied acting at UCLA before moving to New York, where she made her Broadway debut in the musical play Applause in 1971. She is the daughter of filmmaker and actor John Huston. 

A distinct voice, Huston's theatrical performances brought a unique and exciting dynamic to the stage and screen. She received an Oscar nomination for her portrayal of Aurora Greenway in Terms of Endearment and The Grifters. Her portrayal of a madam in Buffalo Girls and a headmistress in The Moor's Mark earned a Primetime Emmy Award nomination for Outstanding Supporting Actress. In 2019, Hust

Carol Huston (born March 26, 1934) is an American actress and singer, who first gained attention for her performance in the 1961 film Two Rode Together. She went on to win an Academy Award for her work in The Unforgiven (1960), and is widely considered one of the greatest actresses of all time. She has starred in many more films since then, including The Misfits (1961), Days of Wine and Roses (1962), The Towering Inferno (1974), and The Stranger (1980). She has also appeared on television shows such as Columbo, Alfred Hitchcock Presents and How to Marry a Millionaire, as well as having an accomplished stage career. She is well known for her versatility and depth of character, in both comedic and dramatic roles.

Carol Huston (born 15 March 1969) is an American actress, singer, and songwriter. She began her career as a stand-up comedian and soon after launched a career in music in the late 1980s. She has achieved critical acclaim for her performances in films including The Wedding Singer (1998) and What Women Want (2000). Her single “Shine” won a Grammy Award for Best Female Pop Vocal Performance in 2001. She has also acted in several television series, including Saturday Night Live, That 70’s Show, The Good Place, and Santa Clarita Diet. She has performed on Broadway and in regional theater, including The Rocky Horror Picture Show and Good Vibrations. Her music has been featured on many soundtracks, and her voice can be heard on many commercials and theme songs. She currently lives in Los Angeles with her husband and two children.
15:
Nigel Milsom (born 1979) is an Australian artist known for his oil paintings. His work is unique and includes portraits, landscapes, seascapes and abstracts, often featuring his distinctive technique and colour palette.

Milsom was born at Doonside and grew up in Sydney. He studied at the University of New South Wales, where he was awarded a Bachelor of Arts with a Bachelor of Fine Arts in painting.
