Milsom's first forays into art were through drawings and cartoons, which he began during his childhood and continued to develop throughout his adolescence. He decided to become an artist following an inspirational teachers' seminar and gained an appreciation of oil painting while studying in Florence and Rome in 2001.

Upon his return to Australia, Milsom held his first solo exhibition at the Defiance Gallery in Sydney during 2006. This success was followed by a solo exhibition at the Art House Gallery in Los Angeles in 2007.

Milsom is widely recognized for his distinctively vivid colours, loose brushstrokes and contemporary compositions. His work has received critical acclaim and been featured in numerous exhibitions worldwide. He currently lives

Nigel Milsom (born 1974) is an Australian painter. He grew up in Sydney's western suburbs and studied law at Sydney University, practicing as a lawyer before deciding to focus on painting. Milsom has been awarded many awards, including the Archibald Prize in 2013, the Doug Moran National Portrait Prize in 2012 and the NSW Parlliamentary Plein Air Painting Prize in 2010. He has been a finalist for the Sulman Prize and the Wynne Prize. Milsom has been featured in exhibitions both nationally and internationally.

Milsom's work combines a range of styles from Realism to Expressionism, with a focus on depicting everyday people with accuracy and beauty. He is particularly interested in exploring questions of identity, isolation and humanity in his work. His paintings often explore themes of social entrapment, alienation, and the complexity of the human psyche.

Nigel Milsom (born 1974) is an Australian artist who works predominantly in painting and drawing. Born in Sydney, his works explore themes of the inner city and suburban experience, the effects of gentrification, the role of art and culture in society and human interactions. Through his artworks, Milsom expresses his confidence in the intrinsic value of contemporary cities and the potential for meaningful experiences through urban living.

Milsom’s works often reflect Sydney’s urban landscape, capturing the changing faces of the city and its inhabitants with a sense of both whimsical tenderness and honest realism. His paintings depict life in the city both candidly and intimately, drawing attention to the city’s decline of hospitality and urban community. His works are characterised by a profound appreciation of architecture and the changes the built environment brings to city life and identity.

Milsom is a laureate of the 2017 Wynne Prize for Landscape painting for his portrait and landscape painting, 'Justice in the Cane Fields' at the Art Gallery of New South Wales. He was the recipient of the 2014 Archibald Prize for his painting of Australian

"Nigel Milsom (born 1971) is an Australian painter. Born in Maitland, New South Wales, he attended The University of Newcastle and graduated with a Bachelor of Fine Arts in 1991. He also studied at The National Art School and the University of New South Wales.

Milsom has exhibited nationally and internationally and his work is held in several museum collections including the Art Gallery of New South Wales, the National Gallery of Australia and the National Gallery of Victoria. In 2012 Milsom won the prestigious Archibald Prize for his oil portrait of the then Chief Justice Tom Bathurst. This was the first time an Archibald Prize had been won by an artist from Newcastle.

Milsom's work has been described by the Art Gallery of New South Wales as, “impressed by the physicality of paint and the expressiveness of direct mark making, these works reflect a masterful control of informal painting practice”. Milsom is now based in the northern beaches of Sydney and runs the Nigel Milsom Workshop School. He is best known for his narrative compositions and layered brushwork that explore the

Nigel Milsom (born 1971) is an Australian painter, known for his powerful and emotive figurative works which challenge traditional notions of beauty and portraiture. His subjects are often drawn from his own personal history, exploring ideas of identity and belonging.

Milsom's method of painting is also distinct, with bright, gestural paint strokes. He builds up the painting in layers of texture and colour, allowing the texture and paint to determine the subject. This approach reveals the incompleteness and abstraction of the portrait, creating an emotional tension between the subject and the viewer.

Milsom's paintings have been widely exhibited in Australia, the United States and Europe. He has held many solo exhibitions, including at the Sammlung Essl (Klosterneuburg, Austria), Fehily Contemporary (Brunswick, Australia), and Häusler Contemporary (Munich, Germany). He has also had successful sell-out shows in London, Sydney and Melbourne, and has work in collections across the world.

Nigel Milsom (born 1971) is an Australian artist and former lawyer who works mainly in oil and watercolour painting. Inspired by Surrealism and Expressionism and influenced by the works of Edward Hopper and Willem de Kooning, Milsom paints a variety of themes, including portraits, landscapes and interiors. His works often explore psychological, social and political themes, with a focus on individuals and the relationships between people and their environment. Milsom’s art series are associated with experiences he has had during his life, such as those from his childhood in Newcastle, Australia.

Milsom is a self-taught artist and won the 2011 Archibald Prize for his portrait of the artist Ben Quilty. He was also awarded the 2011 Doug Moran National Portrait Prize, and was a finalist for the 2010, 2012 and 2016 Wynne Prizes. He lives and works in the northern suburbs of Sydney.

Nigel Milsom is an Australian painter, who was born in Mudgee, New South Wales in 1981. He completed a Bachelor of Visual Arts in the National Art School in 2001 and a Master of Visual Arts in the University of New South Wales College of Fine Arts in 2009. His works reflect his observation about the human condition, particularly about the lives of people living on the margins of contemporary society. He has exhibited extensively in Australia and internationally.

Milsom's works are held in public and private collections in Australia, as well as internationally in Canada, the UK, and the USA. In 2011, he won the Sulman Prize and in 2017 he won the Archibald Prize with a painting of author, filmmaker and comedian John Clarke. He is represented by the Nicholas Thompson Gallery in Melbourne and the Maunsell Wickes Gallery in Sydney.

Nigel Milsom (born 1978) is an Australian artist from Sydney. He is best known for his paintings which are characterised by strong, broad brushstrokes and a confident use of colour. His work draws on diverse influences including Expressionism, Pop art, and Street art.

Milsom's practice is mainly focused on portraiture, landscape and still life, although his output is also highly eclectic. Taking as his starting point materials of everyday life such as packaging, broken objects and other detritus, he works to layer history, autobiography and narrative into each painting. He has exhibited widely in Australia and is represented by Gallery211 in Sydney. Milsom lives and works in Sydney.

Nigel Milsom (born 1977) is an Australian painter. His work is mostly figurative painting, primarily of figures in the urban landscape. He is recognised for his ability to capture the human condition, expressing conflict, empathy, joy and despair in his work.

Milsom was born in Sydney and completed an Advanced Diploma of Fine Arts at Sydney's National Art School in 2002. He then acquired a Bachelor of Fine Arts at the College of Fine Arts, University of New South Wales in 2005. His first important award was the Paddington Art Prize in 2007.

He has developed a unique figure style, generally painting figures with a palette of white, beige, greens and heavy black outlines, giving them a very graphic style. This is combined with a detailed yet flattened representation of their environments. His works are held in major public galleries in Australia and overseas and have been auctioned in Sydney and Melbourne. He currently divides his time between painting and teaching at the National Art School.

Nigel Milsom is an Australian artist. He was born in 1972 in Newcastle and grew up in the neighbouring town of Raymond Terrace, New South Wales. He attended the University of Newcastle and graduated with a Bachelor of Fine Arts in 1997. 

Milsom has exhibited his artwork extensively in Australia and internationally, including solo exhibitions in Australia, Fiji, New Zealand and the United Kingdom. He won the Archibald Prize for portraiture in 2013 for his self-portrait titled "Jude, deb 2010". He has received numerous awards, including the Wyndham Art Prize (2012), Wynne Prize (2012) and People’s Choice Award at the 23rd Biennale of Sydney (2018). Milsom is represented by Sullivan+Strumpf in Sydney and London.

Nigel Milsom (born 1979) is an Australian painter and sculpture based in Sydney. Milsom was born in Central Coast, New South Wales and studied at the University of Newcastle, NSW.

Milsom's work has been part of major international art exhibitions in the United Kingdom, Europe, and the United States, and he has been the recipient of multiple art awards. He won the 2009 Archibald Prize for portraiture and the 2013 Sulman Prize for subject painting and the 2015 Dobell Prize for Drawing. His work is held in the collections of the National Gallery of Australia, the National Gallery of Victoria, the Art Gallery of New South Wales, and several other art galleries throughout Australia. Milsom's works demonstrate a wide variety of approaches to painting representing the endless range of pictorial possibilities that that medium presents. He often employs a loose application of paint, most noticeably in his works on canvas. His works on paper tend to be much tighter and use a clear, concise approach to the image.

Milsom's body of work is concerned with themes of power, money, celebrity, public life, and

Nigel Milsom (born 1983) is an Australian artist and musician who has been described as a "mix of street artist and old master". He won the 2011 Moran Contemporary Photographic Prize and the Archibald Prize in 2013. He is known for his surreal, textured landscape and portrait paintings.

Milsom was born in 1983 in Blacktown, New South Wales, Australia. He studied law and psychology in his hometown and in Cairns, Queensland. He cites Rene Magritte, Edward Hopper, and Francis Bacon as his major influences. His works often comprise dreamy and unnerving elements, with his paintings incorporating mixed media such as spray paint and paper towel. He was a finalist for the Doug Moran National Portrait Prize in 2014. Milsom has exhibited throughout Australia.

Nigel Milsom is an Australian contemporary realist painter. Born in 1979 in Gosford, New South Wales, he grew up in the Central Coast region and studied painting at the National Art School in Darlinghurst, Sydney. Milsom produces large-scale realist oil paintings, often depicting contemporary scenes of everyday Australia and its culture. He has won multiple awards including the Archibald Prize for portraiture in 2013 for his work, "John Auguste". In 2016, he was awarded the Packing Room Prize for his painting "The Shed". He was recognised with the Haden Photographic Portrait Prize in 2017 and was also selected as a finalist for the Sulman Prize and Wynne Prize for two different paintings in the same year. Milsom is represented in major public and private collections throughout Australia and New Zealand.

Nigel Milsom is an Australian visual artist, known for his painterly interpretations of everyday scenes. As the child of Nigerian and English parents, he grew up in Newcastle, an industrial port city on Australia's east coast. His work explores the "unease of being Australian" and the duality and transience of identity. Selected solo exhibitions include MCA Australia and Après-midi, Entrée, Pataka Art + Museum, Porirua, New Zealand (both 2017), So Much I Held Within Before Silence…, GAGPROJECTS, Brisbane (2016), Painting Has Always Been an Act of Balance, Gellerypanserbirg, Copenhagen, Denmark (2015), and Humanly Possible, Olsen Gruin, New York, US (2014).

Nigel Milsom is an Australian artist, born Sydney in 1978 and lives in Newcastle, New South Wales. Milsom's career began in the mid 2000s and has been the recipient of numerous prizes and accolades, including the $40,000 Dobell Prize for Drawing at the Art Gallery of New South Wales in 2012, the Sir John Sulman Prize in 2015, and the Doug Moran National Portrait Prize in 2019. His art engages in themes of identity politics, international relations, and power structures. 

Milsom's works often feature highly rendered landscapes, empty rooms or back-alleys populated by discarded or forgotten objects. He often incorporates found objects into his work, such as pieces of scrap metal, cardboard, broken dishes, dirt, and paint. He is an Honorary Professor in the School of Creative Arts, The University of Newcastle.

Nigel Milsom (born 1976) is an Australian painter known for his portraits, landscapes and still life works. He was born and raised in Newcastle, New South Wales. He studied painting at the National Art School in Sydney in 1998 and has since become one of Australia’s most celebrated and awarded painters. In 2013 he was awarded the Archibald Prize for his self-portrait painted in the medium of a Rembrandt painting, entitled The Guilty Husband. He is currently represented by the Michael Reid showroom in Sydney. His work is often described as being bold and graphic, while using muted colours and compositions. He is strongly influenced by Northern European old master painting and art from the 19th Century and beyond. In 2017 he was shortlisted for the prestigious Siemens/A&E Art Prize.

Nigel Milsom (born 1977) is an Australian painter. He graduated from Sport and Visual Arts at Swinburne University accompanied by a number of art awards. He has gone on to receive numerous public and private commissions, awards and residencies in Australia and across the world.

Milsom's aim is to disrupt and complicate art history and to challenge viewers to join his own cultural conversations. He does this by combining traditional modalities of painting with present-day approaches to space, composition and expression. He painted a piece for the Archibald Prize exhibition in 2009 and has since shown work in a range of galleries. His work has been held in the collections of the Art Gallery of New South Wales, Cbus Collection, National Gallery of Victoria and the MPRG.

Milsom has received numerous awards, including the Wynne Prize (2015, 2017), Genia Michaela Sosin Commission (2013,2015), Dobell Prize (2012, 2014), andwas included in Younger than Jesus by The New Museum in NYC (2009).

Nigel Milsom (born 1977) is an Australian artist. Born in Newcastle, New South Wales, Milsom studied painting at the University of Newcastle (now the University of Newcastle Australia) graduating in 2002. His work is strongly inspired by narratives of his own life, and is notable for its richly coloured, expressionistic use of paint. In 2020, Milsom was made a Member of the Order of Australia for his services to the visual arts.

Milsom is represented in numerous public and private collections and was a finalist in prestigious art awards including the Archibald Prize, the Brett Whiteley Travelling Art Scholarship and the Doug Moran National Portrait Prize. He is best known for his role as in the 2018 Channel 9/SBS series 'Portrait Artist of the Year', where he co-judged with British artist Tai Shan Schierenberg. Milsom's first major solo exhibition, “Garden of Unearthly Delights”, was held in 2018 at the National Art School Gallery, Sydney, and his work has been the subject of two documentaries.

Nigel Milsom (born 1978) is an Australian painter and artist. He achieved national recognition in 2010 when he won the Archibald Prize for his first entry in the competition, a portrait of the artist Warren H Williams. He has had a number of successful solo and group exhibitions, including the Weswal Gallery in Sydney, Leo Kamen Gallery in Melbourne and Metro Gallery in Brisbane.

Milsom works primarily in oil paint on canvas and often uses source material from magazines and books to explore his interests in a wide range of subjects including music, politics, religion and consumerism. His imagery today often involves surreal dreamscapes and often display a loose sense of realism or surrealism. His work frequently explores Australian identity and society, particularly in references to the struggle between Indigenous Australians and white settlement. Milsom is a storyteller in his work and works are often seen as a visual autobiography. He is passionate about communicating through his art issues of identity, cultural heritage and issues of oppression.

Nigel Milsom (born 23 December 1975) is an Australian painter. He has been in the National Gallery of Victoria's permanent collection since 2004, when he had his first solo show at Melbourne's Tolarno Galleries. His work is focused largely on portraiture and still lives and often centers on people from his local inner-city Sydney community. He has won numerous awards, including the Wynne Prize in 2013, Australia's oldest art award, and the Sulman Prize in 2011. His work is represented in various public and private collections, including the National Gallery of Victoria, the Art Gallery of New South Wales and the Queensland Art Gallery. He also co-founded the 107 Projects gallery in Redfern, Sydney in 2017.
16:
Terry John Alderman (born 3 April 1951) is an Australian former cricketer. A right arm fast-medium bowler, Alderman took 781 wickets in first-class cricket and 114 wickets in Test matches between 1972 and 1989. He had a formidable bouncer, and a useful off-cutter and leg-cutter, generally bowling around medium pace.

Alderman is best remembered for his performances in the 1981 and 1989 Ashes series against England. In the 1981 series, he took 33 wickets and claimed the mantle of Player of the Series. He bettered that performance in the 1989 series, taking 41 wickets, including a ten for in the Fifth Test. He was chosen as Player of the Series for his efforts, and was the first man in Test cricket to win the Player of the Series award in consecutive Ashes series.

Terry Alderman (born 19 April 1952) is a former Australian cricketer who had a long and successful career in both Test and One-Day International (ODI) cricket. Alderman played 39 Tests for Australia from 1979 to 1988, taking 121 wickets at an average of 28.10, including 11 five-wicket hauls. He also played 59 ODIs, in which he took 87 wickets at an average of 24.98 and with best figures of 5/31.

Alderman was a right-arm fast bowler who was capable of swinging the ball both ways, and he became a key member of Australia's Test squad in the 1980s. His best innings figures of 6/89 came in the third Ashes Test at Headingley in 1981, and in the same match he also scored a useful 37 lower down the order. Alderman's most successful season came in 1989–90, when he took a total of 71 wickets at 22.48 in the Sheffield Shield. He had a long and successful career before retiring in 1994.

Terry Alderman (born 14 November 1952) is a former Australian cricketer who was part of the successful Australian team of the 1980s. He bowled right-arm medium pace and was widely regarded as one of the finest swing and seam bowlers in the world. He flourished in domestic cricket for South Australia, and in Test cricket for Australia, claiming 122 wickets in his 32 tests.

Alderman debuted for Australia in the Centenary Test at Lord's in 1980 and earned himself a place in the side for the steps that followed. He was an integral part of the Australian bowling attack, his ability to swing the ball both ways proving an invaluable asset to the team. He was particularly effective against the English, taking more wickets in England than any other bowler in the 1980s. He also formed an effective bowling partnership with Geoff Lawson, the pair combining for many years for both domestic South Australian cricket and for Australia. He was not only a fine bowler however, as his batting was also highly rated, with his clean hitting particularly useful when batting lower down the order.

Terry Alderman (born 19 April 1952) is an Australian cricketer and former Australian rules footballer. Alderman began his career in Perth Western Australia playing over 50 senior games in the WANFL for East Perth between 1970 and 1972. During this time he represented Western Australia twice in interstate competitions. 

In 1973 Alderman decided to focus on cricket, and played for East Perth until his retirement in 1987. During his years with East Perth he played 182 first class games and took 741 wickets at an average of 21.53 runs per wicket. Alderman played in 16 Tests for Australia between 1981 and 1985, taking 70 wickets at an average of 23.94. Alderman is remembered as one of Australia's best and most aggressive fast-medium bowlers of the era. He was awarded the MBE in January 1985 for services to sport.

Terry David Alderman (born 13 October 1948) is an Australian former professional cricketer and Australian rules footballer. He is a former international cricketer and a former member of the Fremantle Dockers.

Alderman played 39 tests and 72 One Day Internationals for Australia before retiring from cricket in 1990. In the 1980s, Alderman was a feared Australian fast bowler, playing a crucial role in Australia's 1982-83 Ashes success with 41 wickets on the tour. He was only the third man in Test cricket to reach the 50-mark in a Test season, Dennis Lillee and Waqar Younis being the other two. Terry Alfred Alderman (born 11 March 1954) is an Australian former Test and One Day International cricketer. Terry Keith Alderman (born 8 December 1952) is a former Australian cricketer who played 41 Test matches and 62 One Day Internationals (ODIs) for Australia in the 1980s and 1990s.

Alderman was a pace bowler of the type most frequently seen in Australia in the 1980s, the tall, seemingly effortless fast-medium bowler. Terry Dean Alderdice (born 2 November 1963) is an Australian former professional cricketer who played for the Australian national team between 1985 and 1992. A medium-fast bowler, he appeared in 11 Test matches and 79 One Day Internationals (ODIs), taking 86 and 113 wickets respectively. Alderdice enjoyed most of his success in the one-day format, taking four or five-wicket hauls on four occasions in which he was named man of the match. He represented Western Australia in the Sheffield Shield and Perth in the Australian domestic limited overs competition. His career was hampered by chronic knee injuries, resulting in premature retirement in 1996.

Terry Alderman (born 3 May 1950) is a former Australian cricketer. He was one of the most successful Australian bowlers of the 1980s and early 1990s, taking 236 wickets in 47 Test matches at an average of 28.7. He was also an effective lower order batsman, scoring 1247 runs at an average of 18.83.

Alderman went on to experience a great deal of success in the 1981 Ashes series against England and was awarded the Player of the Series for claiming his 34 wickets with his accurate fast medium bowling. He gained worldwide fame for his dramatic bowling performances, with another successful Australian tour of England in 1989. Alderman was part of the Australian team that went on the winning 1989/90 tour of England, taking 29 wickets in the series.

Terry Alderman (born 5 October 1951) is a former Australian cricketer and international cricket coach, mainly thought of as a right arm medium-fast swing bowler. He was born in Long Jetty, New South Wales, Australia.

Alderman played 52 Tests for Australia from 1980 to 1991, playing the last at the age of 40. In this time, he took 167 wickets at an average of 28.05.During this period his cricket was characterized by an ability to swing the ball both ways, and he is revered as one of the most successful Australian swing bowlers. He was named as one of the five Wisden Cricketers of the Year for 1981.

Terry Alan Alderman (born 15 August 1951) is an Australian former cricketer, who played in 51 Tests and 25 One-Day Internationals for Australia between 1979 and 1991.

Alderman was primarily a fast-medium pace bowler. He is best remembered for his performance in the Ashes series in England in 1981, when Australia set a then-world record by winning all six Tests. Alderman took an impressive 41 wickets in the series, at an average of 18.48, and was named man of the series.

In 1990 Alderman was again a member of the Australian team that retained the Ashes in England. During that series, in the third test of the series at Old Trafford he reached a personal mark of 150 wickets in Test cricket.

Alderman retired from cricket in 1994 after having played first-class cricket in Australia, England, and South Africa. He is currently a batting coach in Perth, Western Australia.

Terry Alderman (born 3 June 1952) is a retired Australian cricketer. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest and successful bowling attack in Test cricket history. He took 202 wickets in a career lasting from 1982 to 1994, including six five-wicket hauls and a dozen four-wicket hauls. He holds the record for most wickets for Australia in a Test series (41 wickets in 1989–90 Ashes against England). He was also part of Australia's golden era of fast bowling in the 1980s, alongside Jeff Thomson and Craig McDermott. Alderman is also known for his sense of humour and as an entertaining speaker.

Terry Alderman (born 2 April 1954) is an Australian former cricketer. He was a right-arm fast-medium bowler who made his first-class debut for Western Australia in 1977. He featured in an Australian touring team which visited India in 1979 and went on to become a notable member of the Australia Test and One Day International teams. Alderman played in 39 Tests and taking 114 wickets at an average of 29.25, and made his highest Test score of 82 not out against India at the WACA in January 1992. During his Test career, Alderman took four five-wicket-hauls. He also played in 59 One Day Internationals, taking 74 wickets at an average of 27.77, with his best figures of 4/34 coming against Pakistan in Lahore in 1986. Alderman retired from all forms of cricket in 1994.

Terry Wallace Aldermas (born 14 January 1953) is an Australian former professional cricketer who is recognised as one of the greatest swing bowlers in Australian cricket history. Aldermas made his international debut in 1979 and went on to represent Australia in 49 Test matches and 32 One Day Internationals (ODI) over an 11-year international career.

During his career, Aldermas was renowned as one of Australia's greatest ever swing bowlers and was often praised for his accuracy and consistency. He was also seen as one of the few bowlers at the time who could be relied upon to make regular breakthroughs in the batsmen's defences, regularly taking crucial wickets in winning Test matches. Aldermas was named as one of Australia's five Wisden Cricketers of the Year in 1981, and became the first bowler since Shane Warne to take 400 Test wickets in 1997, finishing his career with an impressive tally of 422 Test wickets. Aldermas was awarded the Order of Australia Medal in 2005 for his services to cricket.

Terry Alderman (born 11 December 1950) is a former Australian Test cricketer, who is most famous for his performances in the 1981 Ashes series in England and named in the Australia's team of the 1980's. Alderman was a back-up bowler but seized the opportunity, taking a record-breaking 41 wickets at an average of 23.12 in the series, including a hat-trick in the fourth Test at Headingley. He also had a notable batting performance in the same Test, hitting his first and only Test century to regain a first innings lead.

He took 103 wickets in his 24 Test appearances, with a bowling average of 32.39. He toured India and England, and was part of the 1982 World Cup-winning squad. Terry Alderman (born 22 April 1955) is an Australian former cricketer who played for the Australian cricket team in Test matches and One-Day Internationals. He is most famed for his bowling in Test matches, in which he took 121 wickets at an average of 30.18. He also took 124 wickets in One-Day Internationals at an average of 23.72 and took 10 or more wickets in a match on four occasions. He was a right-arm fast-medium bowler and useful lower-order batsman. Alderman made his debut for Western Australia in the 1976–77 season, and his Test debut against India in 1980–81. He was part of the Australian team which won the 1983 World Cup. 

Following a shoulder injury, Alderman took a break from cricket and moved to England, where he played for Hampshire in the early 1990s and for Derbyshire from 1993 to 1995 before retiring from first-class cricket in 1997.

Terry Alderman (born 15 January 1951) is an Australian former cricketer. He is one of the few players to have represented both Australia and England in Test cricket.

Alderman began his cricket career playing Sheffield Shield cricket for Western Australia in 1975–76. He claimed a then-record seven wickets on debut, and ended the season with 25 wickets. The following season he made his Test debut for Australia against Pakistan at Brisbane in 1977–78, replacing the injured Dennis Lillee.

In the 1982–83 Ashes series against England, Alderman took a then career-best of 8–75 in the second Test at Adelaide and topped the bowling averages for the series with 29 wickets at 19.31. His strong performance in the Tests earned him selection for the 1983 Cricket World Cup in which he took 13 wickets in 10 matches.

In 1989 Alderman became one of the first players in cricket history to play for England after representing another country. He was chosen for a tour of West Indies but was unable to take part and moved to England in 1991. He returned to Test cricket in 1993–94,

Terry Paul Aldermen (born 16 December 1954) is an Australian former cricketer who represented Australia in both Tests and One Day Internationals from 1980 to 1993. Aldermen is a right arm fast bowler who holds the record in Test matches for the most wickets taken in a single Australian season with 68, set in the 1983–84 season when he was the leading wicket-taker in Test cricket. During this season, he took his career-best figures of eight wickets for the match and a career-best innings figures of six wickets for the match against Pakistan. Aldermen took 109 wickets in his Test career at an average of 31.61 and took 129 wickets in One Day Internationals at an average of 24.20. He also scored three Test half centuries and four ODI half centuries, including a career-best of 86. He won a total of four Man of the Match awards, two in Tests and two in ODIs.

Terry Alderman (born 6 October 1949, in Loxton, South Australia) is an Australian former cricketer who played for Western Australia and England. Alderman, a right-arm medium-fast bowler, appeared in 52 Test matches for Australia and took 123 wickets at an average of 28.94, making him Australia's sixth highest wicket taker as of 2020. He also appeared in 58 One Day Internationals, taking 64 wickets at an average of 28.75. He is particularly remembered for having a dominant performance against England in the 1981 Ashes series, where he took 45 wickets and achieved a Test career best of 7/124. During the the 1983–84 Ashes series, Alderman was forced to stop after mishitting a bouncer and was treated with over 100 stitches. He was out of Test cricket for two and a half years due to back and shoulder injuries sustained in the incident.

Terry Alderman (born 1 June 1954) is a former Australian cricketer who played in 41 Tests and 10 ODIs from 1981 to 1989. He is one of Australia's best-ever opening bowlers, appearing with great success alongside the great Australian fast bowler Geoff Lawson.

Alderman's career began when Dennis Lillee returned from injury in 1981–1982. He took seven wickets on his debut in the second Ashes test at Adelaide in December 1981 and, with his unorthodox action, went on to take a total of 78 Test wickets in the 1981–83 Ashes series—the third highest behind only Ian Botham and Bob Willis. This earned Alderman the Player of the Series award as Australia reclaimed the Ashes. He also performed well against West Indies and Pakistan in the following seasons.

Alderman retired from international cricket in 1989. He went on to represent various first-class sides in Australia and England, including Surrey and Essex. Frank A. McLain (April 14, 1884 – April 1, 1967) was an American electrical engineer, inventor and entrepreneur. He is best known for his work with the National Broadcasting Company (NBC) in the development of television.

McLain's career began in 1904, when he joined Thomas Edison's laboratory in Orange, New Jersey. He received a patent for the "L Rule," a caliper device for measuring wire, in 1910. He went on to become an electrical engineer for RCA Victor in 1915, and later joined NBC in 1932, where he developed one of the first color television systems.

McLain's work was also instrumental in the development of the VTR (videotape recorder) and the PFS (Personal Identification System). He was later president of Mason Laboratories and McDonnell Research Corporation.

McLain died in Elmsford, New York at the age of 83. The Frank A. McLain Lecture Hall at CBS Television City in Hollywood, California is named in his honor.

Frank A. McLain (1876–1952) was an American lawyer and politician. Born in Covington, Kentucky, he served in the Kentucky House of Representatives between 1909 and 1920 and in the Kentucky Senate from 1921 until 1934. He attended the Georgetown College and University of Kentucky. In 1934, McLain was elected to the U.S. Senate. He served from 1934 to 1941, when he was defeated for reelection. As a Senator, he supported the Social Security Act, the National Labor Relations Act, and the Wagner Act. After his term in the Senate, McLain returned to Kentucky and resumed his law practice. He passed away in 1952.

Frank A. McLain (July 12, 1858–May 27, 1943) was an American attorney, politician and banker. He served as the 25th Mayor of Pittsburgh from 1909 to 1912, and was later appointed by President Franklin D. Roosevelt as U.S. Treasurer.

The youngest child of Julia (Gleason) and Robert McLain, a shoemaker, McLain was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. While attending public school, he worked as a printer for a newspaper. Later, he pursued a law degree from Allegheny College. After being admitted to the Pennsylvania Bar in 1885, he devoted himself to legal practice and politics. In 1888, McLain was the unsuccessful Republican nominee for state supreme court justice.

McLain was elected Mayor of Pittsburgh in 1909 and served until 1912. He ran unsuccessfully again for that office in 1914. From 1922 to 1931, he was the president of Liberty National Bank, and then after its merger with Mellon Bank, he was chair of the Mellon Board of Directors. Frank A. McLain (February 18, 1894 – May 21, 1972) was an American brigadier general who served in World War I, World War II and the Korean War.

He was born in Ashland, Wisconsin, where he attended local schools before graduating from the University of Wisconsin–Madison with a Bachelor of Science degree, and a major in mining engineering in 1915. During World War I McLain saw combat service in France. After the war he was assigned to various positions in the Department of the Army at Washington, DC.

At the start of World War II, McLain was selected for promotion to the rank of major general and was tasked with commanding the 91st Infantry Division. The Division was activated in 1940 and McLain continued to serve in command of the 91st until he was reassigned to serve in the European Theater of Operations in 1945 and organized several combat commands in the 12th Army Group. After the end of World War II, McLain and the 91st Division were sent to San Francisco.

McLain went on to command the 5th Infantry Division in Korea and the 14th Infantry Division

Frank A. McLain (19 November 1837 - 4 May 1918) was an American politician and a member of the Democratic Party. A native of Madison County, Kentucky, he represented the twelfth district of Kentucky in the United States House of Representatives from 1883-1889. 

McLain graduated from Kentucky Military Institute in 1857 and moved to Frankfort, Kentucky, where he opened a law office. He was a state representative in 1867 and served in the Kentucky Senate from 1875 to 1877. 

McLain was an unsuccessful candidate for lieutenant governor in 1875 and 1879. He served as president of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad from 1886 to 1891, and was appointed Collector of Internal Revenue for the Sixth District of Kentucky in 1893 and served until 1897. He then resumed his law practice in Frankfort. 

McLain died in Frankfort, Kentucky on 4 May 1918, and was buried in Frankfort Cemetery.

Frank A. McLain (April 22, 1905 – October 30, 1992) was an American radio and television personality, best remembered for his long tenure on the nightly radio quiz show Information Please. McLain was born in New Haven, Connecticut and began his radio career in 1932 in New York City.

At the end of 1933, McLain joined the cast of the new weekly radio program Information Please, which premiered on May 8. McLain played the part of the “strictly indifferent” timekeeper of the show, setting the time limits for contestants to answer questions from the show’s panel. McLain stayed with Information Please until its final broadcast on June 7, 1948; he returned as master of ceremonies when the show was briefly revived as an NBC network program in 1952. McLain was part of the quiz show panel on NBC's College Quiz Bowl in 1953, 1954, and 1955. Frank Aloysius McLain (April 25, 1892 – August 4, 1946) was an American lawyer and politician who served as speaker of the Florida House of Representatives and attorney general of Florida.

McLain was born in Madison, Florida on April 25, 1892, the son of Frank E. and Mary (McCormick) McLain. He attended the University of Florida, where he received a bachelor's degree in 1911, and then attended law school at the same institution, receiving his law degree in 1913.

McLain practiced law in Madison from 1913 to 1917. He then relocated to Fort Pierce, where he served as city attorney from 1920 to 1923. In 1924, McLain was elected to the Florida House of Representatives for St. Lucie County and was subsequently chosen as Speaker of the House in 1925. In 1926, McLain was elected Attorney General of Florida, and he served in that position until 1931.

"Frank A. McLain (September 9, 1862–May 28, 1940) was an American lawyer, politician, and investor from Kentucky. He began his career in politics as a member of the Kentucky House of Representatives before serving in the Kentucky Senate. He later held a gubernatorial appointment as Commissioner of Agriculture for the state of Kentucky from 1895 to 1899. McLain served in various capacities in government and the legal profession, and he was an investor in the banking and railroad industries. He also owned considerable real estate in Kentucky during his lifetime and was a member of several philanthropic organizations."

Frank A. McLain (July 24, 1866 – December 21, 1947) was an American politician and banker who served as the mayor of Montgomery for three terms during the early 20th century. Born in Montgomery, McLain began his career in banking as a founding member of the Exchange Bank. He became directly involved in politics following the 1898 Montgomery mayoral election, which was widely disputed. McLain was part of a three-man commission that determined the outcome of this election, a decision which caused McLain to be dubbed the "father of good government" by the Montgomery Advertiser.

Shortly thereafter, McLain received his own victorious election as mayor of Montgomery, serving three terms in office between 1901 and 1907. During his terms, McLain was responsible for several major changes which he implemented in the city, including the introduction of electricity and sewage systems, the creation of a police and fire commission, and the launch of a city-wide street paving project. Frank A. McLain (1868–1945) was an American political figure. He served as a member of the Ohio House of Representatives from 1897 to 1901, representing Knox County, Ohio. McLain was born in Thayerville, Ohio, on November 5, 1868, and later attended Ohio Northern University in Ada, Ohio. He began his career teaching school and later practiced law. McLain was elected as a Democrat to the Ohio House of Representatives in 1896 and served until 1901, when he was appointed judge of the court of common pleas of Knox County. He was re-elected to the court in 1909, 1915 and 1921. McLain was a knight of the Masonic Order, member of the Knights of Pythias, and Shriner. He died in 1945.

Frank A. McLain (April 14, 1870 – November 7, 1963) was an American engineer and inventor known for his patents and contributions to road construction and the early automobile industry. Born in Suiford,Virginia, he was the son of Moses and Mary Bennett Williams McLain. One of his earliest patents was for a "Revised Gravity Arc Machine," submitted in 1905 and issued in 1906. This machine was made to level off the long, flat stretches of road that were quickly becoming an essential part of the American transportation system. 

McLain held more than 50 patents and was involved in numerous associations and clubs dedicated to engineering. He also worked with Edison Electric Illuminating Company, Penn Street and Reading Railroad, Studebaker, and American Steamship. He was a charter member of the American Society of Civil Engineers, a member of the Automobile Club of America, and a member of the National Geographic Society. He founded the Suiford Institute of Applied Mechanics in 1907, where he taught courses on road construction, hydraulics, and engineering. McLain wrote and published several books on these topics as well.

Frank A. McLain (1860–1936) was an American soldier and politician from Marietta, Georgia. He served Georgia in the state legislature from 1889–1890 and again from 1907–1914. First elected as a Democrat, he later switched to the People's Party and eventually the Republican Party.

McLain served during the Spanish–American War as a Colonel in the Georgia National Guard; he was the owner and commander of Company K of the 3rd Georgia Infantry Regiment. Following the war, he was a major during the Philippine–American War, where he helped quell an uprising. He was a decorated veteran, earning several medals, including the Congressional Medal of Honor.

McLain served as Marietta's mayor following his service in the legislature. After his term was up, he served as the chairman of the Georgia Republican Party. He was also a chartered member of the Veterans of Foreign Wars and held the post of state commander of the organization. He was an advocate for veterans' rights, pushing for the establishment of a veterans' home in Georgia. He passed away in 1936 at the

Frank A. McLain (March 2, 1947 - April 29, 2015) was an American physicist and expert in applied mathematics and numerical modeling. He worked for many years in the Atmospheric Sciences Division at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory as a technical staff member and as a program manager.

McLain's career at LLNL began in 1973. He initially served as Principle Investigator on the TeraFLOPS program, responsible for the single precision numerical simulation of atmospheric tracer transport, and more recently as Program Manager of the Massively Parallel Initiative. He was the first person to recognize and champion the potential of massively parallel computing at LLNL. He got the LLNL massively parallel research project up and running. He earned an Outstanding Performance Award in 1988 for this work.

McLain’s other contributions to LLNL included work on growing atmospheric science research related to global climate change, space-weather, and global atmospheric physics. He was a lead investigator on the Multi-Scale Modeling Initiative, a joint project between LLNL and the National Center for Atmospheric Research. McLain was also a Professor Emeritus in the Computer Science Department

Frank Aloysius McLain (1865–1949) was an American soldier and diplomat who served in the Spanish–American War, Philippine Insurrection, and the Boxer Rebellion. He was born in Bangor, Maine to Edward McLain, a shipper, and Isabella McLain (née Donley).

McLain attended the Maine State Normal School and graduated in 1883. He then went on to attend Harvard University, but was evacuated due to rioting during the Boston Bread Riot of 1886. After leaving Harvard, McLain began his military career in the Spanish–American War, enlisting in the US Army as a private in 1898. He was promoted to Sergeant Major and assigned to the 29th Infantry Regiment in the Philippines, where he took part in numerous engagements during the Philippine Insurrection.

McLain rose to the rank of Captain shortly after his arrival in the Philippines, and was appointed to serve as the Commissioner of the U.S. Legation in Peking in 1901. In this position, McLain was responsible for supervising the nation's diplomatic efforts during the Boxer Rebellion. He was

Frank A. McLain (1868-1957) was a pioneering early fruit grower and tomato expert in Florida. He was born in 1868 in North Carolina and at the age of twelve, he moved with his parents to Francisville, Florida. He started out as a truck farmer in the late 1880s and soon discovered that the sandy soils of Florida were perfect for growing delicious tomatoes. He quickly became an expert in tomato production and was one of the first to introduce new varieties of tomatoes to the Florida markets. For the next sixty years McLain was known as the "tomato king" of Florida and the leader of the Florida tomato industry. He grew new varieties of tomatoes such as the Big Boy, and served as a consultant to growers across the state. He was an innovator in marketing, packaging and shipping Florida tomatoes, introducing practices that are still in use today. He earned the respect of growers and was consulted by the Agricultural Extension Service and the Florida Agricultural Experiment Station. Frank A. McLain (1896–1977) was an American lawyer and politician from the state of Missouri.

McLain served in the United States House of Representatives from 1941 to 1945 as a Democrat, representing Missouri's 11th Congressional District. He was an early leader in the development of the rural electrification program created by President Franklin Delano Roosevelt's New Deal. He was re-elected to a second term in 1942 but was defeated in 1944 by Republican Thomas B. Bates.

McLain was born in Maitland, Missouri. He was educated in the local schools and attended the Central School of Commerce in St. Louis, Missouri. He later enrolled in the Washington University Law School, where he graduated with a law degree in 1920. After practicing with a St. Louis law firm for some years, McLain's political career began in 1931, when he was elected as a Democratic to the Missouri state senate, where he served until 1937. He was best known for his advocacy for rural electrification, which he helped to pass in the state legislature and also continued to support once in Congress.

Frank A. McLain (1877-1933) was an American pioneer airman, aeronautical engineer, aviator and airplane builder. He was born in 1877 in New Orleans, Louisiana, and grew up in the Mississippi Delta.

He taught himself mathematics and mechanics while working as an auto mechanic, and at one point worked for Samuel Langley in the Smithsonian Institution shops in Washington, DC. After attending the Wright Brothers' flying school at Dayton, Ohio, and receiving his pilot's license in August 1911, McLain went on to become one of the more popular "Flier Demonstrators" of the day. He flew in and around Wisconsin, Michigan and Minnesota and was one of the first pilots to complete a two-stop tour of the United States.

During World War I, McLain saw active service with the Air Service and was in charge of training pilots in bombing techniques at Belleville, Illinois. After the war was over, he became the chief test pilot for Wright Aeronautical in Dayton, Ohio. He died in 1933 at the age of 56.

Frank A. McLain (June 28, 1929 – March 11, 2020) was an American jazz saxophonist, pianist, and teacher. He was a Louisiana native, and a charter member of the Louisiana Music Hall of Fame.

McLain was born in Natchitoches, Louisiana. He earned a bachelor's degree and a master's degree in music education from Northwestern State University in Natchitoches and taught there for 38 years. As a teacher, he was credited with launching the career of fellow saxophonist Clarence 'Gatemouth' Brown.

The Natchitoches native spent most of his career in music education, but also toured nationally and internationally with acts such as the Tommy Dorsey Orchestra, the Sam Donahue Orchestra, and most prominently with the Lionel Hampton Band. He was featured as a soloist with Hampton in the late 1950s.

In 2014, McLain was inducted as a charter member of the Louisiana Music Hall of Fame, recognizing his longevity as a musician and his contributions to jazz education.

Frank Anthony McLain (born May 9, 1901 – July 28, 1962) was an American soldier and diplomat. He received the nation’s highest honor, the Medal of Honor, for gallantry in combat during World War II.

A member of the United States Army Reserve, McLain was inducted into active service in April 1941. He was assigned to the 117th Infantry Regiment, and was a platoon leader in Company E. On October 28 of that same year, McLain was wounded during an assault against German forces in North Africa.

Despite his wounds, McLain continued leading his platoon and encouraged his men’s bravery in the face of enemy fire. For his part in the assault, McLain received the Medal of Honor in December of 1942, one month before his 41st birthday. In addition to the Medal of Honor, McLain received the Distinguished Service Cross and two Bronze Star Medals for gallantry in action.

After the war, McLain left the Army, and in 1946 was appointed ambassador to Guatemala. Later he served on the staffs of both President Dwight Eisenhower and Vice President Richard Nixon

Frank A. McLain (1858–1933) was an American land surveyor and politician who served in the Wisconsin State Senate and multiple other public offices.

Born in Wrightstown, Pennsylvania, McLain moved to Denmark, Wisconsin in Brown County in 1876 and became a land surveyor. He was Town Clerk and Town Treasurer of Denmark, Wisconsin and served in the Wisconsin State Senate from 1889 to 1893. He was a Republican. From 1894 to 1903, McLain was the Clerk of Courts for Brown County, Wisconsin. Filmore H. Post, McLain’s distant relation, served at the same time. McLain then served as Postmaster of Denmark, Wisconsin until he retired in 1923. He died at his home in Denmark, Wisconsin.

Torry Castellano (born August 27, 1979) is an American musician. She is best known for being the drummer for the punk rock band The Distillers from 1998-2006.

Castellano is a self-taught musician. She began playing drums when she was twelve years old and joined the Distillers in 1998, replacing then-drummer Matt Young. During her time with the Distillers, the band released three full-length albums and several EPs. The band attained worldwide success, appearing on late-night talk shows and touring with bands such as The Offspring and the Foo Fighters.

In 2004, Castellano was diagnosed with reflex sympathetic dystrophy, a chronic nerve disorder, which led to her departure from the Distillers in 2006. Since then, Castellano has advocated for women in the music industry and has been involved in other music projects.

Torry Castellano (born October 26, 1979) is an American musician and songwriter. She is best known as the drummer and songwriter of the all-female punk rock group The Donnas. She is also the author and illustrator of the comic book series Dandelion.

Castellano first gained musical notoriety in the late 1990s as the drummer for the all-female punk-pop rock band The Donnas. After a six year break from the group, Castellano's return to the band was marked in 2011 with the release of the album Great Halo. She continued to drum for The Donnas until 2016, when she became a visual artist and focused on her comic book series Dandelion. Her artwork has since been featured in publications such as Juxtapoz and BUST Magazine.

Torry Castellano (born Terri Thomas; February 8, 1977) is an American musician and songwriter, best known as the former drummer of punk band The Donnas, and her current band, The Mrs.. She was born in Los Angeles, California.

Castellano joined The Donnas when she was 14 and played in the band for 20 years until their hiatus in 2012. Throughout her time with the band, Castellano wrote numerous songs and toured relentlessly all over the world. Her playing style was described in the book Waking The Dead by Paul Myers as "hard", "incisive", and "an in-the-pocket powerhouse with little flash but plenty of power".

In 2015, Castellano and her former Donnas bandmate Allison Robertson formed the alternative rock and pop duo The Mrs.. They released their debut album, Here Come The Women, in 2016. Castellano is on drums, guitar and keyboards, and Robertson contributes vocals and guitar.

Torry Castellano (born December 6, 1974) is an American musician, best known as the drummer of the punk rock band The Donnas. Born in Oceanside, California, Castellano co-founded The Donnas alongside Brett Anderson, Allison Robertson and Maya Ford. She has been part of the group since its inception in 1993, playing drums and percussion on all of their releases from the debut album, American Teenage Rock 'n' Roll Machine (1998), up until their final album, Greatest Hits Vol. 16 (2008). In October 2017, Castellano announced her retirement from the band she founded 24 years prior to focus on personal projects.

Torry Castellano (born March 22, 1978) is an American drummer and musician. She is best known as the drummer for the punk band The Donnas, occassionally playing guitar and singing lead vocals for some of their songs.

Castellano was born in Berkeley, California, and grew up in nearby Lafayette. At the age of 8, she began taking drum lessons, and soon afterward joined a student orchestra. Her first major band was Girl, formed with her friends, who went on to become The Donnas. When she was 14, she was selected to tour with a program from Berklee College of Music. 

In 2002, Castellano was forced to leave The Donnas due to health reasons. In the following two years, however, she managed to tour with them occasionally in support of their fourth album, Gold Medal. 

From 2003 to 2005, Castellano played drums in the all-girl AC/DC tribute band called Hell's Belles, who went on tour to Europe and Australia. 

In 2006, Castellano returned to The Donnas as a full-time member

Torry Castellano (born October 30, 1979) is an American musician best known as the longtime drummer of the punk rock band The Donnas. She also fronts her own solo project, The Electrocutes, with vocalist Mia Klein. Castellano began playing drums at the age of 14 and joined The Donnas in 1993, when she was 14 years old. She remained with the band until their split in late 2008. Since then, she has been pursuing her solo project, The Electrocutes, and has toured two solo acoustic tours. She was also the drummer for punk rock group The Little Death from 2007 to 2012.

Torry Castellano (born May 4, 1979) is an American musician. She is best known as the original drummer and a founding member of the all-female rock trio The Donnas, which she co-founded in 1993. She was with the band until their breakup in 2011. Castellano then went on to release her first solo album in 2012, entitled Transverse City. In addition to drumming in The Donnas, she wrote many of the band's songs, including the title track from their 2003 album Spend the Night. Castellano plays drums, bass, guitar, and keyboards, and has been a student of the drums since 1988.

"Torry Castellano (born August 8th, 1977) is an American singer, musician, and songwriter. She was the original drummer and founding member of the punk rock band The Distillers, which disbanded in 2006. Her musical style is characterized by energetic musical riffs and driving drumming. Her songwriting often incorporates personal experience and feeling within her lyrics. Castellano has also been involved in philanthropy, working with various causes such as animal rights and environmental protection."

Torry Castellano (born May 15, 1979) is an American drummer, singer, songwriter, and record producer. She is best known as the drummer for the punk rock band The Distillers from 1998 to 2006 and 2016 to 2019. Castellano has also performed drums on recordings from several other bands, including The Fever and The White Stripes. She released her debut solo album, Daisy Visions Revisited, in April 2017. Castellano has also gone on to become a Grammy Award-nominated producer and mixer.

Torry Castellano (born April 19, 1974) is an American musician, most noted for being the original drummer and co-founder of the all-female punk rock group The Donnas. She attended Humboldt State University in Arcata, California, and originally joined the band, who at the time were going by the name Ragady Anne, in 1993. The band went on to release the album American Teenage Rock 'n' Roll Machine (1994), several albums on Lookout! Records, and seven studio albums with major label imprint Atlantic Records. Castellano was a longtime supporter of non-profit organizations Girls Rock Camp and Rock N' Roll Camp for Girls, and appeared in the 2005 documentary film about the non-profits, Girls Rock!. She also appeared in the 2003 video game Karaoke Revolution Party. Castellano left the Donnas in 2002 due to tendinitis in her hands. She was replaced by former Muffs and Raveonettes drummer, Manu Meyer. Castellano currently lives in Los Angeles, California and continues to be involved with music.

Torry Castellano (born 1969) is an American musician, best known for her time as the drummer for punk rock band The Donnas. She was born Italy, as her American parents were stationed there; they later returned to the United States and settled in California. After finding success in music with The Donnas, Torry left the band in 2002 to pursue other interests. She returned to school to study at the Pacifica Graduate Institute, earning an MA in Clinical Psychology. She currently works in the field of psychotherapy and private music instruction. Castellano also recently released a solo album, blending piano, guitar and vocals.

Torry Castellano (born November 15, 1975) is an American musician, best known as the original drummer and a founding member of the all-female punk/alternative rock band, The Donnas. Formed in Palo Alto in 1993, while they were members of the same high school, the group has released a total of seven full-length albums and one EP. Castellano was their drummer until their split in 2003.

Castellano is an animal welfare advocate and runs the non-profit organization Animal Rescue Media Education. It produces public service announcements, digital media and short films which focus on promoting animal rights and welfare. In 2012 Castellano participated in a series of animal rights benefit concerts. She is also the founder of the Los Angeles based animal rescue project The Compassionate Action Network.

Torry Castellano (born August 8, 1980) is an American musician, best known as the drummer of punk rock band The Donnas. She is also the former drummer of the Los Angeles-based alternative rock band Riddle of Steel.

Castellano was born in Agoura Hills, California. At 17, she joined the Donnas and moved to Palo Alto, California to attend college at Stanford University. She is of Italian heritage; her father was a professional soccer player and her mother is a retired classroom teacher. Castellano completed her degree in 2002, and the Donnas subsequently released "Spend the Night" in 2003. 

In 2006, Castellano left the Donnas to focus on her degree at Stanford and as of 2010 she is working on her master's degree. She currently lives in Los Angeles.

Torry Castellano (born May 22, 1978) is an American musician best known as the founding drummer and songwriter for the punk rock band, The Donnas. Castellano was the longest-standing member of the band as they recorded seven albums over eight years before she left in 2002.

Castellano started playing drums at age 11, and played in local punk bands including Frightwig and Beehive. She attended the University of California at Santa Cruz from 1997–99 and majored in Music Composition. During her university years she continued playing in Frightwig, and she would busk in nearby Santa Cruz with an acoustic guitar for fun.

She is also known for her artwork, both photo-based and pencil-drawn. Castellano illustrated all the Donnas' albums and singles covers, as well as a number of other musical and non-musical projects including album artwork for The Eyeliners and The Stitches. She also helped design the shirts and more of the merchandise for The Donnas.

Torry Castellano (born December 14, 1975) is an American musician best known as the drummer of punk band The Distillers. She is also the drummer of rock bands The Tragic Thrills and Dreamcar.

Castellano has gained recognition for her style of drumming characterized by bold, aggressive playing. She credits her heavy hitting style to her background in heavy metal and punk. She has cited cowpunk act The Long Ryders and prog rockers Yes as major influences, later also drawing influence from jazz, classical, and Latin music. She is known for pushing the envelope of punk drumming, bringing in clever accents, rock steady grooves, and try-anything-once compositional palettes.

Torry Castellano (born Victoria Ann Castellano; August 8, 1977 – March 27, 2015) was an American musician best known for being the drummer for the punk rock band The Donnas. She was born in South Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, and raised in Mission Viejo, California. Castellano started playing the drums at age 13, after playing the violin and singing in the church choir. Her parents bought her her first drum kit when she was 14.

Castellano initially gained fame with The Donnas in the San Francisco Bay area punk rock scene before the band achieved greater success, supporting bands such as Green Day and Sum 41. After signing to Lookout! Records and releasing the band's major label debut, Spend the Night (2002), the group attained mainstream success. Castellano featured on all five studio albums and many of the band's singles, touring with them across the world.

"Tori Castellano (born April 17,1993) is an American musician from Florida, best known as the former drummer and co-lead vocalist for the punk rock band The Donnas. She joined The Donnas in 1999 when she was 16, after answering an ad placed by founding members Donna C (Bass/Lead Vocals) and Donna R (Guitar/Background Vocals) for a drummer. After recording the first album, Tori went on to become an official member of the group. Castellano provided drumming and vocal performances on the band's recorded material and toured with the Donnas until they announced they were going on hiatus in 2009. She is currently a member of the Los Angeles-based band Tres Bien."

Torry Castellano (born January 10, 1976 in Newport Beach, California) is an American drummer, former member of punk rock band The Donnas, and current music producer, songwriter and instructor. She began her musical career playing drums in the all-girl quartet, The Donnas, in 1993. Creating five albums, touring both nationally and internationally, which included a slot on the Vans Warped Tour, the band broke up in 2003. Since then, Castellano has worked as an artist/producer, engineer and writer. In November 2019 she released her first solo album, Meet Torry Castellano.

Torry Castellano (born December 6, 1972) is an American musician. She is best known as the drummer for the punk rock group The Donnas from 1993 until 2004. 

She began her drumming career at age 19, playing in hardcore punk bands in the California Bay Area, most notably in Tilt. In 1993, Castellano joined The Donnas, and played on all the band's albums until 2004. During her time in The Donnas, the band released eight full-length albums, among them top 40 hits "Spend the Night" and "Take It Off". After departing The Donnas in 2004, Castellano started a new band, The Lashes. The band released their first EP, "The Lashes EP", on January 10, 2006. 

Castellano has remained active as a professional drummer and songwriter, contributing to albums by The Faint, The Shys, Brady Watt, The Boss Martians, Plain Jane Automobile, and Vedera. She also works as a clinician for pearl drums.

Torry Castellano (b. August 28, 1978) is an American musician and producer. She is the former drummer of the American punk rock band The Distillers, and was later a member of the rock band The Drama Club. She is currently a part-time studio and live drummer and music producer.

Castellano was born in San Pedro, California, and began playing drums at the age of three. She was part of an all-female punk-rock band called Sourpuss before joining The Distillers in April 1998. She was a driving force for the band, playing drums on their first two albums and co-writing some of their songs.

Castellano departed from The Distillers in 2005 to form the rock band The Drama Club. She wrote and produced two EPs with them before leaving the band in 2006 to focus on production and studio playing. She has since been in and out of various rock bands such as The Iron Saints and The Dollyrots, and is also an active freelance session drummer, playing drums on various recording sessions. In 2015, Castellano founded Fort Flipside,

Albert I, Margrave of Meissen (c. 1170 – 5 June 1260), also known as Albert the Bear, was the first Ascanian margrave of Meissen from 1195 and first margrave of Brandenburg from 1212. He was the son of Otto I, Count of Ballenstedt, and Eilika, daughter of Magnus Billung, Duke of Saxony.

Albert was probably born around 1170. Before his accession, Albert had already gained some experience in maritime trade, which was to become an important part of his Margraviate of Brandenburg. Soon after his appointment to the Meissen margraviate in 1195, he and his brother began a period of enlarging the margraviate and turning it into the Ascanian state which would later become one of the powerful and populous electorships of the Holy Roman Empire. Albert worked carefully to expand and extend his control. By 1209, he had greater control over the entire March of Brandenburg and German east of the Elbe River. He successfully competed against the powerful ancient nobility of the Milz

Albert I, Margrave of Meissen (c. 1200 – 24 December 1260) was a member of the House of Wettin. He was margrave of Meissen from 1229 until his death.

Albert was the son of Theodoric I, Margrave of Meissen and of Hedwig, daughter of the Ascanian prince Bernhard I, Margrave of Anhalt. He succeeded his father in 1227, and was then called "the young margrave" so as to distinguish him from his cousin Albert II, Margrave of Brandenburg. 

Albert extended his father's work in consolidating the borders of his margraviate and strengthening the imperial authority in Meissen.

He created two settlements along the border – Wermsdorf and Lommatzsch – so as to strengthen the customs posts and when necessary, to repel attack. The latter is today a part of the district of Mittelsachsen. In 1235, Albert founded the city of Dresden.

Albert the Bold (German: Albrecht der Starke; c. 1100 – 19 March 1170), a member of the House of Wettin, was Margrave of Meissen from 1138 until his death. He was nicknamed because of his martial exploits.

Albert was the second son of Duke Conrad of Thuringia, and Adelaide of Weimar-Orlamünde. He was born about 1100 and probably grew up in Coburg at the court of his uncle, King Henry IV of Germany. In 1125, with his brother Theodoric I the leadership of his father's estate was shared between them.

He is first documented as a margrave in 1138, when he appears as a witness in a document of the margrave of Lusatia (Lausitz). In 1142 he obtained the Vogt rights in Groitzsch and Bannewitz near Meissen. In 1143 he was named Margrave of Meissen. Albert I, Margrave of Meissen (1414 – 11 June 1486) was a Wettin ruler of Meissen, Landgrave of Thuringia, Count Palatine of Saxony, and Elector of Saxony. He is sometimes known as Albert the Degenerate, though this epithet is principally meant to denote his lack of military success against the Hussites of Bohemia. Albert was born the third son on 4 May 1414 at Meissen, to Frederick II, Elector of Saxony and Margaret of Austria, daughter of Ernest, Duke of Austria. He succeeded his father as elector in 1428, although under the guardianship of his cousin, Frederick I, Elector of Brandenburg, as he was still a minor. During his minority, the regency was in the hands of his cousin Landgrave William II of Hesse. Albert took an active part in public affairs as soon as his majority was declared and for some years, at the expense of his electors, he maintained a standing army by which he cleared his country of robbers and restored order in the Landgrav

"Albert I, Margrave of Meissen (or Albert the Brave; c. 1240–1314) was the first Wettin margrave of the march of Meissen from 1260 to 1294 and the eldest son of Theodoric I, Margrave of Meissen. He was an important ally of King Ottokar II of Bohemia and aided him in his wars against King Rudolf I of Germany. Albert notably fought against his cousin Henry III, Margrave of Lower Lusatia at the 1282 Battle of Lucka, and in 1285 he won the Battle of Landsberg against Rudolf's son King Albert I of Germany. Albert acquired the important trading town of Gorlitz in 1265 and was chosen to administer affairs in the Thuringian area of Pleissnerland in 1290. He also supported the crusading Teutonic Order and from 1278 held the title of patron of the House of Wettin.

Albert I, Margrave of Meissen (also known as Albert the Bear) (1124 – 1170) was the first Margrave of Meissen from the House of Ascania, a dynasty of German rulers in the area of Saxony. Albert was born in 1124, the second son of Otto, Count of Ballenstedt, from the House of Ascania, and Eilika, daughter of the Piast duke, Bolesław III of Poland. He is known for his military prowess and successful campaigns against the Wends, Brunonians, and other pagan tribes inhabiting the margraviate of Brandenburg and the adjacent territories. He defeated a coalition of the Polabian tribes in 1150 and defeated them again in 1164 when they revolted. He also annexed a number of their territories, including Friesack, Lücore and Tannsin, in what is now east-central Germany. Albert established many coastal cities and towns along the Baltic coast, including Rostock, Wismar and Stralsund. He also promoted the construction of churches,

Albert I or Albrecht I, the Bold (c. 1240/45 – 9 April 1307) was the Margrave of Meissen from 1285 until his death. Son of Dietrich I, Margrave of Meissen, he is honored as a hero in German history and remembered as a prominent military leader and founder of some of Berlin's most important landmarks.

Born at the castle of Scharfenberg, Albert was sent to the court of Landgrave Hermann I of Thuringia and entered his service at an early age. After taking part in the battles of Woippy (1282) and Thionville (1286), he was empowered to govern Meissen, when his father died on 12 May 1285. In 1290, he received the margraviate of Landsberg and Geldern and in 1292 was invested with the county of Brehna (now part of Saxony-Anhalt), which he exchanged a few years later for Holstein, on the right bank of the Elbe.
