Albert I, Margrave of Meissen (c.1260 – 4 July 1323), a member of the House of Wettin, was the Margrave of Meissen from 1285 until his death. Albert was the eldest son of Conrad II, Margrave of Meissen, and Mathilde of Bavaria. Through his mother, Albert was a member of the Wittelsbach dynasty.

In 1282, Albert's father, Conrad II, was appointed Landgrave of Thuringia. Upon his father's death in 1286, Albert became the Margrave of Meissen and was formally invested with the Margraviate at Plauen on 8 October 1288. Albert died in 1323, leaving the Margraviate of Meissen to his son Frederick. Despite the numerous efforts of Albert's mother Mathilde and his brother Henry, Meissen was divided amongst the five sons of Albert.

Albert I, Margrave of Meissen (German: Albrecht I., Markgraf von Meißen; c. 1070 – 22 March 1138) was a member of the House of Wettin and was Margrave of Meissen from 1127 until his death.

Albert was the eldest son of Otto I the Rich, Margrave of Meissen, by his wife Hedwig of Brandenburg, a daughter of Margrave Albert the Bear. He succeeded his father in 1127 and was followed by his brothers Henry and Theodoric as margraves of Meissen.

Albert I accompanied Henry the Proud, Duke of Bavaria and Saxony, on his campaign against the Slavic Vandals in 1127. Albert was next in line to succeed him in the duchy of Saxony but was outstripped by Lothair of Supplinburg in 1137.

In 1135 he founded the collegial church of the Holy Cross in Nimbschen near Grimma in Saxony, endowing it with generous privileges. The presence of a provost and

Albert I, Margrave of Meissen (died 1260) was a member of the House of Wettin and Margrave of Meissen from 1220 until his death. He was the eldest surviving son of Herman I, Margrave of Meissen and member of the Wettin dynasty.

Albert I succeeded his father as Margrave of Meissen in 1220 and ruled until his death in 1260. He was a respected ruler, who intended to bring peace, stability and prosperity to Meissen. He was able to maintain good relations with neighbouring rulers, such as the kings of Bohemia, Poland and Hungary. As a result, his land was able to keep out of the conflicts between these rulers. He was however struggling to keep Saxony united which was resisted by the local nobility.

Albert I was an ambitious builder and left many architectural works in Meissen, as well as in other parts of Germany including Magdeburg, Würzburg, Bamberg, and Leipzig. He was also involved in several charitable works, including the founding of a hospital for

Albert I (1240–1319), sometimes known as the "Hawk of Meissen", was the Margrave of Meissen, a member of the House of Wettin, from 1260 until his death in 1319. A skilful military commander, Albert successfully defended Meissen, an Imperial state in the Holy Roman Empire, against external enemies, as well as maintained order within the margraviate. He was a venerable figure in German history: he dealt with European leaders of his time, such as Edward I of England and Philip the Fair, and exerted influence within the Holy Roman Empire. He also held numerous imperial offices during the Interregnum period when the German crown was vacant. Albert is also remembered for his establishment of the Meissen pipe and bell foundry, which he had built in 1279 and ran until his death in 1319. This foundry marked the beginnings of the city’s craft-based economy, which had immense significance for the development of Meissen and the rise of the region of Saxony.

Albert I the Proud (c. 1280 - 13 April 1338), was Margrave of Meissen from 1307 until his death. He was the eldest son of Frederick III, Margrave of Meissen and Isabella of Cornwall, daughter of John, Earl of Humphrey de Bohun, Earl of Hereford and Constable of England.

Albert is best remembered as the founder of Meissen as a cultural centre. He invited German authors, composers and musicians to the city, and his court became one of the most important cultural centres of the German Middle Ages. He had a famous pilgrimage church erected in the local and national Romanesque style. Albert also maintained close contacts with the cities of the Hanseatic League and was in 1312 elected an Imperial Prince by the Holy Roman Emperor Henry VII. He received the title of Fürst von Meißen ("Prince of Meissen") in 1329 and in 1336, on his visit at the Diet of Nuremberg, he was proclaimed as the hereditary Duke of Saxony.

Albert I, Margrave of Meissen (German: Albrecht der Bär, Polish: Albert I Mściwój, Czech: Albert Míšeňský), nicknamed the Bear (c. 1165–13. October 1260), was the Margrave of Meissen from 1221 until his death, from 1242 Margrave of Landsberg. Albert was the eldest son of Otto I, Margrave of Meissen and Eilika of Silesia-Liegnitz.

Albert's first marriage was to Luitgard, daughter of Herman I, Landgrave of Thuringia. Her dowry was the castle at Eckartsberga and district at Hainichen. After her death he married 1232 Sophie of Winzenburg. She died in 1242 and left him a son, Henry the Illustrious.

Albert was an accomplished military leader and feudal lord. He maintained close contacts with the kings of Bohemia and Poland, and supported their expansionary policies in Lusatia. He was an ally of Frederick II, Duke

Albert I, Margrave of Meissen (c. 1220 – 11 July 1260), was a German nobleman. He was a member of the House of Wettin. He was the eldest son of Dietrich I, Margrave of Meissen and his wife Mathilde of Oldenburg. Albert I became Margrave of Meissen in 1222, upon the death of his father. He was an ally of the Hohenstaufen emperor, Frederick II, and one of Wenceslaus I of Bohemia's strongest opponents during the years 1236 and 1237. During his lifetime, Albert enlarged the territory of Meissen considerably, with acquisitions which include Meissen, Groitzsch and Bautzen. He also attempted to reclaim the Polish domains of his grandmother, Hedwig of Silesia. He died without issue in 1260 and was followed by his brother, Dietrich II.

Albert the Bold or Albert I (also called Albert the Great; German: Albrecht der Große; 1240 – 13 November 1314) was the first and most prominent Margrave of Meissen from about 1260, when the margraviate was elevated as an imperial state of the Holy Roman Empire. He was a member of the House of Wettin. Albert was the son of Henry III, Margrave of Meissen, and Constantia of Austria.

Albert was a diversely educated, prudent and industrious ruler who gained the esteem of the Holy Roman Emperor Rudolph I. As ruler, he often had to cope with floods of the Elbe River, invasions of pagan tribes from beyond the Albrecht Kaiserpfalz at Torgau (1271/72) and quarrels with his brothers, the Margraves John I and Otto III of Brandenburg among them. Nevertheless, Albert proved his intervention in foreign affairs of the Empire ("imperial politics") and became one of the most important Prince-electors of the Holy Roman Empire by the vast territories and enormous political power

Albert I (c. 1240 – 6 June 1308) was Margrave of Meissen from 1260 until his death. He was the son of Theodoric I, Margrave of Meissen, and Sophie of Thuringia.

Albert I was one of the most significant princes of his time in Germany. During his long reign of almost fifty years, he had succeeded in bringing about a balance of powers in the region of Central Germany through his construction of numerous castles, development of cities and strategic military alliances. He held semi-regal power as a leader in the German states of the Holy Roman Empire.

Albert I forged an alliance with the Bohemian King Ottokar II by arranging the marriage of his own son Henry with the king's daughter Konstancja. This match secured him great influence in both Silesia and Greater Poland, and placed Ottokar, his son-in-law and ally, on the Bohemian throne. Albert I, the Bold (German: Albrecht der Fette; Polish: Albert I Gruby; Czech: Albrecht I. Hrozný), Margrave of Meissen, Duke of Saxony, was the fifth son of Frederick II, Margrave of Meissen, and his first wife, Mathilde von Brandenburg-Salzwedel. Albert is famous for establishing and enlarging the territory of the House of Wettin, and for establishing the Albertine line of the House of Wettin, which would in time become the Electors (Kurfürsten, hence the title of elector which was later conferred on Albert) and Kings of Saxony.

Albert was born in 1256 in Halle, the capital of the Meissen margraviate. His mother Mathilde died in 1260, and his father died in 1262. After his father’s death, Albert, then six years old, succeeded his father as Margrave of Meissen and "Heir of the Wettins". He was taken into custody by his

Albert I the Courageous (sometimes spelled Albrecht or Albert) (c. 1168 – 27 April 1260) was a German margrave of Meissen, Landgrave of Thuringia and Count Palatine of Saxony. Albert was a member of the House of Wettin. He was the eldest son of Otto III, Margrave of Meissen and his wife Hedwig of Brandenburg. He was the father of Bernhard III, Margrave of Meissen and Albert II, Margrave of Meissen and thus the ancestor of all later rulers of Meissen.

Albert was a brave and ambitious ruler. He was an energetic and warlike prince, constantly in conflict. He fought until exhaustion against the forces of Henry the Lion, Duke of Saxony, the House of Ascania, the Thuringian nobility and the deputies of his father-in-law Philip of Swabia. From his early years he showed a great aptitude for war and used to go hunting with Falcons, to train his soldiers and to lead them in battle. His most significant victory was

Albert the Bold (German: Albrecht der Starke, Czech: Albrecht Prusodomý, Hungarian: Albert Erős, 1240–1308) was a Margrave of Meissen from the House of Wettin from 1285 until his death. He is also known as Albert the Strong, although it is likely that he gained this epithet not from his physical strength, as he was a sickly person, but because of his determined will power. He was the youngest son of Dietrich, Margrave of Lusatia and Meissen, from the House of Wettin, the same family that later became rulers of Saxony and Poland.

Albert I (c. 1090 – 8 February 1141), called the Brave, was the Margrave of Meissen from 1123 until his death. A member of the House of Wettin, Albert was the son of Theoderic III, Margrave of Meissen and Hedwig of Brandenburg. Albert is renowned for having founded and expanded the city of Dresden, and was known as an energetic and warlike ruler in his times. Albert is credited with having laid the foundations for the German Empire, including the issuance of the Resdlau and the formation of the states army and navy. He was also the first to begin actively minting coins called Marke. He was the grandfather of Albert, Count of Ballenstedt and thus, ancestor of what was to become the House of Ascania.

Freddie Frith (19 October 1924 – 13 March 1981) was an English motorcycle racer and test rider. Born in Sutton Coldfield, Warwickshire, he won three Isle of Man TT races and in 1950 became the first rider to be crowned the Senior TT Champion. He was the first triple-TT winner and the first multiple Isle of Man Senior TT winner. He competed in six Grand Prix, and was also a prolific test rider for a variety of manufacturers, including JAP, Norton, Triumph and AJS until injury forced him to retire in 1956.

Frith scored race wins at the Isle of Man TT, the North West 200, and the Ulster Grand Prix. He competed in the Grand Prix des Nations in 1954, and at the 1956 Isle of Man senior TT he finished second to the world champion, John Surtees. He also competed in the Ulster Grand Prix, winning the 650cc race in 1954. He was the first rider to win three Isle of Man TTs in the same year, in 1950 when he won the Junior and Senior TT races, and in the Ultra-Lightweight 250cc race. He was

Freddie Frith (1916–2010) was a British motorcycle racer. He was Britain's first international motorcycle road racing superstar, winning the Grand Prix World Championship in 1951 and the Isle of Man Senior TT Race in 1953.

Frith began riding trials on a Velocette motorcycle in 1933 and was soon joining other competitions, becoming a member of the Veloce Motorcycle Racing Club and competing in Reliability Trials up to 1939. After the war, he bought a 500cc Ariel Red Hunter with which he competed regularly in ACU Road Races, winning for the first time at the Wood Norton Trophy Meeting in 1946.

Frith was soon making a name for himself in the world of motorcycling, competing in the Isle of Man TT, as well as across Europe and further afield. Frith competed in many national and international events, including the Swiss GP, Spanish GP, Ulster GP and North West 200. In 1951 Frith finally achieved international acclaim and the coveted honor of becoming Grand Prix World Champion. He followed that up with a win at the 1953 Isle of Man Senior TT Race, one of the most prestigious motorcycle road

Freddie Frith (1916–2009) was an English motorcycle racer who became a record-breaking pioneer of post-war endurance racing.

He is remembered for his achievements racing motorcycles in the 1950s and 1960s, when, despite the increased competition from larger, foreign machines, he continued to win in events such as the Thruxton 500 and Isle of Man TT race. He also holds the outright lap record for the old Brooklands circuit and set first-time records for 24 hour, 12 hour, and six-day individual and team distances in the same era.

Frith was also involved in record attempts, notably the 1951 London-Edinburgh-London trial, which was won by Bob Foster with Frith coming second. Frith continued with endurance record attempts, setting the first 150 m.p.h average lap record at Brooklands in 1951, a feat he repeated in 1954. He was involved in the famous London-Land's End race of 1954, when he and his co-rider DerekPickworth completed the distance in a single day.

Freddie Frith (20 November 1911 – 25 April 1973) was a British motorcycle racer who is most remembered for his exploits at the Isle of Man TT races. He won the 350 cc class in 1935 and was the first rider to win the race in all three solo classes – 250 cc, 350 cc and 500 cc.

Frith began his career in trials riding and joined the Norton factory racing team in 1933, racing on a series of small bikes including AJS and Rudge machines. In 1935 he split from Norton to ride for Triumph in the Isle of Man races and went on to win the 350 cc class on a Brough Superior Motorcycle, setting a new lap record of 74.82 mph. Subsequent years saw Frith win races in the 250 cc, 350 cc and 500 cc classes and his second 500 cc victory in 1939 was recorded as the fastest lap on the old Snaefell Mountain Course of 83.68 mph. In 1941 Frith was selected to join the British Auto Cycle Union's International Six – the most prestigious achievement for a motorcyclist of the time.

Freddie Frith (14 March 1912 – 10 December 1976) was an English racing driver and motorcycle racer. He is principally remembered for his racing achievements in motorcycle sidecar racing, in which he achieved numerous wins and International successes, including becoming an eight-time TT winner. He is also remembered for his achievements and successes in car racing, with European Championship and hill climbing successes.

Frith began his racing career in 1928 at the age of 16 by racing motorcycles in Hare & Hounds events, while also competing in various sprints and grass track meetings. He made his debut in the Isle of Man TT in 1930 and went on to win the Sidecar TT race in 1935 and then again in 1938, making him one of the first double winners of the Sidecar event. During the late 1930s, he also won the 1937 and 1938 French Grand Prix sidecar races, and the European Championship in 1938. He also competed in car racing, and had wins in hill climbing with an Austin 7 in 1934 and 1935 and competing in the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1937 with a 13/60 Sunbeam Saloon.

Freddie Frith, Jr., (24 August 1895, London - 19 April 1976, Denham, Buckinghamshire) was an English Grand Prix motorcycle racer, one of the first to compete in what today is known as motorcycle Grand Prix racing. Frith began racing in 1914, and was the first British rider to win a European championship. He was also the first rider in history to win consecutive European Championships, in 1926 and 1927. He was known for his fearless riding style, and was respected and admired by his competitors. In 1927, Frith was invited to compete for the Sunbeam Works Race Team, and in 1928, he took 2nd place in the Olympia Grand Prix, and competed against the likes of Alec Bennett and Stanley Woods.

Frith was inducted in the Motorcycle Hall of Fame in 2004. He was also named one of the best riders of the 20th century.

Freddie Frith (1915-1992) was an English professional motorcycle racer, who competed in grand prix and the Isle of Man TT races from 1934 to 1951. He achieved success in both short and long-distance motorcycle racing. Frith competed in over 200 races during his career, winning 35 and finishing second in 15 in grand prix motorcycle racing, setting lap records as well as two world speed records. In 1950, while competing in the Isle of Man TT, he became the first person to break the 120 mph barrier at the TT, with a top speed of 123.3 mph.

Frith also raced at the prestigious Isle of Man TT during its golden era, achieving success on the island with three victories and over 15 podium finishes. He was crowned the first ever 350cc TT champion after his victory in 1938, before winning the coveted 500cc Senior TT in 1945. Although his number one plate was taken away due to the outbreak of World War II, Frith returned to the TT and won the 500cc race in 1950, as well as breaking the lap record twice and the 120 mph barrier for the first time. Freddie Frith (1931–2012) was an English motorcycle racer and motocross pioneer. He was the first winner of the 500 cc world championship in 1949 on an AJS Porcupine. He also helped to promote motocross in the UK, leading to the creation of the FIM Motocross World Championship in 1957.

Frith's career was curtailed in 1952 by a crash at Silverstone, which resulted in a ban on road racing. The ban effectively forced him to switch to motocross, resulting in a successful career as a motocross rider, during which he dominated the sport in the UK and Europe. His career came to an end in 1960, when he retired during the season and eventually returned to mainland UK in the same year. In his later years, he was actively involved in the British motocross scene, and was a major advocate for the sport. He mentored numerous young riders, paving the way for a new generation of stars. He died in 2012 at age 81.

Freddie Frith (7 April 1910 – 17 December 1992) was an English motorcycle racer and veteran who, at the age of 61, won the 1964 Isle of Man TT. He was the oldest rider to win an Isle of Man TT race, a record which still stands today. He set a record for the fastest lap of the mountain course, a record that stood for over 4 decades. He raced in the top class of the day on a Matchless G50. He was twice a winner at the British Clubman’s championship at Mallory Park. He was the first man to win two BBC Television's 'Man of the Match' awards, won by riders who completed the most laps in the Isle of Man TT. After retiring from racing in 1975, he continued to attend race meetings up until his death, often as a commentator. His impact on the sport and his popularity with the public ensured that motorcycle racing in the United Kingdom had a much higher profile than it would have in his absence.

Freddie Frith (13 May 1913 – 21 August November 1992) was a British motorcycle racer. He was known for establishing records and achievements that still stand in grass-track, speedway, long-distance trials and road racing in the 1930s, 1940s and 1950s. He appeared at Isle of Man TT races on a number of occasions during his career, with a best result of fourth place in the 1935 Senior TT. He was the first person to win five road races in the same day, a feat he achieved in 1951. He was five-time winner of the famous Scottish Six Days Trial and four-time winner of the Scott Trial (including three consecutive wins). He also established records for driving 2,500 miles (4,023 km) in a car in 48 hours, and for riding a race-prepared 350cc Velocette from London to Land's End to John O'Groats, and back again in under 48 hours in 1951.

Frederick Charles Frith (23 March 1903 - 30 June 1976) was an English racing driver, who competed in motor racing from the 1920s to the 1950s. He competed in a number of disciplines, including Grand Prix motor racing, sports car racing, and hillclimbs.

Frith made his debut in 1921, winning the races at both the Brooklands and Donington Park circuits. He collected several victories at both circuits during the 1920s, before moving to more powerful machinery in the 1930s. He won several races in the United Kingdom, then ventured abroad to compete in the Grand Prix races of the European Championship.

In 1938, he won the North West 200 race securing a first-place finish in both the heat races and the combined final. In 1949, Frith competed in his first Le Mans 24 Hour race, where he secured a fifth-place finish. He also contributed to the development of the Bristol 500, a sports car developed by the Bristol Aeroplane Company.

In the 1950s Frith began to concentrate on hillclimbing, eventually becoming a nine-time British Hillclimb Champion.

Freddie Frith (11 August 1898 – 23 October 1973) was an English motorcycle racer. He was one of the most successful motorcycle racers in Grand Prix motorcycle racing history, with 4 Grand Prix World Championships, 5 Isle of Man TT victories and a total of 26 Grand Prix wins. He was inducted into the AMA Motorcycle Hall of Fame in 2000.

Frith began his racing career in 1919, competing at road and speed trail events on a Triumph. He later moved to AJS, dominating the 1925 season by winning eight consecutive 500 cc races, four of which were the then-prestigious Ulster and French Grands Prix. He was crowned the first-ever 500 cc World Champion in the same year.

Frith encountered success in a variety of disciplines, including international long distance events. He won the French Grand Prix three times. Despite having achieved several successes, he retired from racing in 1929 due to deteriorating health. He continued in the sport as a manager and advisor until his death in 1974. In 2000, he was inducted into the AMA Motorcycle Hall of Fame.

Freddie Frith (1897-1953) was an English professional motorcycle racer and a five-time winner of the Isle of Man TT. Born in Whyteleafe, Frith began his racing career in 1921, racing on the well-known Brough Superior in the London-Exeter and London-Land's End Trial. By 1923, he had become one of the leading competitors in trials, grass track, grasstrack and hill climb events, setting numerous records.

Frith gained significant success between 1924 and 1930, winning several races on motorcycles produced by the British firm Douglas. He stepped up to larger machines in 1931, subsequently winning the Lightweight TT aboard a Norton in 1935, the first of five victories in the Isle of Man TT. His other wins included the Senior TT (1937), Junior TT (1938 and 1939) and the Ultra-Lightweight TT (1941). He retired from competitive motorcycle racing in 1946.

Freddie Frith (1906-1987) was an English racing motorcyclist, who won nine Isle of Man TT races and set a number of world speed records. The pinnacle of Frith's career was winning five Isle of Man TT races, six consecutive in a row between 1934 and 1939. He won his first TT in 1934, and went on to win six more - two Senior TTs, three Junior TTs and one Lightweight TT. His final TT win came in 1939 and was his most famous, beating the reigning champion, Stanley Woods, by a single second in a thrilling finish, described by one reporter as “the greatest race ever seen on the mountain course”. He also set many world records, including the first rider to lap the famous Brooklands track in England at over 100 mph (140 km/h). 

After retiring from competition, Frith worked as a motorcycle test rider, technician, and development engineer for Sunbeam Motorcycles and BSA. He died on August 17, 1987, aged 81.

Freddie Frith (12 December 1901 – 3 April 1972) was an English international motorcycle racer and speedway rider who won thirteen world speedway championship races. He was one of Britain's most successful and pioneering motorcycle racers of all time.

Frith was born in 1901 in the village of Lucan, near London. He began riding motorcycles after his father bought him a 1912 Triumph Model H in 1920, and he soon developed a passion for the sport. In 1926, he won the Junior Tourist Trophy to become the world's amateur motorcycle racing champion.

Frith competed in multiple types of racing and won several prestigious events, including the 1931 Belgian Grand Prix and the 1932 Ulster Grand Prix. He was also the first four-time international champion (1933–1936). Even after his racing career began to slow down in the 1940s, Frith remained competitive and in 1949 he won the Sanremo Grand Prix with a Norton.

Frith is also remembered for his pioneering spirit and competitive spirit. He was a co-founder of the International Six Days Trial, a cross-country motorcycle riding competition, and he was one

Freddie Frith MBE (25 April 1908 – 6 April 1985) was an English motorcycle racer, film actor and stuntman.

Frith was born in Poplar, London and started racing in 1929, winning many trophies and awards. He moved to the TT Races on the Isle of Man, where he became the first rider to average over 100 mph on the event's Mountain Course in 1935. He competed in 18 Isle of Man TT races over 17 years, with a highest finish of eighth in 1951. His last TT race was the 1961 Senior race, when at the age of 53 he finished 21st.

He gained the nickname "Fast Freddie" and also became known for his slightly reckless style of riding, although he rarely crashed during his career. He went on to become a well-known stuntman in Films and television, appearing in such classics as Chitty Chitty Bang Bang and Take Me High. He was awarded an MBE in 1972 for services to motorcycling. He was inducted into the A.M.A. Motorcycle Hall of Fame in 2006.

Frederick William "Freddie" Frith (14 June 1911 – 10 January 1998) was an English racing driver from England. He competed in rallies, hill climbs, and Grands Prix. He was widely acclaimed as the most successful pre-war English racing driver.

Frith was born in London in 1911. He was the eldest of seven children and showed a natural aptitude for motor sport from an early age. His early racing career included hill climbs and races at Brooklands, initially driving Verdens and Kissel racers, and from 1927 a variety of other cars, including a Bugatti T35C. During the 1930s he achieved increasing success in major rallies and the more serious forms of motor sport. He competed in the Monte Carlo Rally several times, achieving second place in 1931. He also participated in the Mille Miglia in 1931 and 1932.

In 1936, he competed in his first race at the Nürburgring, where he won in a Mercedes-Benz W25B. In 1938, he competed in a Béchamel SS100 at Shelsley Walsh. He was the outright winner of the

Freddie Frith (born Frederick William Frith, 24 November 1907 – 28 November 1982) was an English racing driver, photographer and endurance record breaker. He was popularly known by his nickname "Fast Freddie" and credited with some of the most impressive performances in the motor racing of his time.

Frith's interest in racing began at Brooklands and he competed in over 500 events across Europe, winning 28 in motor racing, 13 in motorcycle racing and one in aircraft racing. He gained a reputation for setting some of the world's longest endurance records and won the 1936 Tourist Trophy. His most notable achievement was winning the 1939 Brooklands 500 race, and he also finished second in the 1935 Le Mans 24-hour race. His driving career ended following a serious crash at the 1940 Dutch Grand Prix that left him with severe facial disfigurement and limited hearing. Later he pursued a career as a photographer and wrote several books. He was inducted into the Motor Sport Hall of Fame in 2003.

Freddie Frith (17 November 1881 – 20 April 1954) was an English motorcycle racer and car racer, best remembered as the first winner of the first Isle of Man TT race in 1907.

Born in North Feckenham, Warwickshire, Frith began his motorcycling career riding motorcycles in races such as the Twin Cylinder Club race. He became one of the leading riders in the period and enjoyed racing cars, embarking on a successful career in motorsport which included a win in the first ever motorcycle TT race in 1907.

Frith held numerous other records throughout the years and was widely considered to be one of the best and most successful motorcyclists of the time. He raced in the Isle of Man in other major events such as the Junior TT, Lightweight TT and Senior TT, claiming numerous podium finishes, fastest laps and lap records. Frith was also successful on the two-wheeled hill climbs.

Frith continued to participate in motorsport events until an accident at Brooklands in 1930. He passed away in Surrey in 1954, having had a long and successful career.

Freddie Frith was an English motorcycle road racer and trials competitor. He was born in Alfreton, Derbyshire, on 25 August 1923 and died on 26 October 1987. He rode for the Matchless, AJS and Norton motorcycle companies.

Frith established himself with a series of wins at club-level events in the mid-1940s, and began to attract attention from the Conservative government of the day. He was noted for his aggressive, daring riding style and was often called the "King of Grass Track" for his exploits in grass track races. A photograph of him performing a wheelie at Brands Hatch in 1947 has become iconic. In 1950, Frith won the East Midlands Trophy Race and completed his first full season of road racing. He finished as the runner-up in the 1950 and 1951 world championship seasons, and won the TT Races at Silverstone and on the Isle of Man. He also scored numerous wins in the British and World championship series.

In the early 1960s Frith started to move away from road racing and began to focus on trials instead. During this time he won the Scottish Six days Trial

Her fiction has been nominated for a Nebula Award and has twice won the James Tiptree Jr. Award. Her novel A Woman of the Iron People won the Mythopoeic Award.

Eleanor Arnason (born 1942) is an American science fiction and fantasy writer. She is best known for her pivotal contributions to feminist science fiction and her Astrid Johnstone Cycle, spanning five books.

Arnason was born and raised in Minnesota. She attended the University of Minnesota, first studying psychology and then creative writing. It was here she published her first short story, 1981's "The Schennen Touch", in the Minnesota Quarterly. She later went on to obtain a master’s degree in library science from Rutgers University and a bachelor of arts in English literature from University of California, Berkeley.

Arnason was a founding member of Feminists for Animal Rights and is a prominent member of the feminist science fiction community. In 1996, she earned the James Tiptree Jr. Award for her novel, Ring of Swords.

In 2020, Arnason was the recipient of the Robert A. Heinlein Award for a lifetime of improving the awareness of the human condition through works of science fiction and fantasy.

Eleanor Arnason (born 1942) is an American science fiction and fantasy author. She is the author of several books, including Ring of Swords (1993); Large Number (2015), a collection of short stories; andA Woman of the Iron People (1991), which won the James Tiptree Jr. Award in 1992. She has also won the Philip K. Dick Award twice and has been nominated for the Hugo and Nebula Awards.

Her work often combines science fiction and fantasy elements with feminist themes, exploring gender roles, sexuality and the relationships between people, animals, plants and mountains. Her writing has been compared to that of Ursula K. Le Guin and Joanna Russ, two well-known authors of feminist science fiction. Arnason's stories often emphasize the importance of family and community.

Eleanor Arnason (born September 8, 1942 in St. Paul, Minnesota) is an American science fiction writer. Her works often feature feminist themes and explorations of sociological and anthropological issues. They often spotlight characters who confront and overcome prejudice and injustice. Though her works span a broad range of genres, she is best known for writing stories focused on the Hwarhath aliens, a complex and ambiguous species first featured in her novel A Woman of the Iron People (1991). The two sequels are Ring of Swords (1993) and Mama's Boys (1998). She also wrote the novels The Silent Strength of Stones (1995) and Theaban Exile (1995). Her short stories have appeared in numerous anthologies and magazines. Arnason is a recipient of the James Tiptree, Jr Award and the Pilgrim Award.

Eleanor Arnason (born 1942) is an American science fiction writer. She is best known for the Hwarhath science fiction series: A Woman of the Iron People (Ace, 1991), Ring of Swords (Ace, 1993), and Daughter of the Bear King (Ace, 1998). She writes both traditional science fiction and fantasy. Her novels and stories deal with themes of gender and sexuality, and Arnason often includes strong female protagonists in her works. She has been published in major science fiction magazines such as Asimov's, Strange Horizons, and The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction. Her work has received numerous awards, including one Nebula Award and two World Fantasy Awards.

Eleanor Arnason (born 1942) is an American science fiction and fantasy writer. She has published six novels, one collection of stories, and many short stories. Her work is notable for its exploration of gender roles, Native American cultures, and biological themes.

Arnason began her career in the late 1960s, publishing stories in Analog and other magazines. Her first novel, A Friend of the Great World, was published in 1989. It is set in an alternate history with a matriarchal Native American culture. Her 1991 novel, Ring of Swords, utilizes science fiction and fantasy elements to explore women's roles in a world of conflict between advanced societies. Hidden Guirdian (1998) is set in the same universe as the novel and explores sexual politics through the story of a woman of mixed race who changes sexes as she ages.

Eleanor Arnason (born 1942) is an American science fiction and fantasy writer. Her best-known works include the feminist science fiction A Wave in the Mind and Ring of Swords, a novel set in the Hwarhath universe. Arnason also wrote Daughters of Earth, A Storyteller's Tale, and Wide Awake. Much of her writing is identified with the subgenre of feminist science fiction, and Arnason has won Nebula and James Tiptree, Jr. Awards for her work. In 2013, she was a Pilgrim Award Winner from the Science Fiction research Association.

Arnason has written in a variety of genres, including fantasy, science fiction, and mythic fiction, often bringing mythic elements together to form new stories. As a feminist writer, Arnason makes use of archetypal myth and stories about women, often using the mythic tropes of fairy tales as a part of her narrative structure. Eleanor Arnason (born 1941) is an American science fiction and fantasy writer. She is best known for her novel A Woman of the Iron People (Ace Books, 1991) and its sequel, Ring of Swords (Ace, 1993). In 2003 she won the James Tiptree, Jr. Award for her novel, Giant Thief. Set in a far-future version of Earth, the novel is a combination of science fiction, fantasy, and mystery. Her novelette “Boobs” (2004) won the Theodore Sturgeon Memorial Award. She has had stories published in a variety of venues, including Asimov's Science Fiction, the Magazine of Fantasy & Science Fiction, Interzone, and Subtle Edens, an anthology of surrealistic sf stories edited by Peter S. Beagle and Joe R. Lansdale. Her collections of stories include Hunting the Ghost Dancer, Labyrinth of Night, and Mother Aegypt and Other Stories. Her work has been translated into a number of languages, including German, French and Dutch.

Eleanor Arnason (born November 8, 1942) is a science fiction and fantasy author. She was born in Minneapolis and grew up in Minnesota and California. She attended Radcliffe College and graduated with a degree in English literature. Her first published story was in 1975, and she has since published seven novels and more than twenty short stories. She is best known for her science fiction novel, A Woman of the Iron People, which was a finalist for both the Nebula Award and the James Tiptree, Jr. Award. Among her other works are Ring of Swords, The Foreteller, and The Moon Spear. Her work often focuses on Latinx/Chicana and Native American characters, and she frequently includes themes of gender and environmental issues.

Eleanor Arnason (born 1942) is a science fiction and fantasy writer who has published nine novels and more than sixty short stories since her first story appeared in 1976. Her work combines elements of traditional North American and European mythology, science, and feminism. She has won numerous awards for her short stories including the Hugo, Nebula, and American Book Awards. Her novels are mainly set in alternate history versions of the Earth, such as in her A Woman of the Iron People, which looks at the impact of advanced technologies on a primitive society. She also often explores the relationships between humans, machines, and aliens in her fiction. Her novels and stories often focus on contemporary themes and environmental issues while still having an element of fantasy or science fiction.

Eleanor Arnason (born 1942) is an American science fiction and fantasy author. Her work often features strong female protagonists and themes of gender, ethnicity, and culture. Her first novel, A Woman of the Iron People (1991), won the James Tiptree, Jr. Award and both the Mythopoeic and Lambda Literary Awards. Her most recent novel is Ring of Swords (Ace Books, 2013). She has also published two collections of short stories. Her stories have appeared in The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction, Asimov's, Aboriginal SF, and other venues. She is currently working on a novel about Mormon sailors who navigate the stars.

Eleanor Arnason (born 16 October 1942) is an American science fiction and fantasy writer. She is best known for her works set in the Hwarhath universe, Aliens and Others (1982) and Ring of Swords (1993). Her other works include two genre-mixing novels, A Woman of the Iron People (1991) and Mama Day (1988), as well as several of short stories and novellas.

Arnason began writing while a student at Minnesota State University Moorhead, where she graduated with a BA in English in 1968. She obtained a PhD in American Studies in 1975, studying at the University of Minnesota, and taught at various colleges in Minnesota. Since 1988 she has been a librarian at Minneapolis' Hennepin County. Her works are frequently honored for their depth of character development and quality of prose, with A Woman of the Iron People receiving the LOCUS Award for best science fiction novel of 1991. In addition, she won the Tiptree Award twice, in 1996 for her short story "A Friend of the Family," and in 2000 for her novel Ring of Swords.

Eleanor Arnason (born August 9, 1942) is an American science fiction writer. She is best known for her novels A Woman of the Iron People and Ring of Swords, and her short story "A Visit to the Head and Other Histories". Her fiction often focuses on themes of gender and sexuality, and often deals with feminist themes such as female agency and the use of traditional women's skills to confront difficult and complex problems. Others of her works have focused on Native American mythology and themes of ecofeminism. Her fiction has been nominated for the Philip K. Dick Award, James Tiptree, Jr. Award, BSFA Award and Nebula Awards.

Eleanor Arnason (born February 8, 1942) is an American science fiction and fantasy writer. She has published nine novels, three collections and thirty-five short stories.

Arnason's work is known for its engagement with myth and cultural theory, often using themes of feminism and indigenous people in her works. Her best-known novel is Ring of Swords (1993), a Planetary Romance set in a post-apocalyptic world inhabited by diverse races. Many of her works feature strong female characters and explore themes of gentleness, reverence and power. She won the James Tiptree Jr. Award for her novel A Woman of the Iron People (1991), and the distinguished Campbell Award for her novel The Sword Smith (1998).

Eleanor Arnason (born December 1, 1942) is an American science fiction writer. She received the Tiptree Award in 2002 and is best known for her novel A Woman of the Iron People (1991). She has also published several short story collections. Her works often explore themes of native American and gender issues. Arnason's works also include elements of post-modernism and draw from ecology, anthropology, and biology. She has been praised for her powerful and eye-opening feminist writing.

Eleanor Arnason (born November 9, 1942) is an American science fiction writer, best known for her fantasy and feminist stories. Her works often feature strong female protagonists and explore gender roles, Native American and Scandinavian folklore, and the relationship between anthropomorphic animals and humans. Arnason was born in Minnesota and studied literature in college. She has lived in Minneapolis and on the East Coast, though she currently resides in the Twin Cities. She is an alumna of the Clarion Writers Workshop and has taught classes in Creative Writing and Library Work. Arnason is a member of the Minnesota Science Fiction Society. Her work has been published in various anthologies and magazines including The Magazine of Fantasy & Science Fiction, Asimov's Science Fiction, and Strange Horizons, and has also appeared in numerous anthologies.
