Eleanor Arnason (born October 10, 1942) is an American science fiction, fantasy fiction, and historical fiction writer. She published her first story in 1974, and was a finalist for the Hugo Award and Nebula Awards for her 1989 novel A Woman of the Iron People. Her novelette “Six Hours to Live” won the Asimov’s Reader's Choice Award for best novelette for 2000. She was awarded the Mary Kay Bunting Award for her 2000 science fiction novel Ring of Swords. Her works have won multiple awards and has been reprinted in a number of year’s best anthologies. She has lived in Minneapolis, Minnesota, since the early 1970s.

Eleanor Arnason (born 1941) is an American science fiction writer. She is best known for her novel A Woman of the Iron People, which won the James Tiptree Jr. Award, and her stories set in the "Hwarhath" series about an intelligent alien species. Her work often features themes of gender identity, as well as exploration of complex societies. Arnason is known for combining elements of fantasy and science fiction, with influences from Native American culture, in her works. Her short fiction has been collected in Ring of Swords, and she has published a short story cycle, Big Mama Stories. She has also written books for young readers, including To Be Left Behind and The Whatever Witch.

Eleanor Arnason (born August 11, 1942) is an American science fiction author. She has published over a dozen books, and her short stories have appeared in major SF magazines and anthologies. She is known for her works that feature gender, culture and gender roles, and feminist themes. She is the recipient of two Hugo Award nominations, four Nebula Award nominations, and five James Tiptree Jr. Award Honor List selections. She has also been an occasional teacher at the Clarion Writing Workshop. Arnason began publishing short science fiction in 1986, and her first novel, Ring of Swords, was published in 1993. Her works have been translated into Spanish, French, German, Russian and Finnish.

Eleanor Arnason (born October 28, 1942) is an American author of speculative fiction. She is best known for her science fiction novel A Woman of the Iron People (1991), which was a finalist for both the James Tiptree, Jr. Award and the Philip K. Dick Award. She also received Nebula Award nominations for her stories "Dapple" (1989) and "Ring of Swords" (1993).

Arnason's works often feature feminist themes, as well as highlighting ecological issues. They usually include aliens whose societies are very different from our own, as well as exploring the intersection between posthumanism and human traditions. She is an active member of the feminist science fiction community. She was the guest of honor at Wiscon in 2002 and has written a number of Books of Honor essays for the convention.
22:
Rod Morgenstein (born January 24, 1954) is an American rock and jazz drummer and founding member of the Grammy-nominated progressive metal band, Winger. He is widely known for his work with the band throughout their career spanning the late 1980s to the late 2000s.

Morgenstein has appeared on numerous albums with artists such as Dixie Dregs, Steve Morse Band, Dregs of the Earth, Jordan Rudess, Alice Cooper, Neal Morse Band, David Lee Roth, Grand Funk Railroad, and many others. He has toured or performed live with multiple artists, including a reunion of the Dixie Dregs for their 2007 tour. In 1985, Rod Morgenstein joined the newly formed Winger, which rose to quick fame with the popularity of the band's debut album featuring the smash hit "Seventeen". Morgenstein is recognized for his intricate drumming style, notable for its artful mixing of metal and jazz. He is also considered to be a master of double bass drumming. He was voted one of the top 25 drummers of all time by Modern Drummer magazine in 2000. Morgenstein is also an

Rod Morgenstein (born January 21, 1955) is an American session and touring drummer, best known for his work with the bands Dixie Dregs and Winger.

Morgenstein began playing drums in 1965 and studied at the Berklee College of Music from 1974 to 1976. After graduation, he formed a progressive rock/fusion band called Dixie Dregs. He has toured and recorded with the band off-and-on since that time while performing as a studio musician in various genres including rock, pop, country, jazz and gospel.

Morgenstein was the percussionist for the 1990s melodic hard rock band Winger, notably playing on Pull, their second full-length album. In recent years, he has played with the Paul Nelson Band, Derek Sherinian, and is the current drummer for both The Steve Morse Band and Jørn Lande's solo project.

"Rod Morgenstein (born April 16, 1952) is an American musician, most famous for being the drummer of the progressive metal band, Dream Theater. He is the son of Sidney Morgenstein and the younger brother of tabla player Badal Roy.

Morgenstein has been Dream Theater's drummer since 1985's When Dream and Day Unite. Morgenstein has toured and recorded as a member of Dream Theater as well as other bands such as Dixie Dregs and Winger. He has also worked as a drum instructor for Berklee College of Music, where he received his Bachelor of Music in 1976. His major works include Rhythm Knowledge (2 CD's + DVD), DVD The Rod Morgenstein Lesson & the double DVD The Rod Morgenstein Project. He is the founder of Drum Nation which offers drum educational clinics, product clinics, and custom schooling for students of all levels."

Rod Morgenstein (born May 2, 1956) is an American drummer and music instructor. He is best known for playing for the progressive metal band Dream Theater from 1989 to 1997, and for the rock and blues acts Winger, Dixie Dregs, and Steve Morse Band. Morgenstein studied at the Berklee College of Music in Boston, and holds a degree in music education. His playing is rooted in jazz, funk, rock, blues and world music.

Morgenstein has been influential in teaching, writing and recording since entering the music scene in the late 1970s. He is a member of the Berklee faculty, and has held the position of Professor of Drums at the Columbia College of Chicago, among other institutions. He has authored books, instructional videos, and has released numerous drum instruction recordings. He continues to teach at numerous sites worldwide, as well as at his own studio in North Carolina.

Rod Morgenstein (born August 11, 1960) is an American drummer and educator. He is best known as a member of the progressive rock band, Winger, and is a featured clinician in the educational drumming book The Ultimate Beginner's Drumset Instruction Book by Andy Ziker.

Morgenstein came from a musical background, playing trombone and piano as a child. He received a Bachelor of Music degree in Jazz Performance from the University of Miami in 1982 and continued his studies at the Eastman School of Music in Rochester, New York. Here he earned a Master's degree in Jazz Composition in 1984.

In high school, Morgenstein gravitated towards the drums, learning them while studying with jazz drummer Walter Proszcow and Woody Lewis, the band director at his school in Long Island, New York. He has since gone on to build an incredibly successful career, performing with a variety of acts including Winger, Simon Phillips, Joe Lynn Turner and many others. He became a full-time faculty member at the San Francisco Conservatory of Music in San Francisco in 2001 and currently resides in the Bay Area of California.

Rod Morgenstein (born April 7, 1953), is an American drummer, composer and music educator best known for his work with the rock/progressive band, Winger, with whom he has recorded and toured for the past 30 years. He has also been a longtime drum tech for the rock band Toto.

In the mid-1970s, Morgenstein studied at Berklee College of Music in Boston and then studied under jazz greats Alan Dawson and Gary Chester in New York City. He also studied improvisation under saxophonist/composer Joe Lovano and bass guitarist/composer Gene Bertoncini.

Morgenstein is a full-time faculty member of the Berklee College of Music in Boston, where he teaches Drum set Performance, Recording and Mixing and a course in Drum Instruction entitled The Spirit and Art of Drumming. He also co-teaches a course in Studio Performance Tools with fellow Winger bandmate Reb Beach. He has served as an Artist in Residence for Berklee College of Music’s International Programs in Valencia, Spain (2017). Morgenstein is a drum clinician and certified

Rod Morgenstein (born May 16, 1952) is an American drummer, composer, record producer and educator. He is best known as the drummer and one of the founding members of the progressive metal band Winger. He is also known for collaboration with other rock musicians, having recorded and performed with Dixie Dregs, Steve Morse Band, Jordan Rudess, John Petrucci and Gamma, and many others. He has also performed and/or recorded with jazz luminaries, including Mike Stern, David Sanborn, Dave Samuels, Bill Evans, Frank Gambale, and Anika Noni Rose.

Morgenstein has studied at The Eastman School of Music, The Juilliard School, The Institute of Audio Research, Berklee College of Music and Manhattan School of Music. He holds three degrees in musical performance (B.A., M.M. and D.M.A.). He is currently a professor of Contemporary Drum Set Studies at Berklee College of Music in Boston, Massachusetts.

Rod Morgenstein (born May 16, 1952) is an American rock and jazz drummer, best known for his work in the Dixie Dregs and Winger. He has also performed or recorded with The Steve Morse Band, David T. Chastain, Jordan Rudess, Allan Holdsworth, Steve Vai, Savoy Brown, Giant, and many others. 

Morgenstein grew up in Brookline, Massachusetts, and attended Boston's Berklee College of Music, where he graduated magna cum laude in 1976 with a degree in performance. While studying at Berklee, Morgenstein was an active participant in the music scene in and around the college. Immediately upon graduation, Morgenstein joined The Dixie Dregs, then a studio band, and he has been a mainstay in their recordings and live performances ever since. 

Morgenstein has been featured on numerous other recordings. He also has garnered a considerable fan base for his affiliations with NAMM (the National Association of Music Merchants) and Drum!, a magazine dedicated to percussion styles from around the world. Morgenstein has written a book on jazz fusion drum

Rod Morgenstein (born June 14, 1959) is an American drummer, composer, and educator best known for his work with rock and progressive rock groups Dixie Dregs, Winger, and The Steve Morse Band. He is notable for his jazz- and progressive rock-influenced drum technique, which he has employed on numerous albums and commercial recordings since the late 1970s. He has performed with artists including Steve Morse, Dave LaRue, Jordan Rudess, Andy West, and John Petrucci, and has integrated himself into the contemporary jazz world, holding clinics and performing with the likes of Jean-Luc Ponty, Tom Kennedy, and Simon Phillips. Morgenstein has played live with Steve Howe, Tony MacAlpine, and other eminent musicians. He regularly plays in clinics and drum festivals around the world.

Rod Morgenstein is an American drummer, songwriter, producer and clinician. A renowned educator, he is best known as the drummer for the progressive metal band Winger, as well as the instrumental jazz-fusion band Dregs. He is the author of The Jazzrock Manual, and the co-author of the Chops from Hell instructional video series. Morgenstein has recorded and performed with hundreds of artists, including Dixie Dregs (with Steve Morse and Steve Davidowski), Steve Vai, The Fernando Saunders Band, Richie Kotzen, Flying Colors, Jordan Rudess, Larga, Ellipse, Kip Winger, and Trans-Siberian Orchestra. In his role as a clinician, Morgenstein has held drum clinics at schools and music swapping events around the world for over 30 years.

Rod Morgenstein (born November 20, 1952) is an American drummer best known for his work with the bands Dixie Dregs and Winger, as well as being a highly sought-after session musician.

Morgenstein began playing drums at age nine and by age 13 he was already playing in a band of teenage musicians. In 1974, he attended Berklee College of Music in Boston, where he played and studied composition and arranging with jazz drummer Gary Chaffee.

In 1977, Morgenstein joined the Dixie Dregs, who have earned a devoted following for their blend of jazz, classical and progressive rock. Morgenstein's aggressive and dynamic drumming on classic Dixie Dregs records such as Free Fall, Unsung Heroes and Night Of The Living Dregs is widely acclaimed.

Aside from his work with Dixie Dregs, Morgenstein rejoined old high school friend Kip Winger in 1988 to form the multi-platinum selling band Winger. Winger's debut album, Winger, featured Morgenstein on most of the tracks. He has since played on every subsequent album.

Rod Morgenstein (born June 28, 1959) is an American drummer and percussionist best known for his work with the progressive rock/metal band Winger, which he co-founded with Kip Winger in 1987. He has also worked with The Dregs, the Richie Kotzen Band, and Steve Morse. In 1994, he joined the faculty at Berklee College of Music in Boston, Massachusetts. He has been teaching there ever since.

Morgenstein's musical influences included drummers such as Buddy Rich, Tony Williams, John Bonham, and Gene Krupa. He has toured with Alice Cooper, Alan Parsons, and Twisted Sister as well. He was featured on the cover of Modern Drummer magazine in July 2001. In 2002, he released his first solo CD, Rod Morgenstein's Hedgehog Protocol. In October 2003, he released his first instructional DVD, The Rod Morgenstein Drum Lesson Library Vol. 1: Power & Independence. His second instructional DVD, The Rod Morgenstein Drum Lesson Library Vol. 2: Advanced Techniques, was released in early 2005. He was part of the faculty at the Modern Drummer Festival

Rod Morgenstien (born May 1940) is an American drummer and percussionist who is best known for his work with Rush, Queensrÿche, and Dweezil Zappa.

Morgenstien started his musical career performing with local Long Island, New York acts during a period of time when rock music was beginning to emerge as a popular genre. In 1975, he was recruited by Alex Lifeson of Rush to join the band, which was already at the height of its Canadian popularity. Morgenstien contributed his trademark sound to the making of Rush's 1976 album, 2112, and toured extensively with the band in support of the album, appearing on the cover of the live recording, All The World's A Stage. With Rush, he also toured extensively throughout the United States and Europe, appearing on the band's 1980 hit, "The Spirit of Radio". Morgenstien departed Rush in 1983. 

In the late 1980s and 1990s, Morgenstien became heavily involved with the progressive metal scene, performing with such acts as Queensrÿche, Armored Saint, and Dwe

Rod Morgenstein (born April 24, 1952) is an American drummer who has worked with numerous rock bands, most notably Winger and the Dixie Dregs.

Morgenstein was born in Brooklyn, New York, and moved to Miami, Florida at an early age. He started playing the drums at age two, and began playing professionally at age 12. He studied at the University of Miami, where he graduated with a degree in Studio Music and Jazz. He also studied jazz with master teacher Freddie Gruber.

Morgenstein has been a part of many bands and recording sessions, such as the Dixie Dregs, Winger, Steve Morse Band, Beau Nasty, The Richies, Shattered, Oh Yeah!, Twister Sister, and many others. He is also a member of the faculty at the Berklee College of Music and the author of The Complete Modern Drummer.

Rod Morgenstein (born February 19, 1960) is an American drummer, author and educator, best known for his work with the bands Dixie Dregs, Winger, and The Steve Morse Band. He is also the Director of Percussion Studies at the Frost School of Music at the University of Miami, and the co-founder and executive director of The HBCU Alumni Music and Arts Institute.

Morgenstein began playing drums at the age of 12, when he was given a drum set by his parents. He went on to study percussion at the University of Miami and the Berklee College of Music. After graduating, he played with a number of bands, including the Dixie Dregs, Winger and The Steve Morse Band. He also did session work and produced some recordings. In addition to performing, Morgenstein released two instructional books, The Rhythmic Vocabulary (1991) and Mastering the Drums (2007). He has also produced several instructional videos, and regularly gives drum and percussion clinics and master classes around the world.

Rod Morgenstein (born October 27, 1956) is an American drummer, composer and music producer, best known for his work with the progressive rock/metal band Dixie Dregs. Morgenstein is a graduate of the Berklee College of Music and has played with the Dixie Dregs since their inception in 1977, as well as appearing on nearly every recording by the band. He also has worked as a featured guest artist/instructor on Aqua Teen Hunger Force, Fishbone, Flying Colors, King's X, Messengers and the Crimson ProjeKct. He has recorded, produced or performed with numerous artists including (partial list): Chris Broderick, Steve Morse, Martin Barre, Michael Manring, Steve Vai, John Petrucci, Richie Kotzen, Tony Levin, and Paul Gilbert. Morgenstein's production credits include albums by Philip Sayce, Iron Maiden, Mike Keneally, Eric Martin and Eyes of Fire.

Rod Morgenstein (born July 28, 1959) is an American drummer, songwriter, and producer. He is best known as the longtime drummer for the progressive metal band Winger.

Morgenstein began playing drums at the age of seven, taking his first lessons from Tony Mottola. He attended the High School of Music & Art in New York City, and later studied with Jim Chapin and Dom Famularo.

In 1985, Morgenstein became a member of Winger, replacing founding drummer Steve Friel. He remained with the band until it disbanded in 1994. During this period, Morgenstein co-wrote the song "Seventeen" which appeared on the band's gold-selling album In the Heart of the Young and became their biggest hit single.

Morgenstein has released two solo albums, Jamnation and Jughead, and he has recorded and toured with various other artists. He currently works as a session musician in the Nashville area. In addition, he is a co-author of the book The Modern Drummer Festival DVDs, which was released in 2001.

Rod Morgenstein (born March 10, 1957 in Northport, New York) is an American drummer, who is best known for his time in the progressive rock band, Dixie Dregs (later the Dregs), and Winger. He has also been a member of Long Island-based instrumental rock/jazz fusion band, Project Unity, since the late 1990s and has toured with the blues-rock band, The Chris Duarte Group, since 2008. He also co-founded The Yardbirds in 2004, joining original members Jim McCarty and Chris Dreja.

Morgenstein began studying drums at the age of six, with an early influence being jazz legend Buddy Rich. He attended the Berklee College of Music in Boston, Massachusetts before joining the Dixie Dregs. Throughout his career he has been associated with fusion, jazz, rock and progressive music. He has appeared on twenty-one gold and platinum albums with various artists, including Winger, The Dixie Dregs, Fiona, Vital Information and Steve Morse.

Rod Morgenstein (born December 17, 1959) is an American drummer, author, and educator. He is most noted for being the drummer of the progressive rock band Winger and the jazz fusion band Dixie Dregs.

In addition to his drumming career, Morgenstein is also an active educator, authoring five books on drumming, the latest being Frozen in Time – A Drummer's Perspective (2019). He has written 20 instructional columns for Modern Drummer magazine and currently holds a faculty post at the Berklee College of Music in Boston, MA, where he has taught since 2003.

Rod Morgenstein (born October 27, 1960) is an American drummer, percussionist, record producer, composer, and educator, best known for his work with the prog-metal band Winger, The Dregs, Darrel and the Headliners, and The Rich Refriks.

Morgenstein began playing drums at the age of 10, and attended Shenandoah Conservatory and Berklee College of Music. He has toured extensively with various artists and groups. He is an active session drummer and has toured and recorded with Dixie Dregs, Winger, Steve Morse Band, Richard Marx, Big Al Downing, Mark O'Connor, The Stoll Vaughan Band, and Derringer. He has also recorded tracks on the DVD The Supernatural Featuring Joe Satriani.

Morgenstein is currently teaching a course in music production and drum instruction at the Berklee College of Music. He is a clinician, endorser, and contributing writer for Modern Drummer Magazine, and has published several books on drum tuition and music production. He also co-wrote, co-produced, and performed on Ignorance Is Bliss
23:
Rich Williams (born October 10, 1960) is an American rock musician, best known as being the lead guitarist and a prominent songwriter in the rock band Kansas. He has written and co-written the majority of the group's best-known songs, including “Carry On Wayward Son” and ”Dust in the Wind”.

Williams was born in Topeka, Kansas. He started playing guitar at the age of eight and joined Kansas in 1973, at the age of thirteen. He was the lead guitarist on every album and tour since that time, with the exception of a few years in the mid '80s when he left the band and formed the rock group Streets and played acoustic guitar with a band called Lazer.

After leaving Kansas in 1982, Williams recorded several solo albums, some jazz projects, and appeared on many releases of other artists. He rejoined Kansas in 1985 and continues to be a part of the 'Sound of Kansas' today, producing albums and songwriting. He spawned a new generation of guitarist when “Dust in the Wind” quickly became known as an anthem for guitar players.

"Richard Williams (born July 21, 1950) is an American singer, songwriter, musician, and producer from Austin, Texas. He is best known for his solo work, which incorporates elements of country, blues, rock and roll, folk, and other styles. He has released more than 25 albums since 1975, with subjects ranging from his early days as a road warrior to present day reflection on life and love. Williams is lauded for his technical mastery of a variety of instruments, his deep understanding of the American music tradition, and unique voice. He has had a long and successful career, working with many different artists and labels, and has earned the respect of both mainstream and alternative country and Americana music scenes."

"Richard "Rich" Williams (born April 15, 1945) is an American guitarist best known for his work in the rock group Kansas. He founded the group with singer/keyboardist Steve Walsh and drummer Phil Ehart in 1970. He is the primary composer and guitarist, writing and arranging much of Kansas' music. Williams also tours extensively with the band and is known for his electric and acoustic guitar work. He has recorded several solo albums. Williams' musical style is characterized by melodic electric guitar soloing and strong, tasteful melodies. He has experimented with various guitar effects and techniques, creating a unique and complex sound."

Rich Williams (born 1948) is an American guitarist, singer and songwriter. He is best known as a longtime member of the soft rock band Kansas, having joined in 1973 and continuing as a part of the band's current lineup. He is one of only two original members remaining in the band together with fellow founding member and keyboardist, Steve Walsh.

Williams has also worked as a solo artist, as a member of the group Native Window, and has also been a session musician for various projects. He also has a reputation as an excellent guitar technician and is known to have worked on the guitars of musicians such as Steve Morse and Brad Paisley. Throughout his career, Williams has made use of several different instruments, including the Fender Stratocaster and Gibson ES-335 guitars.

"Rich Williams (born June 17, 1949) is an American guitarist, songwriter and founding member of the band Kansas. Williams learned to play the guitar as a teenager, inspired by his brother's record collection. Playing with local bands in the area, he joined a power trio known as White Clover in 1970. After gaining notoriety as a sought-after session musician, he joined the progressive rock band Kansas in 1973. With Kansas, Williams has released fourteen studio albums, five live albums and twelve compilation albums, and toured worldwide on a regular basis."

Richard Williams (born 20 November 1933) is a Welsh Canadian animator, voice actor, and writer best known for co-directing the animated film Who Framed Roger Rabbit. Williams is known for his unconventional approach to character animation and his independent approach to feature animation.

Williams was born in Toronto, his father Henry being a Welsh minister and his mother Scottish. In the 1950s, he set out on a hitchhiking adventure to Europe, spending nearly a year in Paris. During this period in France, he developed an appreciation for the Montmartre arts scene's affording of a choice between brilliance or obscurity. 

Returning to his native Canada in 1955, Williams began his career in earnest performing as a stand-up comic. He achieved success through appearances in the early 1950s editions of the Jackie Gleason Show, the Perry Como Show, and the Ed Sullivan Show. His theatrical career saw him appear in projects such as "Home and Away" (1959) and "The Four-Poster" (1962).

"Richard Williams (born 22 May 1940) is an English animator, best known for his work on Who Framed Roger Rabbit (1988). He began his career in animation in 1959, and since then has been credited on over 180 films and television series. Williams is widely regarded as one of the most influential and innovative figures in animation, and is the recipient of multiple honors, including three Academy Awards.

Williams has directed acclaimed short films such as The Little Island (1958), A Lecture on Motion (1966) and Alas, Poor Fred (1971) and has been instrumental in the development of the British animation industry since its conception in the mid-1950s. In 2017, he was awarded a lifetime achievement award by the British Film Institute. Williams is also well known as an animation illustrator and writer, having worked on numerous popular features such as The Thief and the Cobbler.

Williams' work often focuses on combining traditional animation with live-action and rotoscoping, a technique that creates an animation from a live-action shot. His films typically feature unconventional narratives, complex visuals and a wide range of motion techniques. Williams has been praised

"Richard Allen Williams (born December 31, 1949) is an American physician, entrepreneur, author, film-maker and former world-class international track and field athlete. He is best known for his groundbreaking work as the founding president and CEO of the Minority Health Institute. Under his leadership, the Institute has launched more than 50 national programs in 10 countries, focusing on health disparities and health care equity for minority and underserved populations. He is also an internationally recognized authority on health and social inequities, cultural competence and civil rights in health care and one of the nation's top experts on the health of African-Americans, Latinos and other minority populations. 

Williams' other notable achievements include: serving as director of the Southern California Center for Health and Disease Management; serving as clinical professor at the UCLA School of Medicine; serving as executive director of the Southwest Council of Black American Physicians; his founding of the Williams Institute and Williams Foundation; and, his numerous public appearances and books on health, wellness, and wellness care disparities in the U.S. and abroad. Williams holds a Doctor of Medicine degree from Howard University College of Medicine and a Master's Degree in

"Rich Williams (born October 19, 1953) is an American guitarist, best known for his work with the rock band Kansas. After playing in several bands around the Wichita, Kansas, area and joining the newly formed Kansas in 1973, Williams took the lead guitar spot, contributing songwriting and guitar work to Kansas' best known albums, including Leftoverture (1976) and Point of Know Return (1978). He co-wrote the hit songs "Carry On Wayward Son" and "Dust in the Wind." Williams has also released two solo albums, composed musical scores for radio and television, and continues to tour with the reunited Kansas. He is married and the father of two daughters."

"Richard "Rich" Williams (born May 14, 1943) is an American musician best known for being a member of the influential rock band, Kansas. Williams attended the University of Miami and joined the band in 1970. He was initially hired as a temporary replacement on guitar, but stayed on as a full-time member and eventually shared lead-guitar and vocal duties with Kerry Livgren.

Williams wrote or co-wrote several songs on Kansas albums, such as "Cheyenne Anthem" and "Children of the Sun" on Masque, "The Preacher" and "Two Cents Worth" on Leftoverture, and "On the Other Side" on Point of Know Return. He is an accomplished slide guitar player, demonstrated on Point of Know Return on "Closet Chronicles" and "Portrait (He Knew)".

Williams also had a solo career, releasing two albums in 1979 and 1980 respectively. After recording Playn' to Win, he left Kansas in 1980, but returned in 1985, most notably co-writing and singing the guitar-driven "All I Wanted" on the band's 1986

Richard Williams (born 1943) is an American jazz keyboardist, who has been a music director and has composed numerous jazz, blues and R&B songs, notably "Hot Chocolate", "Disco Lady", "Another Star" and "Let's Groove". He was an in-house producer and composer for Prescription Records, Lowell George's Invitation Records and other labels.

Williams was born in Cleveland and at an early age started playing jazz and R&B music on the keyboard in local bands. He was later hired as an organist for a church before moving to Los Angeles in the late 1960s. During his time in Los Angeles, Williams worked as a studio musician and supported acts like Ray Charles and the Temptations. In the early 70s, Williams started writing and producing music for records and went on to produce and write numerous hits.

" Richard Williams (born 13 February 1943) is an English animator, best known for his work on Who Framed Roger Rabbit. He attended art school in Cannington and studied fine art and 3D design, later becoming a comic book artist before beginning his animation career in 1966.

After beginning his career in England, Williams left to work in the United States in 1968 as supervising animator of The Endless Way at DePatie-Freleng Enterprises. Over the next few years he worked on various projects, including the Academy Award-winning short film A Christmas Carol and two feature film adaptations of the Dr. Seuss stories, Horton Hears a Who! and The Cat in the Hat. 

From 1981 to 1987 he worked on Who Framed Roger Rabbit, for which he won two Academy Awards for Animated Effects and for Animation Direction. One of the most notable aspects of the film are the three-dimensional backgrounds, which were a product of collaboration between Williams and Fred Hellmich. He followed up his success on Who Framed Roger Rabbit by directing the animated feature The Thief and the Cobbler, sharing screenwriting credits with Pamela

"Rich Williams (born April 24, 1952) is an American guitarist, singer and songwriter. He is best known as the guitarist, backing vocalist and songwriter with the rock band Kansas, which had hits in the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s such as "Carry On Wayward Son" and "Dust in the Wind". Williams began his career as rhythm guitarist with Kansas in 1973 and he also shared lead guitar work with original member, Kerry Livgren. For almost four decades with the band, he contributed to many of the group's albums, songs, and videos. He became the main lead guitarist in Kansas after the departures of Steve Morse and John Elefante, though Livgren and Williams continued to share lead guitar duties, as well as vocal harmonies, on the band's studio albums. Williams is also a solo artist, and has recorded four solo albums with his own solo project, Rich Williams' WMD."

Rich Williams (born June 25, 1952, in Topeka, Kansas) is an American jazz saxophonist and composer, who has enjoyed a three-decade career as the leader of his own groups and as a sideman. He has performed or recorded with artists such a Chuck Mangione, The Rippingtons, Steely Dan, Tom Scott, Bob Mintzer, Robben Ford, Gerry Mulligan, Herbie Hancock, Al Jarreau, David Sanborn, Branford Marsalis, Tom Jones, and Lee Ritenour. He has released four albums as a leader, composed several books of music, and is a longtime adjunct professor of jazz saxophone at the University of Kansas. His recording of the classic standard, “Cherokee,” from his self-titled debut album (1992), is recognized as a modern-day classic. He continues to tour and record worldwide.

Rich Williams (born October 4, 1951) is an American guitarist, best known as a long-time member of the rock band Kansas.

Williams joined Kansas in 1973 and played on their first four studio albums, as well as on their 1977 live album Two for the Show. He left the band in 1980, citing creative differences, and was replaced by Steve Morse. In the early 1980s he formed the band Redwing, which had some success with their self-titled album. He rejoined Kansas in 1985 and played with them until 1997.

Williams is a songwriter, having written and co-written many songs for Kansas. He has also written for artists such as Olivia Newton-John, Linda Eder and The Beach Boys. Williams has also released several solo albums and participated in various side projects with other musicians. He still occasionally performs and records with Kansas.

Rich Williams is an American musician, best known for his role as an original guitarist, vocalist and founding member of the rock band Kansas. He wrote some of their most enduring hit songs and performed on a wide range of albums, from the group's 1974 debut, Kansas, to their Grammy®-nominated 2016 release, The Prelude Implicit.

Williams also composed and sang one of Kansas' most popular songs, "Dust in the Wind," as well as multiple other early Kansas hits, such as "Carry On Wayward Son," "Point of No Return," and "Play the Game Tonight." He joined Kansas shortly after the band's formation in 1973, and would remain an original member until the mid-1980s. During this time, Kansas released a number of now-classic rock albums. Williams co-wrote many of the songs on these albums, including the immensely popular "Carry On Wayward Son," which garnered the band their highest chart position ever, as well as "Point of No Return," "Play the Game Tonight," and "Dust in the Wind," all of which have become standards still played frequently on classic rock radio today

"Richard Kenneth Williams (born July 15, 1948) is an American jazz guitarist, composer, and arranger. He played with Weather Report, Herbie Hancock, Jaco Pastorius, McCoy Tyner, George Benson, and other jazz luminaries, and his compositions swing through bebop, funk, Latin, and fusion. Williams is a Grammy Award-winning artist; his recordings with Herbie Hancock in 1974 earned him a Grammy Award for Best Jazz Instrumental Performance, Duo or Group. He is a USC (University of Southern California) Thornton School of Music Board of Councilors Member, and in 2020 he was awarded an Honorary Doctor of Music (Hon. D.M.) degree, the highest honor bestowed by USC."

Richard O'Neal Williams (born February 16, 1943) is an American businessman and entrepreneur. He is the founder and CEO of the Williams Companies, Inc., an energy, pipelines and utilities holding company in Tulsa, Oklahoma. He is reported to be the 72nd wealthiest person in America, with an estimated net worth of $7.2 billion. 

Williams was born in Tulsa, Oklahoma to an African American family. He attended Central High School, and later studied electrical engineering at schools such as Southern Methodist University and University of Tulsa. He began working in the pipeline business at the age of 18, first as an apprentice and then as a full-time employee for two of the major companies in the industry. 

In 1989, Williams founded the Williams Companies, Inc., which soon became a leading energy producer in the region, with oil, natural gas, and crude pipelines, which extend from Canada, across the United States, and into Mexico.

Williams is known for his philanthropy, and has donated large amounts of money to the Tulsa Community Foundation, the Oklahoma State University College of Engineering, and the University of Tulsa College of Engineering.

Rich Williams (born October 4th 1981) is an American musician and songwriter, best known for his rock band Kansas. Williams is the band’s main songwriter, vocalist, and guitarist, and is one of the few original members still in the band, having been an integral part of Kansas's long and successful history. 

Williams was born in Topeka, Kansas, and began playing music at the age of six. He received his first guitar at age nine, taught by his father, and quickly began developing his songwriting skills. By the age of 15, he was playing in the local Topeka circuit, and at age 16, he joined Kansas officially as lead vocalist and songwriter, replacing co-founder Steve Walsh.

Since then, Williams has lead Kansas on a number of successful albums, singles and tours, selling millions of albums worldwide. He has written countless hits for the band, such as "Carry On Wayward Son," "Dust in the Wind," and "Point of Know Return," and continues to write new material for the band's live shows. Williams is also the primary guitarist for the group

Richard "Rich" Williams (born February 25, 1954) is an American rock guitarist, vocalist, composer, and producer. He is best known for his role as lead guitarist, vocalist, composer, and occasional producer of the rock band Kansas, which he co-founded in 1973 with original drummer Phil Ehart and keyboardist/vocalist Steve Walsh. He composed some of Kansas' biggest hits, such as "Carry On Wayward Son", "Dust in the Wind", and "Point of Know Return". Williams was inducted into the Oklahoma Music Hall of Fame in 2007.
24: Thomas Harriot (sometimes spelled Harriott, Hariot, or Heriot) (c. 1560–1621) was an English polymath, scientist, mathematician, astronomer, and philosopher who made important contributions to the scientific revolution and to the Enlightenment. He is sometimes credited as the founder of the scientific method, as he was one of the first to apply mathematics and data collection to empirical observations in order to learn about the natural world. He was also an important early champion of the Copernican heliocentric theory of the universe, one of the first European observers of the Moon through a telescope, a translator of complex mathematical, astronomical and technological works, a member of the School of Night that included the likes of Francis Bacon, Walter Raleigh and others of the period, and an incessant writer of scientific papers, many of which were unpublished until centuries later.

Thomas Harriot (c. 1560 – 2 July 1621) was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer and translator. He is sometimes credited with the introduction of the potato to the British Isles. Harriot was the first person to make a drawing of the Moon through a telescope, on 26 July 1609, over four months before Galileo. He made extensive observations of the Moon and documented a large number of its features, in an era when such observations had never been attempted by any other astronomer. He was also an early pioneer in the history of optics.

Harriot was an early supporter of the Copernican theory, claiming that the Earth's motion could be explained by heliocentrism. He published a map of the Moon and wrote extensively about the Moon's features. He was a proponent of the experimental method and is sometimes credited as being the first to use it in natural philosophy, or science. He studied the refraction of light and invented an improved version of the refracting telescope, the 'ocular'. He worked with the astronomer and cartographer John Smith in the production of Smith's detailed map of the then known world.

Thomas Harriot (c. 1560 – 2 July 1621) was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer, and translator. He made advances in the fields of mathematics, astronomy and navigation and left a legacy of scientific instruments, among them the astronomical telescope, which he used to observe and make notes on the moon and planets, which he had first seen through a Dutch telescope in 1609, and which were later published as the seminal book A Brief and True Report of the New Found Land of Virginia.

Harriot also conducted experiments in botany, zoology, metallurgy and mineralogy, and wrote a Treatise of Field and Gardens, in which his discoveries in natural history were detailed. He was one of the earliest Britons to be educated in the scientific method and was critical of the theories of Aristotle. He was the first to successfully calculate the heliocentric effect of the planets on the earth with his celestial globes. He also proposed a universal language to facilitate global communication.

Thomas Harriot (also spelled Harriott, Hariot or Heriot; c. 1560 – July 2, 1621) was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer, and translator who made advances within the scientific field. He is sometimes credited with the introduction of the potato to Europe.

Harriot was one of the foremost scientific minds of the Elizabethan period. He studied mathematics, aquinas, optics, astronomy, philosophy and the scientific methods of Copernicus and Galileo. He developed a system of equations to determine orbital paths and his mathematics was more advanced than most of his contemporaries. Harriot developed the first observatory in England and mapped the Moon. He was the first person to record the brightness of the stars, and he developed new ways to measure them. He also recorded noted weather patterns, including convection currents, and he proposed a theory of their cause. Harriot made numerous experiments in alchemy and was an adept in the island's Native American language of Roanoke.

Thomas Harriot (c. 1560 – July 2, 1621), also spelled Harriott, Hariot, or Heriot, was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer and translator. He is sometimes credited with the introduction of the potato to the British Isles. Harriot was the first person to make a drawing of the Moon through a telescope, on 26 July 1609, over four months before Galileo. He studied the geometry of the triangle and the circles of a spherical triangle on the sphere, figured out methods for the area of a spherical triangle and the volume of a pyramid and a cone, and also discovered "secret constructions" of regular polygons. Most significantly, he made important contributions to the scientific field of analytical trigonometry and with Pascal's triangle. He also popularized the use of algebraic notation for the mathematic equations. As an astronomer, he conducted observations on the relation of the Earth and Moon, the motion of the Moon, and the rotation of the Earth.

Thomas Harriot (1560 – 2 July 1621), also spelled Harriott, Hariot, or Heriot, was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer, and translator. He is sometimes credited (mainly in the USA) with the introduction of the potato to the British Isles. He made a map of the Moon and noted its major features and properties, noting differences between terrestrial and lunar, such as differences in measuring angles of longitude and latitude on land versus on water and in the air. He documented the observational behavior of comets and the time of flow and ebb of the tides. He also engaged in significant studies of wind and attempted to devise mathematical models to explain atmospheric phenomena. Thomas Harriot (also spelled Harriott, Hariot, or Heriot; c. 1560–2 July 1621) was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer, and translator. He is sometimes credited as the first to observe, in 1609, the Moon through a telescope, but likely with less precision than his competitor Galileo Galilei. He was also an important influence on the astronomer Johannes Kepler.

Harriot published his last work in 1617, an extended work on Navigation and Astronomy with illustrations. He used the "New Star" (or Kepler's supernova) of 1604 as an example for illustrating his method for determining the parallax of a star, becoming the first astronomer to do so. He was also noted for inventing a refined version of the Bellarmine Barometer for measuring atmospheric pressure.

Thomas Harriot (also spelled Hariot; c. 1560– 2 July 1621) was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer, and translator. He is sometimes credited with the introduction of the potato to the British Isles. He was the first person to make a drawing of the Moon through a telescope, on 26 July 1609, over four months before Galileo. Harriot was a pivotal figure in the history of science in the early modern period within the English-speaking world and he was one of the key figures in the English Scientific Renaissance. He was one of the first to make practical use of the telescope, and his observations of the Moon, taken with a refracting telescope, were some of the earliest recorded. He studied the geography of the Americas, and was among the first Englishmen to investigate the accustomed living styles of the linguistic Americans.

Thomas Harriot (c. 1560 – 2 July 1621), also spelled Harriott, Hariot, or Heriot, was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer and translator. He is sometimes credited with being the first to make a drawing of the Moon through a telescope, on 26 July 1609, over four months before Galileo Galilei. Harriot's work was also an important contribution to the field of optics and the understanding of the refraction of light, the astronomical observations published posthumously as The observation of forty-eight fixed stars (1609) and the collection of scientific data published in A briefe and true report of the new found land of Virginia (1588). He was one of the earliest scientists to make use of the recently invented telescope to study the night sky. Harriot was the first person to record the use of a telescope in England to observe the heavens, and is affiliated with the 17th-century scientific revolution.

Thomas Harriot (also spelled Harriott, Hariot or Heriot; c. 1560 – 2 July 1621) was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer and translator. He made significant contributions to the fields of mathematics, astronomy, and navigation. Harriot was the first person to make a drawing of the Moon through a telescope, on 26 July 1609, over four months before Galileo. He assisted Francis Drake in his 1585 expedition, by planning navigation for the voyage and by recording the observations of North America he made. He also wrote an early treatise on the use of the decimal point.

Harriot was a Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians of London and a professor of mathematics at the University of Oxford. He studied at St Mary Hall, Oxford, but did not take a degree. He made a cross-country excursion in the summer of 1580. He traveled through Northern England to Edinburgh, where he joined a debating group composed of William Armstrong, George Buchanan, Thomas Macaulay, and David Peebles. Thomas Harriot (c. 1560–1621), also spelled Harriott, Hariot, or Heriot, was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer, and translator. He is sometimes credited with the introduction of the potato to the British Isles. Harriot was the first person to make a drawing of the Moon through a telescope, on 26 July 1609, over four months before Galileo. He conducted over 60 experiments with refraction of light involving lenses and mirrors, and developed a new mathematical technique, now known as Raleigh's method, to determine the shape of the Earth by measuring the altitude of the stars at night.

He was also involved in the colonisation of America, having made accurate maps of the Roanoke Island area of present-day North Carolina, the Chesapeake Bay area of Maryland, and the New England area of what is now Massachusetts, Connecticut, and New Hampshire. He also wrote a book on navigational theory titled Artis analyticae praxis ad triangulationem. He was a member of the East India Company, and participated in several voyages to the New World. Thomas Harriot (also spelled Harriott, Hariot or Heriot; 1560–1621) was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer and translator. He is sometimes credited with the introduction of the potato to the British Isles. Harriot was the first person to make a drawing of the Moon through a telescope, on 26 July 1609, over four months before Galileo. He was an essential contributor to the scientific revolution of the 17th century, and his pioneering work in astronomy was quickly recognized by his contemporaries, including Johannes Kepler and Galileo Galilei. He was also a respected surveyor and navigator, making maps of coastal areas in the American colonies and directing several expeditions to the New World. He was probably the first person to use algebra to solve a problem in navigation.

Thomas Harriot (also spelled Harriott, Hariot, or Heriot) (baptised 5 March 1560 – 2 July 1621) was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer and translator who made advances within the scientific fields of astronomy, algebra, and optics. He is sometimes credited with the introduction of the potato to the British Isles. Harriot was the first person to make a drawing of the Moon through a telescope, on 26 July 1609, over four months before Galileo Galilei. He engaged in exhaustive studies of the heavens, for which he constructed a large quadrant to accurately predict the locations of planets and stars. His work in treastises on navigation were so advanced that some have suggested he anticipated the discovery of Newton's law of gravitation. He undertook diffusion of information concerning many scientific discoveries and inventions in Europe, Asia and the Americas. An early scientist, he conducted many experiments while employed by Sir Walter Raleigh. He is sometimes known as the English Francis Bacon or the "Father of English Science".

Thomas Harriot (also spelled Harriott, Hariot or Heriot; c. 1560–2 July 1621) was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer and translator who made advances within the scientific field. Harriot was the first person to make a drawing of the Moon through a telescope, on 26 July 1609, over four months before Galileo. He was a major influence on Isaac Newton. In 1585, after graduating from St Mary Hall, Oxford, Harriot entered the household of Sir Walter Raleigh as his personal assistant in their expeditions to the New World. In addition to collecting botanical and other scientific data, Harriot was a keen observer of American Indian cultures and languages; some of his work survived and was edited by Edward Everett in 1847, a century after his death. 

Harriot was a pivotal figure in the development of modern science and mathematics, and his contribution to the study of Solaria, a type of planetary motion, formed the basis of Newton's theories. Thomas Harriot (c. 1560 – 2 July 1621) was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer and translator who made advances in the fields of astronomy, mathematics and geography. He is sometimes credited with the introduction of the potato to the British Isles.

Harriot was the first person to make a drawing of the Moon through a telescope, on 26 July 1609, over four months before Galileo. He also anticipated the forthcoming discovery of the satellites of Jupiter, anticipating their number as four, which was confirmed by Galileo in 1610. He did pioneer work in algebra. He studied the tide and also anticipated Isaac Newton’s laws of motion and gravitation. He was a central figure of the Scientific Revolution. His notable-contributions included the refinement of the Copernican Theory and he was among the first to suggest that the Moon was not perfectly smooth but had mountains and valleys.

Thomas Harriot (c. 1560–1621) was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer and translator. He is sometimes credited with the introduction of the potato to the British Isles. Harriot was the first person to make a drawing of the Moon through a telescope, on 26 July 1609, over four months before Galileo. He was a pioneering investigator of both astronomy and the natural sciences, and was the first to analyse the geometry of a work of art, recognise the importance of double refraction and recognise that colour was a property of light, rather than a property of the things that are illuminated. He was also an innovative mathematical practitioner, whose book on equations has been praised as a precursor to René Descartes' influential La Géométrie. Harriot's principal lasting legacy was his promotion of the advancement of science in Elizabethan England.

Thomas Harriot (c. 1560 – 2 July 1621) was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer and translator who made advances in the fields of astronomy, mathematics and sciences; he was part of the scientific group at the School of Science in Oxford during the late 16th century. Harriot was the first to make a drawing of the Moon through a telescope, on 26 July 1609, over four months before Galileo. He made extensive observations of the Moon and noted the its spherical shape. He also studied the solar system. He was the first English scientist to make a systematic study of algebra and used his analytical methods to solve geometric problems. He was an important figure in the popularisation of algebra that formed the basis of modern mathematics. He also made contributions to optics, particularly the development of refraction and the use of lenses to magnify small objects.

Thomas Harriot (also spelled Harriott, Hariot or Heriot; c. 1560 – 2 July 1621) was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer, and translator who made major contributions to the field of mathematics, including the use of algebra in the English language, the first collected system of the algebraic rules of real numbers—the analytical triangle, the “solution of triangles”, and the Law of Sines. He is sometimes credited with the introduction of the potato to the British Isles. Harriot was the first person to make a drawing of the Moon through a telescope that was powerful enough to resolve significant detail. He made other important advances in astronomy, including improved astronomical instrumentation. He was an early proponent of the Copernican system providing an undated manuscript containing key propositions for a proposed book on the heliocentric system. He was also an early experimenter in optics, and was the first to describe scientifically the phenomenon of apparent occultation, which occurs when a brighter celestial body blocks the view of a less bright celestial body. Thomas Harriot (1560 – 2 July 1621), also spelled Harriott, Hariot, or Heriot, was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer, and translator who made advances within the scientific field and made significant contributions to the field of astronomy and navigation. He is sometimes credited to being an important contributor towards the start of the scientific revolution.

Harriot was an important figure in the early development of both the astronomical telescope and the sextant, two tools which were later used as standard equipment aboard ships. A talented mathematician and distinguished astronomer, Harriot worked with Johannes Kepler who referred to him as a "most acute mathematician". He investigated the refraction of light, observed sunspots, studied the Moon and eclipses, and charted the stars of the southern sky. He also discovered that the Moon had an uneven surface, made observations of the irregularities of the Earth’s rotation, and, as early as 1609, was among the first to realise that the constellations of the southern hemisphere could not be seen from England.

Thomas Harriott (cbc1560 – 2 July 1621) was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer, and translator. He is sometimes credited with the introduction of the potato to the British Isles. Harriott was a key figure in the founding of the new science of experimental philosophy. He was active in the scientific academy at the last Elizabethan court, from 1583 onwards. He was appointed observer for the 1591 British expedition to North America, where he studied and wrote about the native population and bird species. He was the first to draw an accurate map of the Moon. He invented a telescopic sight for a musket and might have been the first to use a telescope for astronomical purposes in 1600. He was one of the first Englishmen to make use of algebra in his writings on mathematics. His work was later disseminated through two books published posthumously.

He was inducted into the Scottish Football Hall of Fame in 2007.

Gordon David Strachan (born 9 February 1957) is a Scottish football manager and former player. He is currently the manager of the Scotland national football team. As a manager he has been in charge of Coventry City, Southampton, Celtic and Middlesbrough.

He moved to Manchester United in 1984 and, during his five-year stay, won the 1985 FA Cup and the 1987–88 FA Cup. Gordon David Strachan (born 9 February 1957) is a Scottish football manager and former player, currently the manager of Scottish Premiership club Aberdeen. Ronnie Barker, OBE (25 September 1929 – 3 October 2005), was an English actor, comedian, and writer. He was known for roles in British comedy television series such as Porridge, The Two Ronnies, and Open All Hours, as well as his sketch writing partnership with Ronnie Corbett.

Ronnie Barker (25 September 1929 – 3 October 2005) was a British actor, comedian, and writer. He was best known for his roles in British comedy television series, such as Porridge, Open All Hours, The Two Ronnies, and Clarence.

Ronnie Barker (25 September 1929 - 3 October 2005) was an English actor, writer, and comedian. He is best remembered for his roles in several British television comedy series, including The Two Ronnies, Porridge, Open All Hours, and the sketch show The Frost Report.

Barker began his career in repertory theatre and made his television debut in 1956. He became one of Britain’s best-loved comedians, and his performances in sitcoms and sketches made him one of the most familiar faces in British comedy.

Ronald William George Barker OBE (25 September 1929 – 3 October 2005) was an English actor, comedian, and writer. Ronald William George Barker OBE (25 September 1929 – 3 October 2005), was an English actor, comedian, and writer. He was known for roles in British comedy television series such as Porridge, The Two Ronnies, Open All Hours, and Clarence.

Ronnie Barker (25 September 1929 – 3 October 2005) was an English actor, comedian, and writer. He was known for roles in British comedy television series such as Porridge, The Two Ronnies, and Open All Hours.

29: "Jearl Walker (born June 2, 1961) is an American physicist and science writer. He is best known for his book The Flying Circus of Physics, first published in 1975. The book is a collection of anecdotes that Walker has collected over the years, as well as some of his own experiences, related to the world of physics. Through these stories, he demonstrates how classical physics, the physics of everyday life, applies to the everyday person in an interesting and entertaining way. The book has been popular with students, providing a way to understand physics by relating them to everyday life. Walker has published several more books on the physics of everyday life, including Amusement Park Physics and Fun With Physics, and is the editor-in-chief of the American Journal of Physics."

Jearl Walker (born July 25, 1945) is an American physicist, author and professor emeritus of physics at Cleveland State University. He is probably best known for his books The Flying Circus of Physics and its two-volume successor, The Amateur Scientists, which have become popular among both physics students and life-long learners. Walker is also the founding editor of The Physics Teacher, the official journal of the American Association of Physics Teachers.

Walker is known for his distinctive writing style, humor and enthusiasm for physics. His books, lectures and magazine articles have informed and entertained millions around the world and he has received numerous honors and awards. Walker received his B.S. in mathematics (1966) and Ph.D. in physics (1970) from the University of Missouri. He has since held faculty positions at Purdue University, University of Texas-El Paso, Cleveland State University and Rollins College. He was also a postdoctoral fellow at the University of California-Berkeley, working with E.O. Lawrence. In 2010, he was the recipient of the Outstanding Educator Award from the American Association of Physics Teachers.

Jearl Walker (born 1948 in Galveston, Texas) is an American physicist and author. He is best known for his popular science books, The Flying Circus of Physics, which has sold more than 300,000 copies in seven languages, and its sequel, The Amateur Scientist. Walker is an emeritus professor of physics at Cleveland State University and served as editor of the American Journal of Physics from 1990 to 2002. He is a fellow of the American Physical Society and a past president of the Forum on Education of the American Association of Physics Teachers. He is also an avid birder and beekeeper.

Jearl Walker (1961-present) is an American physicist and author. He is best known for his research in elementary particle physics, particularly the theory of high-energy collisions, and for writing the popular-level physics books The Flying Circus of Physics and its sequels. He has written more than 100 research papers and several textbooks. Walker has won numerous awards, including the 1995 Hertz Foundation Teaching Award for the undergrads at Ohio State University and the 2012 American Association of Physics Teachers Julius Edgar Lilienfeld Prize. He is a Fellow of the American Physical Society, a member of the Ohio Academy of Science and a past president of the American Association of Physics Teachers.

Jearl Walker (born December 3, 1947) is an American physicist and science writer best known for his popular science books. He has undergraduate degrees in physics and mathematics from Duke University (1969) and a PhD in Physics from Cornell University (1975). He is currently a professor emeritus of physics at Cleveland State University. 

Walker has written several successful books, including The Flying Circus of Physics, The Amateur Scientist, and The Physics Teacher's Book of Demonstrations and Experiments. He has also authored articles for scientific and popular magazines, including Scientific American, American Scientist, Popular Science, Natural History, and The Physics Teacher. He is the recipient of numerous awards and honors, including an honorary doctorate from the University of Turku, Finland; the 1998 Oersted Medal of the American Association of Physics Teachers for "Outstanding Contributions to the Teaching of Physics"; the 2004 Hans Christian Oersted Medal of the American Association of Physics Teachers for "Distinguished Service to Physics Education"; and the 2006 Andrew Gemant Award from the American Institute of Physics.

Jearl Walker (born April 25, 1945) is an American physicist and the Clarence J. Fasold Professor of Physics at the Cleveland State University. He is the author of the popular physics textbook and multimedia series, The Flying Circus of Physics.

Walker specializes in the fields of physics education and the scientific method, chaos theory, and the mechanics of waves, particularly of sound waves. His research has appeared in numerous scientific publications, including thirty-two papers in The Physical Review, two papers in Nature, and two papers in Science.

Walker is the author or co-author of nine books, ranging from popularized physics texts to professional level research monographs. He has written over 100 articles for the physics education journal American Journal of Physics. He is a Fellow of the American Physical Society, of the Acoustical Society of America, and an Honorary Member of the American Association of Physics Teachers. He has been featured on television, in newspapers, and in magazine articles, including in U.S. News and World Report, Popular Science, and Discover.

Jearl Walker (born July 9, 1945) is an American physicist and science writer. He is a professor of physics at Cleveland State University, Fellow of the American Physical Society, and a former section editor (1980–2015) of the scientific American magazine.

Walker was born in Cleveland, Ohio, and graduated from John Adams High School. He went on to receive an undergraduate degree in physics from Vanderbilt University in 1967 and completed his Ph.D. at Cornell University in 1971. His field of specialization is Statistical physics, and his research involves quantum mechanics, condensed matter theory and the statistical mechanics of lubrication theory.

Walker is an author, writing in both technical and non-technical publications. His books, The Flying Circus of Physics and The Amateur Scientist, explaining various physical science experiments to laypeople, were among the most popular of the Scientific American book series. He has also written seven college-level books on physics topics (including introductory physics, modern physics and thermodynamics).

Jearl Walker, an American physicist, is best known as the author of The Amateur Scientist, a regular column he wrote for Scientific American magazine from 1975-1985. The column's subject was the exploration of such diverse subjects as using electricity to repel bees, making hydrogen fuel, and coaxing the secret music from a wine glass. In recognition of his work, Walker was awarded the 1990 Alexander Hollaender Award from the American Institute of Biological Sciences.

Walker is also the author of 10 books, including Fundamentals of Physics, which with co-author Halliday, aided millions of student to understand the fundamental principles of physics. In 2005, the fifth edition of Fundamentals was issued. Also, Fundamentals of Physics was awarded the 1998 Texty Award from the Text and Academic Authors Association for being the most widely used college textbook of 1997-98.

Jearl Walker (August 15, 1945 – June 5, 2020) was an American physics educator and author. He was best known for his bestselling book, The Flying Circus of Physics (1975). Walker earned an undergraduate degree from University of Central Oklahoma, then a doctorate from University of Rochester in 1975.

He was the first host of the popular PBS television program "Scientific American Frontiers with Alan Alda" that starred on prime time for 12 years. He served as a professor at the Case Institute of Technology (now Case Western Reserve University) for 34 years. During the early part of his career, Walker served as the department chair from 1982 to 1985. Walker also contributed to the Physics Teacher journal.

Walker was awarded the Oersted Medal by the American Association of Physics Teachers ay its annual meeting in August 2006. The Oersted Medal is the highest award given by the AAPT and is bestowed upon a physicist or physical science teacher who has contributed significantly to the teaching of physics. Walker received a lifetime achievement award at the Ohio Section of the AAPT in 2008. He also received the 2006–2007 Award for Excellence in Under

Jearl Walker (born June 2, 1945) is an American physicist, currently Clevegray Professor Emeritus at Cleveland State University. He is best known for his popular books on physics which include The Flying Circus of Physics, a 1977 textbook now in its third edition, plus several follow-up volumes, and the science fiction novel The Physics of Superheroes.

Walker was born and raised in Memphis, Tennessee. He earned his B.S. in physics from the University of Missouri in 1967, then completed his Ph.D. in theoretical physics in 1972 at Syracuse University.

Walker has written for both scholarly journals and more popular publications about physics, mechanics, and mathematics. In The Flying Circus of Physics, now in its third edition, he emphasizes the fun of physics by combining theory with humorous anecdotage. He has been called the Johnny Carson of physics.

Jearl Walker (born October 6, 1945) is an American physicist, author, and educator. He is best known as the author of the popular physics textbooks, The Flying Circus of Physics and its companion, The Amateur Scientist, as well as Physics forEntertainment. He has written articles for Scientific American magazine since 1975, so frequently that he is known as “the Mr. Wizard of Physics”. He has also served as a consultant to the National Science Foundation and the National Science Teachers Association.

Jearl Walker (born 1945) is an American physicist, author, and popular science educator. He is Professor Emeritus of physics at Cleveland State University and the author of several books on scientific topics. He is best known for The Flying Circus of Physics, a light-hearted magazine column and book series which he began writing in 1975.

Walker has served as Associate Editor of The American Journal of Physics, and his works have appeared in Scientific American, Discover and Smithsonian magazines. He has been a frequent guest on the PBS series Newton's Apple, and occasional co-host of the PBS series Scientific American Frontiers. He has delivered over 2000 lectures on various science topics, and has received numerous awards for his writing and teaching. He is a Fellow of the American Physical Society and the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Jearl Walker (born October 20, 1941) is an American physicist, educator, author, and public speaker. He is Emeritus Professor of physics at Cleveland State University (CSU), where he served as department chair from 1995 to 2011. He served in the U.S. Army in Vietnam during much of the war, and was the recipient of three Purple Hearts.

Walker is best known for the popular science book Freakonomics: The Movie (2006), based upon his 1975 book The Flying Circus of Physics. He is also the author of over 50 books including Scientific American's “The Amateur Scientist” series, Physics for Poets, The Flying Circus of Physics, and The Physics Teacher Guide. In addition to his contributions to science and education, Walker is recognized for his many public lectures, research presentations, and his books that stress the importance of scientific literacy.

Jearl Walker (born February 24, 1947), also known as "The Flying Scientist", is a Professor of physics at Cleveland State University, an informal science educator, and the author of several popular science books. He is known for his innovative demonstrations of physics principles for television, such as the Discovery Channel program "Invisible Universe", and for writing articles for Scientific American magazine, which he did for many years. Walker is the recipient of numerous awards, including the American Association of Physics Teachers’ Robert A. Millikan Award (1978) and the American Institute of Physics Science Award (1991). He is a Fellow of the American Physical Society, a Fellow of the American Association of Physics Teachers, and a professor of physics at Cleveland State University.

Jearl Walker (born May 12, 1948) is an American physicist, author and professor at Cleveland State University. He is the author of books on physics geared towards a non-technical audience, and is a Fellow of the American Association of Physics Teachers and the American Physical Society. Walker is primarily known for authoring the Flying Circus of Physics series of books, which demonstrate the relevance of his subject by examining unusual and entertaining illustrations of physics topics. In 1982, Walker received the Oersted Medal from the American Association of Physics Teachers for distinguished contributions to the teaching of physics, and for fostering appreciation of the richness and excitement of physics to students and the public.

"Jearl Walker (born 1948) is an American physicist and popular science author who has written two physics textbooks and two popular science books, The Flying Circus of Physics and Spinoffs from the Flyng Circus of Physics, both of which have been translated into several languages. He has appeared on several television and radio shows, including Nightline, Nova and Jim Lehrer NewsHour, and has given lectures to scientific and general audiences. He is a Fellow of the American Physical Society and past president of the American Association of Physics Teachers. Jearl Walker (born December 17, 1952) is an American physicist, professor and author known for his work on the physics of everyday life.

Jearl Walker (born June 29, 1945) is an American physicist, professor emeritus at Cleveland State University, and most known for his works in physics education, particularly The Flying Circus of Physics. In 1980, he completed a Master of Public Administration at the John F. Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University. 

Lee was an officer in the Singapore Armed Forces, where he held the rank of Brigadier-General. He worked in the Ministry of Trade and Industry and became CEO of the Port of Singapore Authority from 1981 to 1982. He later entered politics and was made a cabinet minister in 1985, becoming the youngest ever to do so.

Lee Hsien Loong (born 10 February 1952) is a Singaporean politician who has been Prime Minister of Singapore since 2004. He is the eldest son of Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's first Prime Minister. He entered politics in 1984 as a Member of Parliament, and in 1985 he was appointed the Acting Minister for Trade and Industry. In 1986, he became the Chairman of the Finance and Investment Subcommittee of the People Action's Party (PAP). Since then he has held many ministerial portfolios, including Minister for Trade and Industry, Deputy Prime Minister, and Finance Minister. In August 2004, he succeeded Goh Chok Tong as the Prime Minister of Singapore, and was re-elected in May 2006, May 2011 and September 2015. As Prime Minister, Lee has continued to pursue the legacy of his father, focusing on housing and infrastructure projects, and overseeing Singapore's transition to a knowledge-based economy.

Lee Hsien Loong (born 10 February 1952) is a Singaporean politician who has been the Prime Minister of Singapore since 2004. He is the eldest son of Singapore's first Prime Minister, Lee Kuan Yew. He graduated from Trinity College, Cambridge University in 1974 with a bachelor's degree in mathematics and a master's degree in computer science.

Lee began his career in the Singapore Armed Forces, and eventually rose to the rank of brigadier general. He subsequently served in the Cabinet, holding various ministerial portfolios including Minister for Trade and Industry, Minister for Defence and Deputy Prime Minister. He became Prime Minister in 2004, succeeding Goh Chok Tong.

Lee's political career has been marked by efforts to reduce red tape, simplify taxation systems, and attract foreign investment to Singapore. He has also sought to raise Singapore's diplomatic profile and champion the cause of free trade. He has also maintained a social safety net for Singaporeans and advocated Education for All initiatives. He continues to lead the ruling People's Action Party with a comfortable majority, though his frequent cabinet reshuffles have been met with much criticism.

Lee Hsien Loong (Chinese: 李显龙; born 10 February 1952) is a Singaporean politician and the current and third Prime Minister of Singapore since 2004. He is the eldest son of Singapore's first Prime Minister, Lee Kuan Yew. 

Lee graduated with first-class honours from the University of Cambridge in 1974 and later obtained a Master of Public Administration from Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. He served in the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) where he rose to the rank of brigadier general, and was later appointed a cabinet minister by Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong. He became the country's Deputy Prime Minister in 1990 and succeeded Goh as Prime Minister in August 2004. 

Lee is considered the architect of modern Singapore and under his leadership, the country has achieved rapid economic growth, with its per capita GDP increasing largely. He has also pushed for regional integration and has sought to strengthen Singapore's diplomatic relationships, particularly with the United States, China, and India.
