34: Thutmose III (alternatively spelled Djehutymes, given the Greek rendering Thutmōsis or Tuthmosis; thought to be Thoth-born, Thoth being the Egyptian god of wisdom; c. 1507 BC – 1450 BC) was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty. Although often regarded as the greatest, Thutmose III never personally declared himself as pharaoh, nor did he personally declare a co-regency between his reigns. His third regnal year marked the first of a series of campaigns that stretched for almost 25 years and showcased the full extent of his military manoeuvring. He was the first Pharaoh of the New Kingdom to cross the Euphrates in battle and the first to campaign in both Upper and Lower Egypt.

Thutmose III (sometimes read as Thutmosis or Tuthmosis III, Thothmes in older records and c. 1458–1425 BC) was the sixth pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt. He ruled the country for almost 54 years, the longest reigning pharaoh in the New Kingdom. He was a skilled warrior and military leader who brought Egypt to unprecedented power and prosperity during the eighteenth dynasty.

He conducted at least 16 land-based military campaigns and six naval campaigns that allowed him to expand Egypt's borders to the east and south, while not losing any territory. He reorganized the Egyptian bureaucracy, eliminating corruption and unrest, reorganizing the flow of personnel, and abolishing feudalism.

Overall, Thutmose III is often regarded as one of the greatest pharaohs of the New Kingdom for his amazing military accomplishments and for his success in bringing political stability and prosperity to Egypt. He was a great example of an effective ruler and has gone down in history as one of Egypt’s greatest.

Thutmose III (sometimes read as Thutmosis or Tuthmosis III, Thothmes in older history works, and meaning "Thoth is Born") was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt. He ruled from 1479 BC to 1425 BC (Circa). His reign is usually regarded as the zenith of Egypt's New Kingdom and he was described by Herodotus as "the greatest ever". He was regarded as a great conqueror and was involved in a number of campaigns that greatly expanded Egypt's influence in the Near East. He also erected many monuments and temples in Egypt, as well as nationalizing many ancient Egyptian structures. He also built a great number of obelisks and pylons throughout Egypt. He was also known for his successful diplomatic relations with other countries.

Thutmose III (sometimes read as Thutmosis or Tuthmosis III, Thothmes in older history works) was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt. He ruled from 1479-1425 BC in the New Kingdom and is considered to be the greatest military pharaoh of Ancient Egypt. Amenhotep II, the Thutmose's father, had campaigned extensively in the Near East, Thutmose continued the impetus for expansion, claiming the Sinai, Canaan, and part of the Hittite empire for Egypt. During his 33-year reign, Thutmose III launched several military campaigns waged outside of Egypt in Mari, Syria, and other parts of the Levant that had a profound effect on the political landscape of the Middle East. He also restored temples, monuments, and other buildings throughout Egypt.

Thutmose III (sometimes read as Thutmosis III and meaning "Thoth is Born"; also written Djehutymes[3] in older studies) was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt. His reign began in 1479 BC and he became co-regent with his stepmother, Hatshepsut, at the age of six or seven, if not earlier. He then went on to rule for approximately 54 years. During his long reign, he headed 17 major campaigns, subjugated large areas of South West Asia and successfully invaded Nubia twice. He also established diplomatic and trade ties with the Mitanni Empire and built ambitious monuments, such as the Precinct of Amun-Re in Karnak. He is credited to have made the first significant military use of chariots and the first use of the composite bow. He was also the first Egyptian pharaoh to cross the Euphrates river, doing so as far north as Carchemish. 

He was succeeded by his son, Amenhotep II.

Thutmose III (often referred to as Thutmosis or Tuthmosis III and meaning "born of the god Thoth") was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt. He ruled from 1479 BCE to 1425 BCE and is considered to be the greatest military pharaoh who ever lived. He had a lengthy reign of 54 years and is frequently cited as the greatest ruler of the New Kingdom (c. 1550-1070 BCE). Thutmose III strengthened the power of the central government and furthered the development of art and literature. He also expanded the borders of Egypt by campaigning to the north, northeast, and east and bringing parts of Syria, Nubia, and the Sinai Peninsula under his control.

Thutmose III (sometimes read as Thutmosis or Tuthmosis III, and meaning "Thoth is Born") was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt. He ruled Egypt for almost 54 years from approximately 1479 to 1425 BCE, and his reign is usually dated from 1504 to 1450 BCE. He is considered to be Egypt's greatest military leader and one of the most successful in military history. Thutmose III led 17 military campaigns in Syria, Canaan and Nubia, and raised the army of Egypt to one of its greatest heights. His military campaigns are recorded in impressive detail in the ancient records. He also introduced a vast building program that encompassed the construction of various monuments and temples, such as his mortuary temple in Thebes. Thutmose III was an accomplished administrator, and in addition to his military campaigns, he also introduced many taxation and other reforms to Egypt's central government.

Thutmose III (sometimes read as Thutmosis or Tuthmosis III, reigned 1479–1425 BC) was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty. He is commonly regarded as the greatest military pharaoh who ever reigned in Egypt. His reign is usually dated from 1479 BC to 1425 BC. Thutmose III was a warrior pharaoh who expanded Egypt's borders within and beyond Syria, among many other military campaigns, defeating their enemies and enlarging the Egyptian Empire greatly. He appointed governors and established laws and a strong government. Thutmose III was a pious and wise leader who also contributed greatly to Egyptian literature and art, and was a patron of the arts. He would take special interest in musical composition, being a skilled performer and listener, who claimed that “For me, sweetest music is that which comes from the harp's strings.” 

Thutmose III was a highly successful military leader and is known as Egypt's Napoleon. He was the first Pharaoh to cross the Euphrates and reach Babylon and Anatolia. He extended the borders of Egypt farther than ever before, and

Thutmose III (sometimes read as Thutmosis or Tuthmosis III and meaning "Thoth is Born") was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty. Offering his reign as a chief period of expansion and conquest, Thutmose III presided over a remarkable period in Egypt's history, which witnessed the country's new peak in power and prosperity. He sought to extend Egyptian influence in Nubia and the Near East, and invaded the Mitanni Empire in Syria. During his long reign, the Egyptians undertook the penetration of Nubia southward and extended their rule to a maximum of about 150 km (93 mi) of the upper Nile valley. Thutmose III also re-conquered parts of Syria from the Mitanni. He was a master military strategist, who had no rival. Underway was his plan to build a great canal joining the Nile to the Red Sea.

Thutmose III (sometimes read as Thutmosis or Tuthmosis III, Thothmes in older history works; c. 1507–1450 BC according to conventional Egyptian chronology) was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty. Thutmose III was a very active and successful military leader who had a long reign, farther reaching than any other Egyptian Pharaoh of the period. His rule is accepted as being the peak of the Egyptian Empire and he campaigned extensively in the Near East, conquering much of Syria-Palestine, extending Egyptian sphere of influence as far as the Euphrates river and beyond to the southern Levant. He also engaged in campaigns in Asia, where he achieved decisive victories, and was the first pharaoh to reach the upper Euphrates River. Thutmose III is widely considered one of the greatest military commanders in ancient history.

Thutmose III (sometimes read as Thutmosis III; c. 1479 – 8 March 1425 BC) was the sixth pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt. He ruled at the peak of Egypt's imperial conquest in the mid-15th century BC, resulting in an empire that stretched from modern-day Syria to the Sudan. Thutmose III celebrated a sed festival radiating from the city of Memphis and extending circa 2,500 km (1,600 mi) to label his achievements as a powerful ruler. Under his reign, Egypt reached a pinnacle of power; he and his queen, Hatshepsut, commissioned hundreds of projects, resulting in the flourishing of artistic and architectural creations and development of massive building projects in and around Thebes, including his mortuary temple which stands today at Deir el Bahri. His military campaigns and expansions initiated the widespread first use of chariots in battle, forming the backbone of Egypt's military power to come.

Thutmose III (sometimes read as Thutmosis or Tuthmosis III, Thothmes in older history works; c. 1507–1450 BC) was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty. The rule of Thutmose III is quite remarkable due to his successes in both military campaigns and ambitious building projects. He is often regarded as the greatest ruler of the Empire of Ancient Egypt due to his extraordinary tenure, unprecedented military power, and prosperous reign. During his long rule, he led the Egyptian Empire through a full period of prosperity and spread it throughout the Euphrates River. Thutmose III initiated unprecedented building projects such as the construction of the Great Hall of Karnak and the temples of Amun-Re and Ptah at Karnak. His military campaigns extended the Egyptian boundaries from Egypt to Babylon, and the Gaza Strip all the way to Syria. His military campaigns ultimately resulted in Egypt controlling a vast empire.

Thutmose III (also spelled Thutmosis or Tuthmosis III, thoutmosis III, Thothmes III) was the sixth pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt. He ruled from 1479–1425 BC, being a strong and pious ruler in Egypt's New Kingdom. He is considered to be one of the most successful pharaohs, since he expanded Egypt's geographical boundaries, as well as established the Nineteenth Dynasty. He is also credited for re-establishing the Egyptian Empire within the Near East after it had been in decline for the past century. Thutmose III was a skilled diplomat and military General who greatly enhanced his kingdom's wealth. He established diplomatic relations with the kingdom of Mitanni, conquering the lands of Kush and Syria while also making an alliance with Assyria that secured him even greater power in the Near East. He also led several campaigns into Nubia and Libya.

Thutmose III (sometimes read as Thutmosis or Tuthmosis III, Thothmes in older history works; c. 1479 – 8 March 1425 BC[2]) was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty. Offering a military reign of almost 54 years during the New Kingdom, he is regarded as the most successful of all Pharaohs of the New Kingdom. During Thutmose's reign, Egypt reached the height of her wealth, power, and territorial extent: she became the pre-eminent power in the region and gradually became a great military power in the Near East. Some Egyptologists consider Thutmose III to be the greatest Pharaoh in the New Kingdom.

Thutmose III (sometimes read as Thutmosis or Tuthmosis III, Thothmes in older history works) was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt. He ruled from 1479 to 1425 BCE in the New Kingdom of Egypt, and was a military leader. He is considered to be the greatest military commander and strategist of ancient Egypt, and is often regarded as the greatest Pharaoh of the New Kingdom. During his reign he led numerous campaigns in the Near East, extending Egyptian control as far as the Euphrates river, and was a major factor in the rise of Egypt to pre-eminence in the region. He also oversaw the completion of many monuments and buildings, and is remembered for his military successes and for the building projects he commissioned. He built several great monuments, including the Precinct of Amun-Re at Karnak, the Hypostyle Hall at Karnak, the Temple of Amun-Re at Luxor, and the later additions to the Temple of Amun-Re at Karnak.

Thutmose III or Thutmose III of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt, was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty. He ruled from 1479 to 1425 BC during the period of Egypt's greatest prosperity, and was a pious and successful warrior king. He extended Egypt's boundaries and stabilized its merchants in the Near East. He was one of the most prolific builders in ancient Egypt, and commissioned more than 300 temples and shrines across Egypt's many regions and colonies. He was the first king to lead military campaigns beyond Egypt’s traditional borders, expanding the empire across Syria and beyond. He was an early master of diplomatic relations, and successfully negotiated non-aggression pacts with other empires.

Thutmose III (c. 1479–1425 BC) was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty. He ruled for 54 years and is regarded as the greatest military leader of ancient Egypt. He is credited with successfully fending off invaders and expanding Egypt's empire to include Syria and Nubia. He also developed new building and military technology, improved trade with other nations, and fostered a flourishing culture. Thutmose III is sometimes referred to as the "Napoleon of Egypt" due to his considerable military accomplishments. He successfully fought against many enemy armies and suppressed rebellions within Egypt, using both diplomacy and force.

Thutmose III (sometimes read as Thutmosis III, Thothmes III, or Thothmes IIII; c. 1501–1447 BC) was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt. He is known as the Napoleon of Ancient Egypt due to his military genius and he was the most successful Egyptian Pharaoh. He consolidated the empire created by his grandfather, Thutmose I, and expanded Egypt's borders far beyond their native territories. His campaigns, which aimed to extend Egypt's borders to the furthest reaches of Southwest Asia and beyond, laid the foundations for the powerful empire Egypt would become under the New Kingdom. He also personally led a number of military campaigns and battles, both in Egypt and beyond its borders, securing Egypt's expansion and establishing him as one of the great imperial rulers of ancient times. He is also known for commissioning hundreds of monuments and building projects, including the famous Valley of the Kings.

Thutmose III (sometimes read as Thutmosis or Tuthmosis III, Thothmes in older history works), meaning "born of the god Thoth", was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt. Thutmose III was a strong and energetic ruler who greatly expanded Egypt's influence in its three major foreign endeavors — the Nubian campaign in the south and Syria–Palestine in the north, and the trade with Punt in the far south. He also initiated a large building and public works program in Egypt and Nubia, and is often regarded as the greatest of Egypt's warrior Pharaohs. By the age of twenty-two, Thutmose had already begun to expand the frontiers of Egypt and had brought Egypt to the height of its power. He was the first Pharaoh to lead an army out of Egypt on a military campaign, rather than relying on his vassals and allies. During the first campaign, he easily conquered Nubia. After a decade of campaigns, Thutmose III had extended Egypt's borders from Kush in the south to beyond the Orontes River in the

Thutmose III (sometimes read as Thutmosis or Tuthmosis III; c. 1479–1425 BC) was the sixth pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt. He is generally regarded as the greatest monarch of the New Kingdom of Egypt, and was one of the most powerful figures of the ancient world. He is credited with a number of successful military campaigns, an effective administrative system, and an expansion of the Egyptian empire. Thutmose III was a skilled diplomat, statesman and warrior, and known for his tremendous military power, often referred to by early scholars as the "Napoleon of the Nile". During his reign, the Egyptian empire reached the height of its power, and his rule established the basis for a powerful and prosperous Egypt for centuries after his death.

Saul David (born 1954) is a British historian and broadcaster. He is a professor of military history in the Department of War Studies at the University of Birmingham. He was formerly an officer in the British Army and was a visiting professor at the University of Buckingham. 

David's writing explores the history of the British Army and its role in world affairs, but also extends to such topics as the Indian and Pakistani armies and peacekeeping operations. He is the author of more than a dozen books, including the internationally acclaimed two-volume history, The Indian Army, 1860–1914, which was shortlisted for the Duff Cooper Prize and The Jewish Century, which was nominated for the Jewish Quarterly Literature Prize and was named one of New York's 'notable books of 2004'.

Saul David (born 1964) is a British historian, academic and broadcaster. He is a professor of military history at the University of Buckingham and a visiting professor of International History at King's College London. He was previously professor of strategy and security at Exeter University. He is the author of several history books, focused mainly on wars of the modern era. These include Victoria's Wars: The Rise of Empire (2011), All the King's Men: The Greatest Battle of the Indian Mutiny (2009) and Monsoon: The Indian Ocean and the Future of American Power (2010). He has contributed to national newspapers and magazines, documentaries, radio and television programmes.

Saul David (born 1959) is a British historian and broadcaster who specializes in military history. He is Dean of the Faculty of Arts, Humanities and Social Sciences at the University of Buckingham.

David has written numerous books on military history, focusing on the two world wars and the interwar period. His books include The Indian Empire At War (2001); Zulu: The Heroism and Tragedy of the Zulu War of 1879 (2004); Churchill's Sacrifice of the Highland Division: France 1940 (2005); and Th eHomelanders: A Novel (2007). In 2011 he published a biography of General Sir Charles James Napier, one of Victorian Britain's most eminent military commanders.

David also regularly appears on TV, radio and podcasts discussing Britain's military history. He has narrated or featured in programmes including How We Won The War – two-part series for the BBC, several documentaries for the National Geographic, and a three-part series on Attenborough's "Great War" on Channel 4. David is a regular guest on the BBC Radio 4's long-running programme In Our Time.

Saul David (born 1964) is a British military historian, author, and journalist. He is Professor of Strategic Studies at the University of Exeter and a Senior Fellow at the International Institute for Strategic Studies. His books focus on the military history of the British Empire and Commonwealth, including the major conflicts in India, Africa, and the Middle East.

He studied at Magdalene College, Cambridge and then joined the British Army in 1986 serving in the Royal Green Jackets before joining the staff of the International Institute for Strategic Studies. From 2001-4 he was Professor of War Studies at the University of Wales, Aberystwyth.

Saul David is a Member of the Council of the British Commission for Military History and a Fellow of the Royal Historical Society. He was awarded an MBE for services to higher education in the Queen's Birthday Honours list in 2005. He has presented television documentaries such as Guns and Tigers: The Soldiers of Queen Victoria's Empire, aired in 2006.

Saul David (born Thupateni David Saul, c. 1915 – c. 1985) was a veteran of World War II and a major contributor to the growth of the Nigerian film industry. He was an active member of the Nigerian film industry from the 1950s to the 1980s and his name is synonymous with the growth and development of Nigerian films.

Saul was born in the Igbo-dominated southeast of Nigeria and was one of the earliest practitioners of Nigerian films. He wrote, produced, and directed several films, often with his wife and five children acting in them. He was known for his "no-nonsense" directing style and was often nicknamed "Saul the Terror" for his intensity and strictness. His films explored a variety of subject matter, from poverty to religion to politics. Saul was also credited with inventing the low-budget, slapstick style of filmmaking in Nigeria and even coined the term Nollywood in 1968.

The legacy of Saul David is an important part of cultural history in Nigeria. His work is seen as the foundation of modern Nigerian film, and his influence can still be felt in many aspects of

Saul David (born 11 May 1965) is a British historian, broadcaster and author Specialising in Military History. He is a professor at the University of Buckingham, member of the British Commission for Military History and has written several books about military history. His books have covered a range of periods and topics, including the Battle of Britain, post-World War II British Army, and the Crimean War. Saul David is an experienced television presenter and regularly contributes to BBC radio programmes. He also appears regularly on TV programmes such as Newsnight and BBC Breakfast. His most recent books, Zulu: The Heroism and Tragedy of the Zulu War of 1879 and Greek Fire: The Story of Maria Callas and Aristole Onassis, were critically acclaimed.

Saul David (born 20 April 1971) is a British historian and broadcaster. He was educated at Warwick School, Worcester College, Oxford and the University of London.

He is the author of several books, including a biography of the First World War poet Wilfred Owen, Who Died For England? (2002), Zulu: The Heroic Gallantry of the Defiant Zulu Nation against the British Empire (2004) and Churchill's Sacrifice of the Highland Division: France 1940 (2005). He is a regular broadcaster for BBC Radio 4 and is the series presenter of recent History documentaries. Most recently Saul has released a new book 'The Indian Mutiny: 1857' (2018). He has also written for History Today and for newspapers such as The Guardian, Daily Mail and The Times.

Saul David (born 1960) is a British historian, military expert, and broadcaster. He has written extensively about British military history and the history of the Middle East. He is the author of several award-winning books including Victoria's Wars: The Rise of Empire (Short-Listed for the 2002 Whitbread History Prize) and Zulu: The Heroic History of the Zulu War (Winner of the 2007 Hessell-Tiltman Prize). He is a frequent contributor to radio and television programmes, and has served as a consultant on various military-themed films. His most recent book is Britain's Great War, a narrative history of World War I.

Saul David (born in 1966) is a British historian, author, and broadcaster. He is best known for his military histories, particularly his acclaimed 2003 study Zulu: The Heroism and Tragedy of the Zulu War of 1879, which was shortlisted for the 2003 Cundill Prize and Longman History Today Trustees' Award. His 2019 book, Victoria's Wars: The Rise of Empire, was listed by The Times as one of their Top 10 History Books of the Year and by The Sunday Times as one of its 100 Best Books of 2019. In addition to his written works, Saul is a regular broadcaster on BBC Radio 4 and a Professor at the University of Buckingham.

Saul David (born 12 August 1954) is a British military historian, broadcaster, and award-winning author. He has written thirteen books, including the acclaimed works Zulu, Victoria's Wars and 100 Days To Victory. He is a professor at the University of Buckingham, fellow of the Royal Historical Society and consultant historian to the Imperial War Museum.

David is a regular commentator on the BBC and in 2008, he presented a nine-part television series on the Indian Mutiny, Besieged. He is also the presenter of the acclaimed documentary series Battlefield Britain, Saints and Sinners and The Monarchy. His family is descended from the Welsh fusiliers who fought at Rorke's Drift in 1879 during the Anglo-Zulu war. In 2003 he was awarded an MBE for services to defence studies.

Saul David (born July 29, 1966) is a British historian and broadcaster, best known for his award-winning books on British military history. He was educated at Balliol College, Oxford, obtaining a PhD in International Relations. Saul currently serves as Professor of Leadership in the Department of War Studies at King's College London, and is also the Chair of the university's Military Sciences Department.

His writing focuses on contemporary history and the Royal Navy, with several of his books covering the period from the late 19th century to the present day. He has written biographies of General Gordon, Montgomery of Alamein, General Slim and David Lloyd George, as well as books on the Falklands War and the First World War. His book Warrior Race: A History of the British at War was awarded the Wolfson Prize in 2001. Saul has also written for newspapers and magazines about British military history, and regularly appears on radio and television programmes as an expert commentator.

Saul David (born 1963) is a Professor of Military History at the University of Buckingham, and author of several books on military history, as well as a television historian and presenter.

He is best known for his books Zulu: The Heroism and Tragedy of the Zulu War of 1879, Churchill's Sacrifice of the Highland Division, The Indian Mutiny: 1857 and All the King's Men: The British Army and the Beginning of the Great War, as well as presenting television series, including Britain's Greatest Generals and Hero of Waterloo, both for UKTV channel Yesterday.

Saul David (born 1972) is a British historian and broadcaster. A professor of strategy and security at University of Exeter, he is an expert on twentieth century military history.

David was born in England in 1972. He attended Trinity College at the University of Cambridge, and later St Antony's College, Oxford. After graduation, he joined the British Army as an officer in the Intelligence Corps, and served in Bosnia in 1995. Following this, he returned to Oxford to take his master’s degree in Modern History. And in 2000 he received his D.Phil. in Modern History from St. Antony's College.

David has since held various posts in academic institutions around the United Kingdom, including at the Defence Academy of the United Kingdom and St Andrew's University. He was also a visiting professor at King's College London from 2003-2005. He is the author of several books on military history, including Operation Thunderbolt: Flight 139 and the Raid on Entebbe Airport; God of Battles: A Study of War in Ancient and Modern Times; Zulu: The Heroic Last Stand at Rorke’s Drift; and The

Saul David (born 1969) is a British historian and broadcaster, best known for his work on British military history and his popular BBC Radio 4 and BBC2 series, Battlefield Britain. Originally from Cardiff, he took degrees in history at Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge and University College, London. He is the author of several books on the military history of the British Isles, including The Indian Mutiny (2003), Zulu: The Heroism and Tragedy of the Zulu War of 1879 (2004) and Victoria’s Wars: The Rise of Empire (2007). His most recent book is The Homicidal Earl: The Life of Lord Cardigan (2019), a biography of Crimean War hero Lord Cardigan.

Saul David (born 1962) is a British military historian and author. He has written extensively on military history, as well as on intelligence, diplomacy and international relations. David was educated at Exeter College, Oxford, and the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst. He is currently Professor of War Studies at the University of Buckingham, Director of the Centre for Leadership and Public Values, and Senior Fellow of Birmingham University's International Education Centre.

David has written and presented several television documentaries, including the acclaimed 3-part series on the history of the Israel–Palestine conflict, Israel: A History (1999). He has also presented a series on the factors behind the rising tide of international terrorism, including the first television interviews with Osama bin Laden in 1997. He has edited a number of books and is the author of more than 18 authored and co-authored books. These include the 2016 British Army on Campaign series, published in association with the UK's National Army Museum.

Saul David is a British historian, broadcaster and author. He is currently Professor of Military History at the University of Buckingham and Senior Fellow at the Brookings Institution. He has taught at Sandhurst, served in the British Army, been British Defence Attaché in Kabul and marked the centenary of the Great War in France and Belgium with the British Royal Family.

He is the author of several books on British military history, notably Zulu: The Heroism and Tragedy of the Zulu War of 1879, Victoria's Wars: The Rise of Empire and Wall of Guns: The Battle of Rorkes Drift. He has also written extensively on the modern wars in Iraq, Syria and Afghanistan. His latest book, In Sight of Tiberias: The Great War in the Holy Land, is published in July 2018. He has written many articles in publications such as The Guardian and The Daily Telegraph. He appears regularly on television and radio and is a familiar face at defence and security conferences.

Saul David (Hebrew: שאול דוד, born 30 June 1981)[1] is an Israeli historian and author. He is the author of the critically acclaimed histories Blood and Fire (2002), Operation Thunderbolt (2007) and The Fight for Jerusalem (2007).

Saul David was born in Jerusalem, but raised in South London. He was educated at Latymer Upper School in London, and became interested in the history of the Holocaust and the Israeli–Palestinian conflict at a young age. After reading History and Politics at Oxford University he completed a Master of Studies in War Studies at King's College London and a doctorate in Modern History at Jesus College, Oxford.

He is a regular commentator on military history and current affairs, appearing on television and radio programmes around the world as an expert on contemporary conflict and diplomacy. He has held visiting fellowships at Harvard and King's College London, where he is a Senior Research Fellow in War Studies.

Saul David (born 1963) is a British historian and professor at the University of Buckingham. He is best known for his books about British military history and the history of British India. "Nodar Kumaritashvili (Georgian: ნოდარ კურმარითაშვილი; February 17, 1988 – February 12, 2010) was a Georgian luger who died during a training run at the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver. He was the first athlete to die during a Winter Olympics competition or related training activities. 

Kumaritashvili came from the Georgian-speaking minority in the south west of Azerbaijan, listed as an endangered language by UNESCO. He began competing in the luge in 2003 and became the first Georgian to compete in luge in an Olympics. He was one of five debutants on the team and his best finish in the 2009-10 Luge World Cup before the Olympics was 13th.

He flew to Canada 10 days before the accident for his second Winter Olympics competition. On February 12, Kumaritashvili died

Kermit Davis (born October 8, 1959) is an American college basketball coach, currently the head coach at Middle Tennessee State University (MTSU). He previously coached at Idaho, Louisiana Tech, and Texas A&M, and held his first head coaching job at Campbellsville University, beginning in 1985. 

A native of Pikeville, Kentucky, Davis starred at basketball in high school and later attended Transylvania University, where he started all four years as a point guard and graduated with a degree in physical education in 1981. After briefly attending graduate school, he moved to the college coaching ranks with a female assistant coach job at Georgetown College and then head coaching job at Campbellsville. In 1987, he moved to Idaho where he coached for seven seasons before landing the head coaching job at Louisiana Tech in 1994. 

Davis would be at Louisiana Tech for 12 years and achieved success, including reaching the NIT twice, winning the 2005 WAC Tournament, and making the NCAA Tournament in 2006. After being hired by Texas A&M in 2016, he moved to Middle Tennessee in 2018. He guided MTSU to the

Kermit Davis (born June 4, 1965) is an American college basketball coach who currently serves as the head coach of the University of Mississippi men's basketball team. After spending 16 seasons as the head coach at Middle Tennessee (since 2002), Davis became just the fourth head coach in Ole Miss history on March 15, 2018.

During his 16-year tenure at Middle Tennessee, Davis compiled the most wins in school history (332) and was named the 2017 Conference USA Coach of the Year. In addition, he led Middle Tennessee to its first NCAA tournament victory in 2016, a 90-81 upset win over Michigan State as a 15-seed.

Kermit O. Davis (born February 15, 1956) is an American basketball coach. He is currently the head men's basketball coach at Middle Tennessee State University in Murfreesboro, Tennessee.

A graduate of the University of Mississippi, Davis began his coaching career as an assistant coach for the Ole Miss Rebels under Ed Murphy in 1985. He was named head coach at Texas A&M University-Commerce in 1990, leading the Lions to a 206–2012 record and NAIA National Championship in 1993. He was named head coach at Idaho in 1994, where he compiled a 148–89 record through 2000. Following his stint at Idaho, Davis was the head coach at New Orleans from 2000 to 2006, where he posted a 112–88 record. In 2006, Kermit accepted the head coach position at Middle Tennessee State University, and led the Blue Raiders to their first NCAA tournament berth in 2016. That same year, the Blue Raiders upset Michigan State in the 2017 NCAA tournament, one of the biggest upsets in NCAA tournament history. Davis has overseen eight NCAA tournament appearances (2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, and 20

Kermit Davis Jr. (born November 18, 1964) is an American college basketball coach. He is currently the head coach of the Mississippi State Bulldogs men's basketball team. Davis previously coached for 16 seasons at Middle Tennessee, where he led the Blue Raiders to four NCAA tournament appearances and four regular season conference championships. 

Davis began his coaching career in 1987 as a graduate assistant at Vanderbilt University, where he would help lead the team to the Elite Eight of the 1988 NCAA Tournament. He moved on to be an assistant coach at several different schools, including Idaho, Oregon, Kansas and LSU before becoming the head coach at Middle Tennessee in 2002. Davis had immediate success at Middle Tennessee and in his sixteen seasons with the Blue Raiders he compiled a 282–186 record, including four regular season conference championships and four NCAA tournament appearances.

"Kermit Davis (born March 18, 1955) is an American college basketball coach, currently the head coach of the Ole Miss Rebels men's basketball program. Prior to this position, Davis had been the head coach of Middle Tennessee for 16 seasons, amassing an overall record of 327–187 (.635). At Middle Tennessee, he had the most wins in program history, winning over 20 games in each of the last 10 seasons. In 2016, Davis led the Blue Raiders to a Conference USA tournament title and their first-ever NCAA tournament victory.

Davis earned his bachelor's degree in health and physical education from The University of Tennessee at Martin in 1977. He also earned a master's degree from UT Martin in 1979. He spent his first two college coaching seasons as an assistant with his alma mater, UT Martin, under his former head coach, Phil Snowden."

Kermit Davis (born July 29, 1956) is an American college basketball coach. He is currently the head coach of the Ole Miss Rebels men's basketball team. Davis was previously the head coach of the Middle Tennessee Blue Raiders men's basketball team, where he led the team to four NCAA tournament appearances in his 16 seasons. Before taking the Middle Tennessee job in 2002, Davis spent 11 seasons as the head men's basketball coach of the Texas A&M Aggies, leading the team to three NCAA tournament appearances.

Kermit Davis Jr. (born June 17, 1958) is an American college basketball coach. Davis is the current head coach of the University of Mississippi men's basketball team, a position he has held since the start of the 2017–18 season. He previously served as head coach of Middle Tennessee State University (MTSU) for 16 seasons, during which he compiled a 332–187 overall record, including an NCAA Tournament appearance in 2017. Davis has also served as head coach at Texas A&M, Idaho, and Arizona State. Davis is a two-time Conference USA Coach of the Year, having been recognized in 2009 and 2018, and led MTSU to four conference championships. His father, Kermit Davis Sr., was a college basketball coach at the University of Toledo and later at the University of Idaho.

Kermit Davis Sr. (born December 29, 1957) is an American college basketball coach and current head coach of the Mississippi State Bulldogs of the Southeastern Conference (SEC). He was previously head coach of Middle Tennessee State, leading the Blue Raiders to four NCAA Tournament appearances. He was also the head coach at Idaho, Texas A&M-Corpus Christi, and Central Arkansas.

Davis began his coaching career as a high school coach in 1980, serving as the head coach at Florence High School in Florence, Alabama until 1984. He then went on to serve as the top assistant at Chipola Junior College (1985) and Idaho (1986–1990) before becoming interim head coach of the Vandals in December 1990. He was promoted to permanent head coach in February 1991, and he was at Idaho until 1994. In December 1994, Davis took over at Texas A&M–Corpus Christi, where he stayed until March 1998, when he became the head coach at Central Arkansas. He stayed at Central Arkansas until 2001.

Kermit Davis Jr. (born April 4, 1961) is an American college basketball coach. He is the current men's basketball head coach at University of Mississippi (Ole Miss). Davis led the Rebels to an NCAA Tournament berth in his first season at the helm of the program in 2018. In his 18 seasons as a head coach at the NCAA Division I level, Davis has won four regular season conference championships and six conference tournament championships. Prior to Ole Miss, Davis was head coach at Middle Tennessee, leading the Blue Raiders to five postseason berths in 11 years, including four trips to the NCAA Tournament and one NIT Final Four.

Prior to his arrival in Murfreesboro, Davis served eleven seasons at the helm of Texas A&M–Corpus Christi and a single season rebuilding an Oklahoma State squad that had been decimated by NCAA sanctions.

Kermit Davis (born August 20, 1957) is an American college basketball coach. He is currently the head coach for the Auburn Tigers of the Southeastern Conference (SEC). Davis previously served as the head coach at Middle Tennessee from 2002 to 2016 and prior to that at Idaho from 1998 to 2002. Davis won the 2013 Conference USA Men's Basketball Coach of the Year and led Middle Tennessee to the NCAA Sweet Sixteen in the 2016 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament, one of the biggest upsets in NCAA Tournament history. His teams have been known for their tenacious defense, with Middle Tennessee leading the nation in scoring defense in 2014.

Kermit Davis (born June 22, 1958) is an American college basketball coach who is currently the head men's basketball coach at Texas A&M University. He was previously the head coach at Middle Tennessee State University, where he led the Blue Raiders to two NCAA Tournaments and four NIT appearances. Davis also coached at Idaho, Dallas Baptist University, Lamar, and Texas A&M–Commerce. He was the SEC Coach of the Year in 2017 and won the 2018 Conference USA Tournament Championship with Middle Tennessee State.

Kermit Douglas Davis (born December 24, 1959) is an American college basketball coach and the current men's head coach at Ole Miss. He was the head coach at Middle Tennessee from 2002 to 2018, where he was the NCAA's all-time leader among current Division I coaches in win percentage with a record of 332–165, giving him an overall win percentage of .668. He also is the current Southeastern Conference (SEC) coach with the highest winning percentage of any active coach in all NCAA divisions.

Prior to his tenure at Middle Tennessee, Davis held head coaching positions at four other universities: Idaho, Texas–Arlington, Texas–El Paso, and Appalachian State. Davis guided MTSU to seven NCAA Tournament appearances and four regular season championships, including a Conference USA regular season championship in 2017. Davis is a former player and assistant coach of the University of Alabama's men's basketball team. In 2020, he became the first coach in NCAA Division I basketball history to lead a team to the NCAA tournament after his institute was sentenced to a postseason ban.

Kermit Davis Jr. (born April 5, 1959) is an American college basketball coach, currently head men's basketball coach at the University of Mississippi. He was the head coach at Middle Tennessee State, where he coached for 16 seasons, from 2002 to 2018. Davis led the Blue Raiders to national prominence, with eight NCAA tournament appearances from 2009 to 2018, winning the First Four matchup in 2017 en route to the round of 32 against Butler.

Davis was named the SEC Coach Of The Year in his first season with the Rebels, guiding the team to a 20–11 record, a share of the SEC regular-season title, and a No. 5 seed in the NCAA tournament. After topping Oklahoma in the first round, the Rebels lost in the second round to eventual national champion and No. 1 seed Virginia.

Kermit Davis and the Ole Miss Rebels opened the 2017–18 season with excitement and optimism, after having won the 2017 Southeastern Conference (SEC) Tournament in what was an historic season for the Rebels. They returned just three starters from that year, however, and quickly hit a few bumps in the road early on. Despite this, Davis’s optimism was unshaken; down the stretch, Ole Miss finished strong with 18 wins in their last 25 games and a berth in the NCAA Tournament. 

They gave eventual Sweet Sixteen participant Texas Tech—coached by future Olympic gold medalist and Naismith Coach of the Year, Chris Beard—their only loss in non-conference play. This experience paid off as the Rebels made it to the NCAA Tournament for the fourth time in ten seasons. Davis and his squad earned the eight seed in the South Region, and their first tournament victory since 2001, beating Oklahoma in the opening round before falling to Xavier in the Round of 32.

"Kermit Davis Jr. (born May 27, 1959) is an American college basketball coach who is the current head coach of the Middle Tennessee Blue Raiders men's basketball team. Davis formerly coached the Mississippi Rebels from 2018–2020 and previously held head coaching positions at Texas A&M–Corpus Christi, Idaho, and Troy University. From 2002–2011, Davis was an assistant for both the Clemson Tigers and the Mississippi State Bulldogs."

Kermit Davis (born July 29, 1956) is an American college basketball head coach. He is the current head men's basketball coach at the University of Mississippi (Ole Miss), and was previously head coach at Texas A&M University, Middle Tennessee State University, Idaho, and Davidson College. Davis is best known for having won the 2002 NCAA Tournament with the Middle Tennessee State Blue Raiders. He led Middle Tennessee to five NCAA tournaments, three National Invitational Basketball Tournaments, and four conference championships over his 16 seasons.

Kermit Davis Jr. (born December 23, 1964) is an American basketball coach who is the current head coach of the Ole Miss Rebels men's basketball team. Davis was previously the head coach at Middle Tennessee State University (MTSU), where he led the Blue Raiders to two NCAA tournament appearances and won the 2016 Conference USA tournament. Prior to MTSU, Davis was the head coach at Idaho, Texas A&M–Corpus Christi, and Troy. He was named the 2019 SEC Coach of the Year after leading the Rebels to the NCAA tournament for the first time since 2015.

Kermit Davis Jr. (born April 28, 1960) is an American college basketball coach who currently is the head coach of the Mississippi State Bulldogs men's basketball team. Davis was previously the head coach of Middle Tennessee State and Texas A&M–Corpus Christi (where he became the first head coach in school history). He has also been an assistant coach at LSU and Indiana, and coached at Idaho and Idaho State.

Davis notably led Middle Tennessee State to five NCAA Tournaments, including a shock upset win over Michigan State in the 2016 NCAA Tournament. The win has been called one of the most significant upsets in NCAA Tournament history. After 16 seasons at MTSU, Davis left for his alma mater, Mississippi State, who finished as runner-up to Villanova in the 2018 National Championship. This made Davis the first coach to take two mid-major programs to the NCAA Tournament.

Kermit Davis Jr. (born April 1, 1960) is an American college basketball coach. He is the head men's basketball coach at the University of Mississippi, a position he has held since the 2017–18 season. Prior to Ole Miss, Davis served as head coach at Middle Tennessee State University, Texas A&M University–Corpus Christi, Idaho, and Davidson.

Davis has been an assistant at Louisiana Tech and Denver, and was an assistant at New Mexico from 2002 to 2006, serving as associate head coach from 2004 to 2006. During his five seasons in Tempe, Arizona, from 2006 to 2011, Davis led Arizona State to the NCAA Tournament twice and a National Invitation Tournament title. Davis was hired to lead Middle Tennessee State University's men's basketball program on May 1, 2011. In his second season, he led the Blue Raiders to the NCAA Tournament. Davis led Middle Tennessee to three NCAA tournament appearances from 2013–17. He accepted the head coaching position at Ole Miss on March 15, 2017.

Kermit Davis Jr. (born April 14, 1955) is an American college basketball coach and the current head coach at Mississippi State University. He previously served as the head coach at Middle Tennessee State University, Texas A&M University, Idaho, and New Orleans.

Davis was hired as Mississippi State's head coach on March 24, 2018. Prior to joining the Bulldogs, Davis earned his 300th career win at Middle Tennessee State University in March 2018 and went on to finish the season with 297 victories in 11 seasons. Davis led the Blue Raiders to three NCAA Tournament berths, including two in his final two seasons. At Texas A&M, Davis won the 2010 Big 12 Coach of the Year, posting a school-record 26 wins in 2006–07 — securing the Aggies' first NCAA tournament berth since 1987. He also posted a school-record 25 wins at Idaho in 1998–99, leading the Vandals to an NCAA Tournament appearance. Davis is a three-time conference coach of the year. In his first season at Mississippi State, Davis guided the Bulldogs to a 23-11 record and an NCAA Tournament appearance.
39: Modibo Adama (1820–1876) was the first Almami (leader of an Islamic theocracy) of the Wassoulou Empire in what is now Mali. Adama was born in 1820 in Siby, Mali. He was an early convert to Islam and soon rose to prominence as an Islamic teacher. Later, he became the leader of a Muslim jihad (holy war) against French colonialism and resistance to the Fulani Empire in the Wassoulou region. He was successful in unifying a number of disparate groups in the area, allowing them to fight a successful guerrilla war against the French forces. In 1864, he crowned himself Almami, formally creating the Wassoulou Empire and making himself the supreme political and religious ruler. He died in 1876, leaving a legacy of a powerful empire that survived until French colonization in the 1890s.

Modibo Adama (born c. 1950) is a Nigerian lawyer, legal scholar and traditional ruler who served as the Grand Nasara of the Adama Kingdom. He holds the traditional title of Sarkin Adama and is a member of the Central Council of the Fulani. He is a great-grandson of Modibo Adama, the hero of the Fulani Jihad who led a pan-regional revolt against the Sokoto Caliphate. As Grand Nasara he is the head of the Wadai-Sokoto-Fulani, commonly referred to as the Nasara, and leads their political, economic, cultural and spiritual affairs in Nigeria. He is a vocal proponent of Fulani rights and has contributed to the preservation of Fulani culture, tradition and language in Nigeria. He has also been active in inter-ethnic dialogue in Nigeria and advocating for peace and stability in the country.

Modibo Adama (1820–1868) was a West African statesman and warrior king who reigned over the Adamawa region of present-day Nigeria and Cameroon. Adama was born in 1820 near the town of Gombi and studied at Yanadu Zanaga. Adama rose to prominence as a great leader in 1841 when he lead a revolt among the Fulani chiefs of Adamawa, leading them to victory over the Mandé peoples of the Nupe and Tiv. He subsequently became the King of Adamawa, and his rule was characterized by a period of peace, stability, and prosperity throughout the area. Adama is credited for creating centralized governance and for helping to promote literacy among the population. He implemented a taxation system, established trade networks and markets, and diversified the economy of the region. He died in 1868, leaving a legacy of a peaceful and prosperous kingdom.

Modibo Adama (1847–1920) was a Malian religious leader of the Islamic Tijaniyyah Sufi brotherhood from the Ségou Region of Mali. He is considered a national hero in Mali for his leadership in resisting French colonization, and for successfully unifying Mali's diverse ethnic and religious groups in the face of French expansion. He was born in the village of Belenaba, near Hamdallaye along the Niger River in 1847. In 1887, modibo Adama founded the Bondo Society, a Sufi brotherhood organised to resist French colonial rule. He organised a series of uprisings against the French between 1890 and 1899, which culminated in a major joint Jihadi operation against French forces in 1898. Adama died in 1920, but his legacy continued to inspire the struggle for Malian independence.

Modibo Adama was a West African lawyer and politician. He was a founder of the movement that fought to gain independence for what is now Mali. Adama was born in 1896 in the small village of Koulikoro in the Timbuktu region of Mali. Adama went on to obtain a law degree in Paris in the mid-1920s, and was one of the first Africans to practice as a lawyer in Mali.

Adama joined the struggle for Malian independence, becoming the leader of the (National) Union of the Peoples of Mali (U.P.M.) He was one of the founders of the African Democratic Rally, which was active in the French colonial empire. He was the first president of the U.P.M., and became leader of the Unified Mali Movement, a political party which sought the end of the French colonial rule of Mali. He served as Ambassador to France and the United States, representing the Free Mali government of Modibo Keïta, before becoming Minister of Foreign Affairs. Adama was an important figure in the independence struggle, but also an important leader in the transition to a free, independent

Modibo Adama (1820–1880) was an influential Islamic scholar, philosopher and political leader in West Africa. He was born in the kingdom of Macina, in present-day central Mali, to a father who belonged to an old royal lineage of Fulani. His family belonged to the ruling keita dynasty of the Layenne ruling house and Modibo was trained in the Islamic sciences as well as politics and diplomacy.

During his lifetime, Modibo helped to spread the Islamic knowledge and teachings to West Africa, and his influence was considerable. He wrote many books on religion, philosophy and political science, and travelled widely in Africa teaching people he met. In addition, he founded a center of Milletism in Segu. Milletism was an important political movement in West Africa that called for the unity of Muslims by recognizing the Adhan and following the Islamic Faith.

Modibo was an important political figure and ruler, leading the Macina region during several periods of instability in the late 19th century. He was an influential figure in the 1881 war, and was consulted as an authority on all aspects of the conflict, including

Modibo Adama (also known as Adam Modibo Diarra; born c. 1925 in Ségou, Mali, d. Oct 6, 1980 in Bamako, Mali) was a Malian politician who served as the Prime Minister of the Republic of Mali from 1968 to 1974. He was a highly respected leader who sought to promote unity, peace, and economic growth through his tenure. He was born into an educated and privileged family and received an Ecole Normale Superieure education. Adama was an early advocate of a united Africa, and went on to pursue public office in the Republic of Mali, winning major victories in council elections and ultimately becoming Prime Minister.

During his period as Prime Minister, Modibo Adama focused on economic growth and national unity. He increased the corpus of investments in public infrastructure and designed novel policies to attract foreign investments from US and French firms. His promotion of African unity found expression in the promotion of cultural exchange and collaboration between Mali and other countries on the African continent, and in his permanent advocacy for peaceful solutions to conflicts. Modibo Adama's tenure as Prime Minister ended with a political scandal involving

Modibo Adama (died 1875) otherwise known as Modibo Keïta, was a West African political leader, ruler of the Masina (or Massina/Massinissa) Empire in what is now part of Mali. He was born in Sikasso, in his mother's home of the Sissoko family. His father, Saman Donno, was one of the nyamakalaw ("blacksmiths") of the conquered Konate Empire. Upon his father's death, Modibo Adama succeeded him as chief of the Sissoko family and ruler of the Masina Empire.

Adama is recognized in his native Mali as the first ruler to attempt to unify the many tribes of the area, declaring war on neighbouring communities, often in order to expand his empire. He was an egalitarian ruler, concerned with peace and justice above all else, and his reign brought stability and progress to the region. He also fought off French forces, which had begun to move into the region by the mid-1800s. In 1868, the French invasion of his territory led to the defeat of Modibo Adama

Modibo Adama (1832–1883) was a West African Muslim ruler and significant figure in the history of the Mandinka people of Mali. He is known for his military campaigns in the 19th century against the Bambara Empire, and for his momentous decision to convert to Islam in 1848. He is recognized as a major religious and political leader who united his people during a period of great instability in that region, and who declared himself "Almami" or "king" of the Mandinka people. Adama was an important figure in the spread of Islam among the Malian people, and as such, he is considered to be a pioneer in the history of the Senegambia region.

Modibo Adama (1844–1920) was an African resistance leader, who led an uprising of the "Toucouleur Empire" in the late 19th century. Born to a nomadic family in western Mali, Adama was a member of the Fulani people, a nomadic ethnic group in Western Africa. After participating in various battles for the Toucouleur empire against its enemies, he was appointed Salifu (Sultan) in 1881, and established a strong base in Mopti. During the 1890s, he led the Toucouleur army in a series of successful raids, culminating in the conquest of the Kingdom of Segu in 1895. He successfully defended the kingdom from French colonial forces in 1897, and afterwards became known as the "Lion of Segu". He continued to resist French colonialism into the 20th century, and is regarded as a national hero of Mali to this day.

Modibo Adama (7 June 1908 – 27 August 1984) was a Malian political leader and prime minister who helped gain independence for Mali from France in 1960. He was the leader of several Malian political parties including the Union Soudanaise-Rassemblement Démocratique Africain (US-RDA). Adama was one of the most influential politicians in Mali's turbulent post-colonial history, leading the country through several important elections and playing a key role in implementing policies. He was also the first president of Mali's constituent assembly, as well as serving as mayor of Bamako from 1961 to 1962.

Modibo Adama (also Modibo Keïta; July 29, 1915 – May 16, 1977) was the first President of Mali from 1960 to 1968. He came to power after leading a successful uprising against French colonial rule. Adama was a leader of the Africanist and nationalist political organization, the Sudanese Union-African Democratic Rally, which opposed French plans to divide Mali and to give the northern part of the country greater autonomy. He was also a powerful proponent of pan-Africanism. He was arrested in 1968, along with other leaders of the Union, after a failed coup d’état attempt, and was held in detention until his death in 1977. Adama's legacy as the first President of Mali has been honored with several memorials scattered all over the country.

"Modibo Adama (died 1845) was an Adamawa Emir born into a Fulani family in either 1807 or 1808. He was a contemporary of Umar Tal and participated in various wars during his lifetime, but his greatest achievement was leading the wartime alliance between northern Adamawa Fulanis and the Toucouleur empire of El Hajj Umar Tall in 1845 to fight the southern Adamawa Fulfulde settlers. He died soon after the conquest of the Futa Jallon in 1845, at the age of approximately 37."

Modibo Adama (1847–1922), known as Modibo Keita and Birri-beso or Birriwarmay (Father of the Revolution), was a legendary Malian soldier, soldier-king, monarch, spiritual leader, and moral force of resistance and freedom. He is widely considered to be the founder of the modern nation of Mali, and his revolutionary accomplishments in uniting disparate Malian forces behind a common cause and a unified purpose are seen as a source of Malian patriotism and national pride. Modibo Adama was born into the Keita (Goumba) Sidibe family of Segou, in what is now Mali, who had long been a powerful clan of local kings. His father, Almany Keita, was the local ruler and a member of an ancient tradition dating back to the Mali Empire. Modibo Adama rose to prominence in the mid-1890s when he led a revolt against French colonialism, which at the time controlled much of West Africa. Adama was known for his courage and tenacity, and he played a pivotal role in securing Mali's independence from French rule. He also created

Modibo Adama (1885–1922) was a West African leader known as the founder of the Wassoulou Empire in present-day southern Mali. Following a trend of other military leaders at the time, he established the Wassoulou Empire in 1898 and declared himself Emperor of Wassoulou.

Adama was a born in the village of Kireni in present-day Mali. He was a Soninke, the region's dominant ethnic group during that period. He was a soldier in the regional ruler's army and eventually rose to the rank of commander. In 1898, he declared himself emperor of the Wassoulou Empire which consisted of 44 villages in the region. He appointed village chiefs in each of the villages and increased trade between them.

Adama's primary goal was to protect his people from French colonial rule and expansion. To this end, he created a strong military and had alliances with nearby kingdoms such as Bondu, Kaarta, and other countries. He also adopted a policy of military neutrality in order to avoid conflict. His success at maintaining Wassoulou's independence served as an example to other West African leaders

Modibo Adama (1845-1922) was a leader of the Songhai Empire, which controlled the western Sudan of modern-day Mali. Adama reigned between 1881 and 1893.

He came to power after defeating the previous Mansa, El Hadj Omar Tall, in a battle fought on the east bank of the Niger River in May of 1881. Adama then proclaimed himself Emperor of the Segu Empire, and renaming himself Modibo Keïta, began to centralize his power. He created a professional army and civil service, reorganizing the judicial system, and modernizing education and communications.

Keïta worked to combine the various ethnic and religious groups of the empire into a more unified nation, and strived to suppress aspects of the traditional animistic beliefs of the people in favor of Islam. He also pursued many diplomatic alliances and military campaigns in order to expand the Songhai Empire’s borders, though he never achieved this goal. 

Ultimately, however, Modibo Keïta’s reforms were unsuccessful in stopping the French conquest of the area which began in 1890 and ended

Modibo Adama (1760-1817), also known as Almami Adama, was an Islamic scholar and Fulani Alim Amadu (spiritual leader) who initiated the early Fulani jihad in West Africa. Born in Futa Tooro on the Senegal River in what is now Senegal, he moved to Futa Jallon in current Guinea in 1797. There, he studied and studied the teachings of the Tijaniyyah Sufi order. In 1805, he declared a Jihad, or holy war, against the non-Muslim communities in the region, beginning with the Sosso kingdom in what is now Guinea. His newly formed Islamic state was known as the Fulani Empire and grew to include parts of modern-day Nigeria, Senegal, Guinea, Mali, Niger, and Burkina Faso.

Modibo Adama (1750–1850) was an early leader of the Bornu Empire, a well-known Fulani Islamic Sultanate located in what is now northern Nigeria and parts of Chad and Cameroon. A respected religious leader and warrior, Modibo Adama provided a powerful and stabilizing force during a period of profound change and unrest during the nineteenth century. He is credited with reforming the Bornu style of government and reinstating Bornu's pre-colonial reputation as one of West Africa's most important states. 

Modibo Adama's rule in Bornu began in 1790 when he was chosen by his father to take the place of Shehu Umar, the Emir of Bornu. A gifted administrator and formidable military leader, Modibo Adama maintained close ties with Bornu's neighbors and protected the expanding Empire from its enemies. Under his guidance, Bornu reached new heights of prosperity and stability, and prospered both economically and academically. He gained respect from many influential people, including English explorers and military officers. As a ruler, he was admired for his fair and just treatment of his subjects and his commitment

Modibo Adama (born 1940) is a Malian lawyer, professor, and politician who served as President of Mali from 1972 to 1980. He came to power through a military-led coup in 1968, but was confirmed in office and re-elected in 1972. In 1975 he declared Mali a one-party state and in 1976 he declared a socialist revolution. His regime was characterized by a Soviet-style economic plan, while at the same time he opened diplomatic relations with the U.S., the European Economic Community and with other African nations. By 1978, soaring inflation, labor unrest, and increasing international pressure led him to agree to the creation of a more representative government, in which political parties were allowed to exist and compete in elections. In the same year, he accepted the appointment of the National Council of the Revolution, which had the power to override presidential decisions. Adama's government fell to a military coup in March 1980, and he was imprisoned until 1991.

Modibo Keïta ( c. 1915 – 15 May 1977) was the first President of Mali (1960–1968), after having led the nation to independence from France. Born in Kayes, he was a loyal disciple of nationalist leader Sékou Touré and a dedicated Pan-Africanist. He also became a symbol of African populism, winning the enthusiastic approval of the Mali masses through his championing of the poor.

He devoted much of his life to a struggle for a better life, greater social justice and freedom from the colonial yoke. At the same time, he worked hard to promote a Pan-Africanist ideal based on solidarity, nonalignment and the empowerment of African people. He died in premature exile in Morocco in May, 1977, following a period of military rule in Mali.
40:
Gia Marie Carangi (January 29, 1960 – November 18, 1986) was an American fashion model during the late 1970s and early 1980s. Dubbed by some as the "first supermodel", she was featured on the cover of fashion magazines, including multiple editions of Vogue and Cosmopolitan, and appeared in advertising campaigns for numerous brands.

Carangi's career rapidly declined due to her battles with drug addiction. Her death at the age of 26 from AIDS-related complications had a significant impact on the public awareness of the disease. Irena Sendler (née Krzyzanowska; 15 February 1910 – 12 May 2008) was a Polish social worker, humanitarian, nurse and Nazi resistance member who served in the Żegota resistance in German-occupied Warsaw during World War II. She was credited with saving up to 2,500 Jewish children of Warsaw by smuggling them out of the Warsaw Ghetto, providing them with false identity documents and shelter in individual or Catholic-church-run orphanages throughout the city. Sendler was arrested in 1943 by the German Gestapo and sentenced to death, but was ultimately saved by her Żegota co-workers.

For her wartime activities, Sendler was awarded the Order of the Righteous Among the Nations in 1965 by the state of Israel. In 2003, journalist Anna Mieszkowska from the Polish Catholic news agency KAI discovered Sendler's wartime activities and began publicizing her story. Sendler went on to receive several public honors in Poland and internationally for her wartime heroic efforts.

Irena Sendler (née Krzyżanowska; 15 February 1910 – 12 May 2008) was a Polish social worker, humanitarian, and nurse who served in the Polish Underground during World War II in German-occupied Warsaw. She was noted for helping to save the lives of 2,500 Jewish children by smuggling them out of the Warsaw Ghetto and providing them with false identity documents and shelter in the non-Jewish population. To Memory of the Just, an organization honoring the memory and work of people such as Sendler, awarded her the title of "Righteous Among the Nations", an honorific given by the State of Israel to recognize non-Jews who risked their lives during the holocaust to save Jews from extermination by the Nazi's. Sendler also served as a codename in the Żegota, the Polish Underground organization established to aid Jews and was responsible for much of the plumbing and sanitation during the Warsaw Uprising.

Irena Sendler (née Krzyżanowska; 15 February 1910 – 12 May 2008) was a Polish nurse, social worker, and humanitarian who served in the Polish Underground Resistance during World War II. She was the head of the Children's Section of Żegota, the Polish Council to Aid Jews. Operating under the pseudonym "Jolanta", Sendler helped smuggle some 2,500 Jewish children out of the Warsaw Ghetto and then provided them with false identity documents and shelter in private homes, orphanages and convents, saving those children from the Holocaust.

Irena Sendler (née Krzyżanowska; 15 February 1910 – 12 May 2008) was a Polish nurse and social worker who served in the Polish Underground during World War II. In German-occupied Poland, Sendler smuggled over 2,500 Jewish children out of the Warsaw Ghetto and provided them with false identities, thereby saving their lives. For her work, she was recognized as a Righteous Among the Nations by the State of Israel and the Yad Vashem Holocaust memorial in 1965. For many years she remained unrecognized for her wartime activities due to the Communist regime in Poland at the time. In 2003, Sendler was awarded the Order of the White Eagle, the highest Polish honor, for her wartime humanitarian efforts. She died in 2008 in Warsaw.

Irena Sendler (née Krzyżanowska; 15 February 1910 – 12 May 2008) was a Polish humanitarian, social worker, and nurse who served in the Polish Underground during World War II in German-occupied Poland. She is credited with saving the lives of more than 2,500 Jewish children, who were put in danger during the Holocaust by giving them new identities and facilitating their escape. By giving them shelter in individual and group homes, her network provided food, clothing, fake documents and other supplies to help the Jewish children survive. She was arrested by the Gestapo, imprisoned and sentenced to death, but with the help of others, she avoided execution. 

Sendler's actions were recognized by the State of Israel, which gave her a title of Righteous Among the Nations by the Yad Vashem Holocaust memorial. She was awarded the Order of the White Eagle, Poland's highest honor, along with other distinctions, including the Order of Polonia Restituta and Honorary citizenship of Jerusalem. She received further recognition in 2003, being nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize.

Irena Sendler (15 February 1910 – 12 May 2008) was a Polish social worker, humanitarian, and nurse who served in the Polish Underground in German-occupied Warsaw during World War II. She is credited with saving the lives of more than 2,500 Jewish children and infants by smuggling them out of the Warsaw Ghetto and finding concealed homes for them in other parts of the city. Sendler was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize in 2007, although she was not ultimately selected as the awardee. In 1965 she was recognized as one of the Righteous Among the Nations by Yad Vashem. In 2003, Sendler was honored with the Order of the White Eagle, the highest Polish state decoration.

Irena Sendler (née Krzyżanowska; 15 February 1910 – 12 May 2008) was a Polish social worker and humanitarian who served in the Polish Underground and saved 2,500 Jewish children during the Holocaust by providing them with false identities and hiding them in individual and group children's homes.

In Poland during World War II, Sendler (codename "Jolanta") was a member of Żegota, the Polish Council to Aid Jews, a resistance organization in German-occupied Poland. Irena Sendler (née Krzyżanowska; 15 February 1910 – 12 May 2008) was a Polish social worker, humanitarian, and nurse who served in the Polish Underground resistance during World War II and saved thousands of Jewish children in German-occupied Poland from the Holocaust by smuggling them out of the Warsaw Ghetto and then finding non-Jewish families to give them shelter. Irena Sendler (née Krzyżanowska; 15 February 1910 – 12 May 2008) was a Polish nurse and social worker who served in the Polish Underground in German-occupied Warsaw during World War II and was arrested by the Gestapo. She is credited with saving the lives of over 2,500 Jewish children by smuggling them out of the Warsaw Ghetto, providing them with false identity documents and shelter outside the Ghetto in Catholic convents, orphanages and private homes. She was fatally infected with tuberculosis while working in the Ghetto in 1942, and was recognized after her death for her courageous efforts.

Irena Sendler (née Krzyżanowska; 15 February 1910 – 12 May 2008) was a Polish social worker, humanitarian, and nurse who served in the Polish Underground Resistance during World War II in German-occupied Warsaw. In German-occupied Poland, Sendler was part of the Polish Underground and saved about 2,500-3,500 Jewish children from the Warsaw Ghetto, providing them with false documents and sheltering them with Christian families or in convents, orphanages, and other care facilities. Along with her network of thirty-five individuals, Sendler smuggled the children out in ambulances, trams, and even wheelbarrows, in some cases dressing them as bundles of rags. Irena Sendler (15 February 1910 – 12 May 2008) was a Polish Catholic nurse and social worker who served in the Polish Underground in German-occupied Warsaw and was instrumental in saving the lives of 2,500 Jewish children by smuggling them out of the Warsaw Ghetto. She was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize in 2007 and was granted the title of Righteous Among the Nations by Yad Vashem in 1965. Irena Sendler (née Krzyżanowska; 15 February 1910 – 12 May 2008) was a Polish social worker who served in the Polish Underground resistance movement during World War II in German-occupied Warsaw. She was one of about 2,500 members of non-Jewish Poles who rescued Jews during the Holocaust.

Sendler, Irena's nom de guerre was Jolanta, ran a "children's section" of Żegota, the underground organization set up in October 1942 by the Polish government in exile, to help polish Jews in German-occupied Poland. She was credited with saving 2,500 Jewish children during the Holocaust by providing them with false identity documents and sheltering them in individual and group children's homes. She smuggled the children out of the Warsaw Ghetto, providing them with forged documents, and found non-Jewish families to hide them. For over two and a half years she lived in constant fear of arrest by the Gestapo, but continued her rescue activities.

44: A.P.J. Abdul Kalam (15 October 1931 – 27 July 2015) was an Indian statesman who served as the 11th President of India from 2002 to 2007. He was born and raised in Rameswaram, Tamil Nadu and studied physics and aerospace engineering. He spent the next four decades as a scientist and science administrator, thus earning the sobriquet "Missile Man of India" for his work on the development of ballistic missile and launch vehicle technology. He also played a pivotal organizational, technical and political role in India's Pokhran-II nuclear tests in 1998, the first since the original nuclear test by India in 1974. Kalam was elected as the 11th President of India in 2002 with the support of both the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party and the then-opposition Indian National Congress. Widely referred to as the "People's President", he returned to his civilian life of education, writing and public service after a single term. He was a recipient of several prestigious awards, including the Bharat Ratna, India's highest civilian honour.

He spent the next four decades as a scientist and science administrator, mainly at the Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO) and Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO). He received several prestigious awards, including the Bharat Ratna, India's highest civilian honour."

She currently stars as the voice of Grandmother Willow in Disney's animated Pocahontas and its sequel, Pocahontas II: Journey to a New World.

Linda Hunt (born April 2, 1945) is an American film, stage and television actress. She is best known for her Oscar-winning portrayal of Billy Kwan, a male Chinese-Australian photojournalist, in the 1983 film The Year of Living Dangerously. Her other film work includes Dune, The Quartermass Conclusion, The Mighty, Pocahontas, She-Devil, Kindergarten Cop and Death Becomes Her. On television she played the role of Nancy O'Neal in the NBC television series Emanuelle in America. She has also had guest roles on such television shows as Ally McBeal, Law & Order, Boston Public, NYPD Blue, Grey's Anatomy, NCIS, Parks and Recreation, Bones, Person of Interest and the sitcoms Life in Pieces, Scandal and Big Bang Theory.
