Josiah Mason (1795–1881) was an English businessman, philanthropist and a noted Birmingham manufacturer. He is credited as the founder of Mason Science College, which evolved into Aston University, and of Mason College, Belfast, which became the University of Belfast. Mason was among the first English industrialists to build model villages for millworkers in the industrial towns, and invested heavily in educating workers through various scholarships. He introduced pension funds and companies assistance funds in connection with his own businesses, at a time when such generosity was not common. He was the first employer to introduce a half-holiday on Wednesdays, which had been proposed in 1844. 

Mason made his fortune in the manufacture of keys and small tools, pin, needles and steel pen nibs, for which he gained a world-wide reputation, having sold his wares in many countries. He was said to be the largest pin manufacturer in the world. He was also a keen philanthropist, believing firmly in the Christian imperative to “do unto others as you would have them do unto you,” and investing in education and improving the lives of

Josiah Mason (22 January 1795 – 21 March 1881) was an English industrialist and philanthropist. Born at Camp Hill in Birmingham, Mason was a self-taught man who started his working life at age twelve as an errand boy in a Birmingham hardware store. By the age of twenty-three he had amassed a considerable fortune and moved to the village of Erdington, where he constructed a "model village" of some 500 homes. His charitable works included the founding of Mason College, the first teacher training college in Birmingham and a school of science and industry in Birmingham, an industrial school in Gower Street, Bloomsbury and the Mason Science College. He also established orphanages in Birmingham and London, gave away millions of pounds to charities and set up permanent endowments for numerous religious and educational works.

Josiah Mason (25 December 1795 – 22 August 1881) was an English industrialist and philanthropist. Mason was born in Mill Street, Wednesbury in the Black Country of England. He was the son of a farmer, but had little formal education. After having worked in a factory, he started his own short-lived business in 1817, which failed in 1820. Thereafter, he began manufacturing steel-pens and related items, eventually founding seven industrial companies in the Birmingham area. His companies included a steel-pen factory in Birmingham, the Birmingham Tinytot Factory and the Soho Foundry.

Mason was known for his philanthropy and was generous with his employees, providing firewood, soup kitchens, housing, pensions and schools. He created an endowment for a scholarship at Mason College, later incorporated into the University of Birmingham. He also founded the Josiah Mason Trust which provides grants and funding to local communities in the West Midlands. Mason never married and retired from his business in 1871. He died at his home in Calthorpe Road, Edgbaston, Birmingham, in 1881.

Josiah Mason (4 December 1795 – 8 October 1881) was an English industrialist, philanthropist and Conservative politician. Born into poverty at Cold Norton, Oxfordshire, where he was apprenticed to a master tailor, he was inspired by the teachings of Methodism and later became a well-known industrialist in Birmingham and pledged himself to improve the life of its citizens. Mason made his fortune through his manufacture of steel pen nibs, and went on to become one of Birmingham’s most generous philanthropists. He made large donations to universities, hospitals and schools, and an endowment of his Birmingham residence purchased the formation of Mason University College, dedicated to the education of women. He also founded an orphanage and several almshouses. In addition, he was instrumental in founding Birmingham's public library. Mason was a self-made man, never losing sight of his humble roots which attracted admiration and respect from his contemporaries.

Josiah Mason (28 November 1795 – 16 January 1881) was an English industrialist who, at the height of his career, was the wealthiest man in Birmingham, England. Mason built a substantial industrial fortune as a manufacturer and dealer of steel pen tips, with a foundation of money made from engineering, manufacturing and property investments. He was primarily known for his public works and philanthropic activities, establishing hospitals, schools, a college and an orphanage in Birmingham. He also founded the Mason Science College in Birmingham, which is now part of the University of Birmingham.

Josiah Mason (21 December 1795 – 8 August 1881) was an industrialist and philanthropist from Birmingham, England. After starting life as an engraver's apprentice, Mason made his fortune as a manufacturer of steel pens, becoming one of the wealthiest business owners in Victorian Birmingham. He was also a noted benefactor, donating large sums of money to hospitals, schools, and other charitable causes. Mason funded the construction of St. Joseph's Hospital and founded the Birmingham and Midland Institute and Mason Science College. The latter institution eventually became the University of Birmingham.

Josiah Mason (1795–1881) was an English industrialist and philanthropist who was most notable for having founded Mason Science College in Birmingham, England. He made his fortune after leaving his position as an apprentice joining a cutlery business and selling steel pens. He was one of the wealthiest men in the United Kingdom in his day and donated much of his wealth to his numerous philanthropic causes. Many of the charities he supported were associated with the city of Birmingham, as he believed in its potential for growth. These included a school for the benefit of servant girls, the Josiah Mason Orphanage, a ragged school, a working-men's college, and the Birmingham and District Hospital Saturday and Holiday Fund. He became one of Birmingham’s earliest mayors, a Justice of the Peace, and a Deputy Lieutenant of Warwickshire.

Josiah Mason (21 April 1795 – 16 October 1881) was an English industrialist and philanthropist. He began as a pin maker, and built up a successful business empire that included steel pen and needle making. His philanthropic work included establishing an orphanage and educational trust providing practical education to working class children. He also endowed one of Birmingham's principal hospitals and provided significant contributions to the University of Birmingham. His most notable contribution was the endowment of Mason Science College, which later evolved into the University of Birmingham, regarded as the first civic or 'red brick' university in the UK. Mason's business empire survives to this day, as part of A.T. Cross Company.

Josiah Mason (25 June 1795 – 11 November 1881) was a self-made manufacturer and philanthropist from the English Midlands. Born in Coventry, England, he trained in pen-manufacture from 1810, and between 1821 and 1852 alone, he acquired over a dozen patent rights for improvements in the manufacture of pens, re-shaping Birmingham into the world's leading manufacturer of pens and steel products. Mason is thought to be the most influential figures in the industrialization of the Midlands.

His philanthropy was such that he provided funding for various educational, medical, and other charitable institutions both in the Midlands region and further afield. By his will he provided for the founding of Mason College, now the University of Birmingham, and endowed the school with £500,000. He also provided endowments for St Paul's Church, Birmingham, and in London, Somerset House. One of his more remarkable gifts was the construction and endowment of the Mason Science College in Birmingham. 

He was also a prominent freemason, having been a confirmed member of the Coventry Providence Lodge by 1827.

Josiah Mason (4 December 1795 – 13 August 1881) was an English industrialist, entrepreneur and philanthropist. Born into a poor family and gifted with little formal education, Mason made his fortune producing pens, steel, mortars and mechanical staplers. He also ventured into banking and founded the prominent Birmingham-based firm of J. Mason and Co.

Mason was known for his philanthropy and for being a prodigious benefactor to the Town of Birmingham, particularly in providing, financing and supporting education, health, museums and libraries. He supported his own hospital, the Mason Science College, Birmingham School of Art (the first such institution outside of London) and numerous other charities and philanthropic causes. In 1879 he contributed £250,000 to the construction of the Birmingham and Midland Institute and served as President of the Birmingham and Midland Society for the Promotion of the Fine Arts. He was also instrumental in the founding of the Midland Institute of Natural Science (now the Birmingham Natural History Museum).

Josiah Mason (23 October 1795 – 17 June 1881) was an English industrialist and philanthropist. Born in Borras near Oswestry, Shropshire, he rose from a humble background to become Mayor of Birmingham, a founder of Mason Science College and numerous other charities and cultural assets, including the art gallery in Birmingham, the parks in Birmingham, and the Mason's Arms in Edgbaston. Mason moved to Birmingham in 1822 and apprenticed himself to a pen and pencil maker. Through hard work and thrift he was able to grow his business to include steel pens and pencils, and become extremely wealthy. He was noted for his strong religious convictions and was a major supporter of the Bible Christian Church. His philanthropic works were said to be vast and widespread, the most notable of which were the establishment of Birmingham Town Hall, which was built free of charge, the Birmingham Orphanage, and the ransoming of poor Irish children from workhouses. He is generally regarded in Birmingham as one of the most prominent figures in the history of the city.

Josiah Mason (1795–1881) was an English industrialist who made a fortune from manufacturing steel pen nibs. He was born into a poor family and only left school at age 11 to become an apprentice pen-maker. He eventually moved to Birmingham and set up his first pen-making business in1821. By the mid-1850s, Mason's steel pen-making business was the largest of its kind in the world. He soon diversified into other areas such as ironmongery, the production of iron castings, and later on he built the Mason Science Hall and College in Birmingham. Mason was also a very generous philanthropist who used his wealth to support numerous charities as well as to fund new buildings and public works. He was made a baronet in 1873 and died in 1881.

Josiah Mason (1795–1881) was an English educator, industrialist, philanthropist, and manufacturer. From humble beginnings as the son of a tenant farmer and a seamstress, he worked his way up to become one of the wealthiest men in England. Mason acquired vast wealth through his extensive business ventures in the building and engineering trades, and also through other investments. He founded the successful firms George Richards & Co., and Josiah Mason & Sons, and built a model village in Birmingham. Mason used his wealth to establish several educational institutions, including the famous Mason Science College, now known as the University of Birmingham. He also gave away an estimated £2.5 million to charities and other causes during his lifetime.

Josiah Mason (July 1, 1795 – January 8, 1881) was an English philanthropist and industrialist who founded many of the factories and institutions in and around Birmingham, England, in the 19th century. Mason was born into a poor family in Kidderminster and received no formal education, yet he became enormously wealthy through his own industry. He established several factories and industrial institutions, developed the town of Erdington, and funded a range of public projects, which together formed a lifelong work of philanthropy. Mason's most widely known enterprise was the manufacturing of steel pen nibs, with the first Mason pen nibs issued in 1822. Mason later established a college, hospital and several schools, and gave large donations to charity.

Josiah Mason (12 January 1795 – 15 December 1881) was an English philanthropist and industrialist from Aston, Birmingham, England. With a legacy of over £2 million, Mason was a major figure in the industrial transformation of the city and was respected for his public benefactions. 

He was born on 12 January 1795 at Darlaston, Staffordshire to a family of traders and lived his whole life in the city. In 1813, Mason set up a machine file-cutting workshop in Aston where he used the latest machinery and clockwork principles to develop a highly successful business. Mason's factory later supplied files to the British government during the Crimean War and the American Civil War.

Mason established several schools and educational charities as a way of putting his wealth to good use. One of the schools he founded was Mason Science College, established with the idea of providing primary through to college education. Mason also founded a teacher-training college to educate teachers in the fundamentals of teaching and other subjects such as the sciences.

Mason was known for his charity and philanthropy, donating money to the poor, founding charities

Josiah Mason (1795–1881) was an English industrialist and philanthropist. Born in Kidderminster in 1795, he was the son of Edmund Mason and Sarah Stretton. He began working at a cotton mill at the age of nine, and by the age of twenty he was running a business of his own. He established several successful businesses throughout his lifetime, including a scythe factory, pen manufactory, chemical works, and a hardware business.

In 1850, Mason relocated to Birmingham, where he established a new business in the jewelry trade. He was a benefactor of the city, having financed the building of schools, colleges, orphanages, hospitals, and other charities. He also donated money to many other causes and charities throughout England. Mason was also a successful politician, having been elected Mayor of Birmingham in 1862. He died in 1881, leaving a large fortune and an impressive philanthropic legacy.

Josiah Mason (1795–1881) was an English industrialist, philanthropist and founder of Birmingham's Mason Science College, now part of the University of Birmingham.

Mason was born in 1795 in Hertfordshire and received a basic education until the age of 14, when he was apprenticed to an uncle in Warrington. After six years of training, Mason moved to Birmingham and began working in metal-trading. He soon rose to prominence in business, owning metal works at Erdington, Aston, and Wolverhampton, and manufacturing pens and other metal items.

Mason's significant contribution to the progress and prosperity of Birmingham was the establishment of the Mason Science College in 1875. The college was founded to provide instruction in scientific studies, mechanical engineering and chemical science, with a museum, a chemical laboratory, and a lecture theatre.

Mason was a generous philanthropist and gave away large sums of money during his lifetime. In 1845, he provided £5,000 to St. Martin's Church in Birmingham, which enabled its extension in 1846. In total, Mason gave away more than

Josiah Mason (1795–1881) was an English industrialist and philanthropist. Born in Moseley, Worcestershire, England, Mason was the youngest of nine children born to Richard and Elizabeth Mason. Orphaned at age 15, Mason earned his own living after being apprenticed to a letter-file maker. In 1821 he established his own business manufacturing steel pens in a small Birmingham workshop. His success was rapid, and within four years he had built up a thriving business manufacturing a range of goods from needles to shoelaces. He developed the Birmingham steel pen trade and was the first to manufacture pens using machinery.

Mason became increasingly involved in philanthropic activities, donating the land and buildings that formed the nucleus of the Mason Science College, Birmingham. He was President of the Birmingham and Midland Institute, a respected educational centre, and he was heavily involved in the foundation of the Birmingham Royal School of Medicine and Surgery. He also established a number of charities to assist the local population. Mason was made a baronet of the United Kingdom in 1875. He died in 1881, leaving a large personal

Josiah Mason (15 December 1795 – 1 October 1881) was an English industrialist and philanthropist in the Victorian era. He made his fortune in the pen trade, manufacturing pen nibs and other items of stationery. Mason founded Anstey College in Birmingham, which was later renamed the Mason Science College in his honour. He also founded the Mason's Trust, which in turn founded the Mason's Hospital, established in 1881 for the benefit of elderly people in Birmingham. Mason helped finance the Birmingham and Midland Institute (BMI) and many other public institutions in Birmingham. He was made a baronet in 1871 in recognition of his charitable works.

Josiah Mason (November 15, 1795 – January 12, 1881) was an English industrialist, philanthropist and Freemason whose wealth was made from manufacture of pens. Mason had financial backing from the Big Birth brothers of Birmingham, England. He moved to the city in 1821 and started up his business. Initially, his business focused on the production of steel pens, the process of cleaning, grinding and electroplating into a usable form. His steel pens were sold all over the world, making Mason one of the wealthiest entrepreneurs in Birmingham.

Mason was a generous philanthropist, donating a large part of his fortune to numerous charities, hospitals, schools and educational institutions. He was a member of the Masonic Order and gave substantial donations to the Birmingham Masonic Lodge. He also provided a building for a deaf and dumb school in Birmingham. Mason was also a founder of Mason Science College, a part of the University of Birmingham, established in 1875. Mason died in 1881, leaving his wealth to his wife and three daughters.

Frankie Lymon (September 30, 1942 – February 27, 1968) was an American rock and roll/rhythm and blues singer and songwriter, best known as the lead singer of the New York City-based early rock and roll group The Teenagers. Lymon was one of the first rock and roll stars of the 1950s, achieving mainstream success with "Why Do Fools Fall in Love", which hit No. 6 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart in 1956. During his short career, Lymon had several solo hits, including "Goody Goody", "Little Girl", and "The ABCs of Love". He sang lead vocals on "Out in the Cold Again" and "Creation of Love", and was posthumously inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame as a member of the Teenagers in 1993. Lymon was one of the first African-American singers to attract white teenage audiences. His singing voice and naive style had a major influence on the development of rock and roll.

Frankie Lymon (September 30, 1942 – February 27, 1968) was an American rock and roll/rhythm and blues singer and songwriter, best known as the lead singer of The Teenagers. He was one of the first rock and roll musicians to be targeted towards a teenage audience, and his group's hits, including "Why Do Fools Fall in Love", "Goody Goody", and "I'm Not a Juvenile Delinquent", bridged the gap between rhythm and blues and rock and roll. Frankie Lymon (September 30, 1942 – February 27, 1968) was an American rock and roll and R&B singer and composer. He was the prototypical child star, having success at the age of 13 with the Teenagers in 1955 with the song "Why Do Fools Fall in Love". 

The song—"Why Do Fools Fall in Love"—and related hits helped define the pre-Beatles era of rock and roll and put Lymon on the path to becoming one of the major voices of American popular music for a brief period in the mid-1950s. Lymon's story of fame and decline has been the basis of several books and a high-profile Hollywood movie.

Frankie Lymon (September 30, 1942 – February 27, 1968) was an American rock and roll/rhythm and blues singer and songwriter, best known as the lead singer of the New York City-based early rock and roll group The Teenagers. Frankie Lymon (September 30, 1942 – February 28, 1968) was an American rock and roll/rhythm and blues singer and songwriter, best known as the lead singer of the New York City-based early rock and roll group The Teenagers. Frankie Lymon (September 30, 1942 – February 27, 1968) was an American rock and roll/rhythm and blues singer and songwriter, best known as the lead singer of the New York City-based early rock and roll group The Teenagers. Lymon was one of the first African-American teenage stars to attract a white teen audience. The group's first single, "Why Do Fools Fall in Love", was also their biggest hit.

Frankie Lymon (September 30, 1942 – February 27, 1968) was an American rock and roll/rhythm and blues singer and songwriter, best known as the lead singer of The Teenagers. Frankie Lymon (September 30, 1942 – February 27, 1968), born Franklin Joseph Lymon, was an African-American rock and roll/rhythm and blues singer, songwriter, and producer, best known as the main songwriter and lead singer of the New York City-based early rock and roll group Frankie Lymon & the Teenagers. The group was composed of five boys, all in their early to mid-teens. Lymon was the "soul" of the group, acting as its lead singer, chief songwriter, and general spokesman/manager.

Frankie Lymon (September 30, 1942 – February 27, 1968) was an American rock and roll/rhythm and blues singer and songwriter, best known as the lead singer of the group Frankie Lymon and the Teenagers. Rand argued that individuals should accept responsibility for their own actions and that the only social system consistent with this responsibility was full respect for individual rights.

Thomas Clayton Wolfe (October 3, 1900 – September 15, 1938) was an American novelist of the early 20th century. Wolfe wrote four lengthy novels, plus many short stories, dramatic works and novellas. He is known for mixing highly original, poetic, rhapsodic, and impressionistic prose with autobiographical writing. His books, written and published from the 1920s to the 1940s, vividly reflect on American culture and the mores of that period. 

 Wolfe was born in Asheville, North Carolina, the youngest of eight children of William Oliver Wolfe and Julia Elizabeth Westall, whose ancestors had moved to America from Ireland during the early 1800s. Wolfe had an unconventional education, attending college in his home city, studying briefly at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill. Wolfe went on to Harvard and received his B.A. (with honors) in 1922. He returned to North Carolina and taught in the Durham public schools, which his siblings also attended.

Thomas Clayton Wolfe (October 3, 1900 – September 15, 1938) was an American novelist of the early 20th century. Wolfe wrote four lengthy novels, plus many short stories, dramatic works, and novellas. He is known for mixing highly original, poetic, rhapsodic, and impressionistic prose with autobiographical writing. His books, written and published from the 1920s to the 1940s, vividly reflect on American culture and the mores of that period. He wrote during the period of the Lost Generation, though his work has since been reevaluated for its importance, for he was one of the first deeply personal American authors and wrote stories that can only be described as "American."

Wolfe's novels have been read by intellectuals and the general public alike, and have been called masterpiece of literature. His best-known works are Look Homeward, Angel (1929), Of Time and the River (1935), and You Can't Go Home Again (1940). He is also known for his many visits to the Western North Carolina mountains as a youth, which he wrote extensively about in collections of highly personal non fiction essays

Riccardo Tisci (born 1974) is a fashion designer best known as the former creative director at Givenchy. Tisci was born in Taranto, Italy and studied in London's Central Saint Martins College of Art and Design. He started his career as creative director of Italian fashion house Puma, before joining Givenchy in 2005.

Returning the French couture brand to its former glory, Tisci was credited with helping to make Givenchy one of the world's most desirable fashion labels. During his tenure, he re-designed the brand’s iconic logo and its seasonal ad campaigns, and received critical acclaim for his collections. He has collaborated with the likes of Nike, Beats by Dre, and Notorious BIG on fashion. He has officially left the fashion house after twelve years, and is currently under contract with Burberry.

Riccardo Tisci (born 1974) is an Italian fashion designer best known as the former Creative Director of French luxury fashion house Givenchy. Tisci began his career in 1995 when he was appointed as the chief designer of the Italian fashion label Just Cavalli, before joining the house of Givenchy in 2005. During his 12-year tenure at the helm of the French fashion house, he started a fashion revolution, modernising the brand and taking it to international recognition. Tisci was behind a string of famous couture creations and campaigns, including the greatly successful fragrance Givenchy L’Interdit, and was instrumental in the rise of celebrity endorsements in the industry. He is a notable figure in the fashion industry, being the first Italian designer to hold such a prestigious high-profile position. He retired from Givenchy in 2017 and launched his own eponymous luxury label and art platform in 2018.

59: Hephaestion (Ancient Greek: Ἡφαιστίων; c. 356 BC–324 BC) was an ancient Macedonian nobleman and a trusted friend, bodyguard and general of Alexander the Great. He was "by far the dearest of all the king's friends; he had been brought up with Alexander and shared all his secrets" – whenever Alexander wanted something to be done, he entrusted it to Hephaestion. As a sign of favour, Alexander's father, Philip II of Macedon, had granted him the government of the semi-independent north-western region of Macedonia, while Alexander was away at war. Hephaestion held influential positions in Alexander's administration and distinguished himself several times in battle.

Hephaestion (c. 356 BC – 324 BC), son of Amyntor, was a Macedonian nobleman and a general in the army of Alexander the Great. He was arguably Alexander's closest friend and confidant; they were both taught by Aristotle and were close companions throughout Alexander's ambitious campaigns - both were veterans of the Battle of Granicus (334 BC), the first major battle Alexander fought in Asia. He was entrusted with supreme command of the Companion cavalry, served as Alexander's second-in-command, and was personally selected by Alexander in many of the key battles. Although popularly known as a close friend of Alexander, the two distinctive and separate historical figures have been confused in popular culture.

He was killed at the Battle of the Hydaspes in India in 324 BC, after being wounded by an arrow that became infected. After his death, he received divine status as a hero and his body was allegedly bound in beeswax and shipped back to Macedonia for burial in the royal tombs at Vergina. It is widely believed that Alexander's death was linked to his deep grief over the death of Hephaestion.

Hephaestion (Ancient Greek: Ἡφαιστίων, Hēphaistíōn) was a son of Amyntor, a Macedonian noble. He was a close companion and general of Alexander the Great and was by Alexander's side in Naples when news of Philip II's death reached them in 336 BC. Alexander leapt to his feet, and immediately took over from his father, and dedicated a lion to the deceased king.

Hephaestion was an important figure in Alexander's life, and the two became close friends, joining forces in the first battle of their campaign against the Persian Empire. They were known to be so close that it was rumored they could read each other's thoughts, and it appears their relationship grew stronger as they conquered more and more. When Alexander died in Babylon, Hephaestion greatly mourned his friend's death, and swore to continue his campaigns as Alexander had wished. Shortly after, Hephaestion died himself.

Hephaestion (c. 356 BC – 324 BC) was a Macedonian nobleman and a closest companion of Alexander the Great. He was the son of Amyntor, a Macedonian nobleman, and his wife, Ortheia. He was the companion of Alexander until the end of his life, having been brought up with Alexander, having shared his earliest lessons, and having been trained as a cavalry officer by the father of Alexander's future companion and historian, Callisthenes. It is possible that Philip II gave them a joint hegemony over the corinthian district of Akarnania when Alexander left for Asia. 

Hephaestion's strength and general good disposition, combined with his close friendship with Alexander and the high favor he enjoyed with him, made him one of the most powerful men in the Macedonian court. He was among the officers who were sent to request Cleopatra Thea of Egypt to join a coalition against the Perdiccas government, and stayed with her for some time during that mission. In the Partition of Babylon, he was appointed by Alexander as satrap of this province.

Hephaestion (c. 356 BC – 324 BC), son of Amyntor, was a Macedonian nobleman and a general in the army of Alexander the Great. He was 'by far the dearest of all the friends' of Alexander and his 'beloved comrade', and was entrusted with supreme command of the Companion Cavalry, the elite assault force of the Macedonian kingdom. He was part of the royal bodyguard of Alexander the Great and was even presented with a strand of the King's hair when it was cut during the memorial of the Cabeiri festival. At the time of his accidental death in 324 BC, he was second in command of the military successes of Alexander and was given a similar funeral.

Hephaestion (Ancient Greek: Ἡφαιστίων; d. 324 BC), son of Amyntor, was an ancient Macedonian nobleman and a general in the army of Alexander the Great. He was "'by far the dearest of all the friends"' of Alexander and was his second-in-command. -Many of the details of the life of Hephaestion are missing, or were deliberately suppressed by later authors for various reasons, which has caused much speculation in the field of history and historiography. What is known is that he was much-loved by Alexander, as well as many of the other important figures in the Macedonian court.

Hephaestion (; Greek: Ἡφαιστίων, Hēphaistíōn; c. 356 BC – 324 BC), son of Amyntor, was a Macedonian nobleman and a general in the army of Alexander the Great. He was "...by far the dearest of all the king's friends; he had been brought up with Alexander and shared all his secrets." This close relationship between the king and his companion reinforced their very deep connection and as a consequence Hephaestion commanded the loyalty of all Alexander's troops. His closeness to the king was such that he was even addressed as "The beloved".

Hephaestion (Ancient Greek: Ἡφαιστίων, Hēphaistíōn, c. 356 BC – 324 BC) was a Macedonian nobleman and a general in the army of Alexander the Great. He was "by far the dearest of all the friends" of Alexander. He was an adherent of the Eclectic school of philosophy and renowned for his rapport with Alexander. At the wedding of Alexander and Roxana, he was given away as the "brother" of Alexander, who was followed by Eumenes, Ptolemy and Harpalus; sources portray Hephaestion as a "close intellectual companion of the king and his confidant, the most beloved of all Alexander's friends". Alexander refers to him as the "lovliest of mortals."

Hephaestion (c. 356 BC – 324 BC) was a Macedonian nobleman and a general in the army of Alexander the Great. He was Macedonia's second-in-command and was held in high step by Alexander. He was even given the same divine honours as Alexander. Along with Ptolemy, he was one of Alexander's most trusted companions, and was may have been seen by Alexander as a brother or even more.
 
Hephaestion's name means 'strong in set' or 'he of solid formation' in Greek. He was born in 356 BC in Elimeia, an ancient town on the eastern Greek coast. He grew up with Alexander and was a fellow student at Aristotle's academy of learning in Macedonia. He was Tutored by Aristotle alongside Alexander and became close to him. He was close friends with Ptolemy, whom he accompanied in his journeys after the death of Alexander.

Hephaestion (Greek: Ἡφαίστιον, c. 355 – 324 BC), son of Amyntor, was a Macedonian nobleman and a general in the army of Alexander the Great. He was "a nobleman of high birth and remarkable beauty" (Arrian, Anabasis Alexandri 5.1); he was "the handsomest man in the whole of Greece" (Curtius, 10.9.27). He was "the dearest of all the friends" of Alexander (Curtius 8.6.23). He died at the age of thirty-two, after receiving an honorable burial at Babylon in 324 BC.

Hephaestion (; Ancient Greek: Ἡφαιστίων, Hēphaistíōn; c. 356 BC – 324 BC), son of Amyntor, was a Macedonian nobleman and a general in the army of Alexander the Great. He was "...by far the dearest of all the king's friends; he had been shared with him all his secrets, and was called by him 'brother'". He was distinguished for his bravery in battle and his friendship with the king, and shows up in several shared scenes of the Alexander Romance, a hagiography composed hundreds of years after his death. Most historians accept that Alexander and Hephaestion were distinct historical figures and that they were indeed mutual friends. However, their relationship was closer than that of ordinary friends and it is believed that they might have been lovers.

Hephaestion (Ancient Greek: Ἡφαιστίων, Hêphaistíôn; c. 356 BC–324 BC) was a Macedonian nobleman and close friend of Alexander the Great. Although there is little information about his early life and education, he was an intelligent man who distinguished himself as a military commander of Alexander the Great's multi-cultural army during his reign from 336–323 BC. He became a member of the royal bodyguard of Philip II of Macedon and a friend of Alexander the Great. After Alexander's death in 323 BC, he was given the title of chiliarch and honored as the dearest friend of the king. He was very wealthy and held high command in the Macedonian army during the reign of Alexander the Great. His certain death at the Battle of the Hydaspes in 324 BC drastically reduced the influence of the Macedonian nobility.

Hephaestion (Ancient Greek: Ἡφαιστίων, Hēphaistíōn; c.356 BC – October 324 BC), son of Amyntor, was a Macedonian nobleman and a general in the army of Alexander the Great. He was "...by far the dearest of all the king's friends; he had been brought up with Alexander and shared all his secrets." This close relationship lasted until Alexander's death in 323 BC. There is significant evidence that he was held in high regard by Alexander; he was the only non-family member whom Alexander awarded with the supreme gesture of trust, a shared royal diadem. Hephaestion's military career was distinguished. He was one of the top generals in the Macedonian army, ranked second amongst Alexander's officers after Alexander, since Arrian in his accounts of Alexander's campaigns , states that "after Alexander himself, the bravest of the Companions was Hephaestion".

Hephaestion (died 324 BC), son of Amyntor, was a Macedonian nobleman and a general in the army of Alexander the Great. He was "by far the dearest of all the friends" of Alexander, and their relationship lasted throughout their lives. Many speculation arose over the complex emotional relationship between Hephaestion and Alexander and the romantic nature of their relationship. Hephaestion's military career was distinguished. He was a member of the Lamian War, participating in the Battle of Granicus. After the death of Alexander in 323 BC, he was appointed as satrap of Babylonia, but he died of illness in Susa in late 324 BC.

Hephaestion (; Greek: Ἡφαίστιον, Hēphaístion; c. 356 BCE – 324 BCE) was a Macedonian nobleman and a general in the army of Alexander the Great. He was "by far the dearest of all the friends" of Alexander and "the most trusted of all his generals", and his death prompted the famous remark from the king: "Now I have no friend left." He was a son of a Macedonian nobleman named Amyntor and his primary education was received in Pella; he was originally destined for the administrative service in a military career. Ptolemy, one of Alexander's seven bodyguards, stated that he had been loved by Alexander for his pleasant character and good nature.

Hephaestion (also Hephaestus; Ancient Greek: Ἡφαιστίων, Hēphaistíōn; c. 356 – 324 BC), son of Amyntor, was a Macedonian nobleman and a generalservant, companion and advisor of Alexander the Great. He was held in high regard by Alexander, who considered him his "beloved friend", the same rank as his older half-brother, Philip. He is known to have been the most trusted of Alexander's people. Hephaestion had a previous name at birth: Ariston, but was given the name of Hephaestion, after Hephaestus, the Greek god of fire and metalworking, in memory of Alexander's inheritance through his mother of the temple of Hephaestus in Macedonian stage. His death is considered to have had a profound effect on Alexander. Not reported in the historical record, Hephaestion was possibly buried alive alongside Alexander during his funeral procession (a standard Macedonian custom).

Hephaestion (Ancient Greek: Ἡφαιστίων, Hēphaistíōn, c. 356 BC – 324 BC) was a Macedonian nobleman and a general in the army of Alexander the Great. He was "by far the dearest of all the friends" of Alexander and "had been brought up with Alexander and shared all his secrets". He is considered by some to have been Alexander's second-in-command, after being lead companion at the start of Alexander's "Asiatic" campaign in 336 BC, he was the only individual appointed by Alexander to be given the title philokeraunos ("favorably minded towards thunderbolts"), having been granted this for saving Alexander's life at the Granicus. Fittingly, Hephaestion was also given the exclusive privilege of drinking from Alexander's cup denial of which was deemed an insult of the highest degree.

"Hephaestion (died 324 BC), son of Amyntor, was a Macedonian nobleman and a general in the army of Alexander the Great. He was "...probably the dearest of al these friends" to Alexander for a time and "was a fine strategist and noted for his physical beauty." Alexander directly appointed Hephaestion as the viceroy of all the territories east of the Tigris in 330 BC, which was confirmed by the assembly of the League of Corinth in the same year. In autumn 324 BC, Hephaestion had become ill and died in Ecbatana due to a probable malarial infection. He was cremated in Babylon and his ashes were sent to the newly completed temple to him in Macedon. Alexander was devastated by his death, and memorialized him with a boulder monument in the former capital of Iran, Persepolis. After his death, public honors were paid to him, including a sacrifice at the Temple of Hephaestion in Macedon."

"Hephaestion (c. 356 BC – 324 BC), son of Amyntor, was an ancient Macedonian nobleman and a general in the army of Alexander the Great. He was "by far the dearest of all the friends" of Alexander and their relationship lasted his entire life. This friendship may have been based upon a combination of mutual loyalty and military excellence. Hephaestion seems to have been held in even greater regard than most other of Alexander's friends; he was "the beloved of the king". According to Plutarch, Hephaestion was a moderate alcoholic, and was remembered fondly for his love of drinking; "when he was in his cups, he was capable of outrageous behavior". He is known to have made a great sacrifice at the Battle of Issus in 333 BC, when Alexander's forces succeeded in defeating the forces of Darius III of Persia, and Hephaestion killed two Persian nobles who had taken refuge at an altar in the heat of combat. Hephaestion (Ancient Greek: Ἡφαιστίων; c. 356 BC – 324 BC), son of Amyntor, was a Macedonian nobleman and a general in the army of Alexander the Great. He was born in 356 BC and was same age as Alexander. He was taught in the same school as Alexander and was appointed as the cavalry commander of the Companion cavalry, a military unit of the Macedonian army. He shared the same tent as Alexander during their campaigns. Their closeness was such that Arrian (The Campaigns of Alexander) records that even in the face of danger from enemy forces, "The two friends were so inseparable that Alexander neglected his other Companions and went off with Hephaestion on his own. They became lifelong companions." They sacrificed to the gods together and they sent offerings to each other in token of their love.
